151426341.review:
Darksiders 3 marks the return of War's fiery sister, Fury, as she embarks on a perilous quest to restore balance to the world. While the game delivers a thrilling action-RPG experience, it falls short of its full potential due to a few notable shortcomings.

Graphics: A Visual Feast with Technical Hiccups

Darksiders 3 boasts a captivating art style, with environments that range from desolate wastelands to towering demonic fortresses. Character designs are equally impressive, particularly Fury, who exudes both strength and grace. However, the game's technical performance can be inconsistent, with occasional frame rate drops and texture pop-in.

Soundtrack: An Epic Score with Occasional Repetition

The soundtrack of Darksiders 3 is a powerful blend of orchestral and electronic music, perfectly capturing the game's epic scope and dark undertones. The main theme is particularly memorable, its soaring melodies and ominous harmonies setting the stage for Fury's journey. However, some tracks can become repetitive during extended gameplay sessions.

Story Richness: A Tale of Redemption with Unfulfilled Potential

Darksiders 3 delves deeper into the lore of the Darksiders universe, exploring themes of redemption, vengeance, and the struggle to maintain balance in a world teetering on the brink of chaos. Fury's journey is compelling, as she grapples with her own inner demons while fighting against the forces of evil. However, the game's narrative could have benefited from a more fleshed-out exploration of its themes and characters.

Gameplay: A Satisfying Challenge with Room for Refinement

Darksiders 3 offers an engaging blend of combat and exploration. Fury's whip-based combat is fluid and dynamic, allowing for a variety of combos and attacks. The game also introduces new weapons and abilities, adding further depth to the combat system. Exploration is equally rewarding, as the environments are filled with hidden secrets and puzzles to uncover. However, the game's combat can become repetitive at times, and some platforming sections can be frustrating due to imprecise controls.

Overall Impression: A Solid Action-RPG with Room for Growth

Darksiders 3 delivers a thrilling and satisfying action-RPG experience, but it falls short of its full potential due to technical issues, occasional narrative shortcomings, and a combat system that could benefit from further refinement. Despite these flaws, the game's strengths in graphics, atmosphere, and gameplay make it a worthwhile experience for fans of the genre.

149899928.review:
This was my first Darksiders game, so I dived in with no expectations, but ended up really enjoying it. The user rating is really unfair in my opinion, this is a pretty nice and polished game, although not without flaws.

It's not really a souls-like either, there are only some superficial elements, like the "bonfires" you respawn at, the "estus" like healing, animation commitment (can be turned off via the "classic" mode, which I recommend). The game has a 2 weapon combat system, you fight with the whip + one of the 4 elemental weapons (dual chains/fire, spear/lightning, hammer/gravity and dual swords/ice), and there's also a chakram/glaive as your sole ranged option. The combat is much faster paced than Souls and there's a lot of combo potential, e.g. you can do Scorpion's "get over here" thing (from Mortal Kombat) to catch an enemy with your whip and then juggle them. You can also jump, stomp, do charged attacks, and there's even a Devil Trigger like super transformation.

You can't block and the dodge is just a short dodge step, no rolling. The only defensive option is the dodge counter a la Bayonetta/Oneechanbara. You dodge at the last second, the game slows down and you press one of the attack buttons to counter, which deals a lot of damage and has very satisfying animations. This also usually breaks the enemy's combo, thus making a lot of 1v1 fights quite easy. Just bait the first hit, then counter and go ham.

However, the combat system shows its flaws when it comes to group fights. The game loves spamming large groups of fast enemies and even with the whip's wide, sweeping hitboxes it's still easy to get overwhelmed and chain stunlocked, as you can't really dodge counter when surrounded by multiple enemies, so you kind of just pull back and mash. The camera is not the best either, it's too low when locked on, with Fury partially obscuring the opponent.

The enemies hit hard and it's possible to get 2 shot, especially early on when you're low level and don't have any upgrades, however the game offers a plethora of difficulty options to accommodate all skill levels (but none of them will let you just button mash through the game, you still have to counter). I recommend playing on balanced (aka normal) + classic mode (you can dodge cancel your attacks).

There are a lot of boss fights, but none of them are too hard, except for maybe [spoiler]Lust[/spoiler] who's a double boss fight very similar to Ornstein & Smough in Dark Souls, as well as the last boss in the Void Keepers DLC who's a little overtuned.

The game is set in a large interconnected world with no loading screens and numerous shortcuts and secrets to find, and you can tackle the areas and bosses in a non-linear fashion. There are also metroidvania elements, you unlock 4 elemental powers and each comes with multiple new movement abilities (e.g. high jump, wall jump, gliding, walking on water etc). There's a fair amount of platforming and even some puzzles (although nothing too crazy). The game has no map and you're thrown in with no guidance or handholding, which I found really refreshing and fun. The exploration is excellent, you pick a direction, drop down a hole, and can end up somewhere really cool.

While the game is not AAA, the graphics are quite pretty, and the animations are very smooth. The cutscenes are very cinematic and the voice acting is solid. The game runs on Unreal Engine 4 and I haven't encountered any bugs or issues (aside from the missing texture for a shipping container, which you can fix using [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/darksiders3/mods/25]this mod[/url], apparently the texture got lost in one of the updates).

Overall, if you're a fan of challenging action games and metroidvania like exploration with no guidance, Darksiders III is lots of fun and an easy recommendation.

149360715.review:
The game is okay. It's not the best game in the franchise, but definitely playable.

There are bugs here and there, such as falling through the floor, the game freezing as though it has crashed during loading sections, and very sudden performance issues that happen rarely, but are easily fixed by just restarting the game.

Some boss fights are great, others not so much. Most of the bosses don't have the greatest of character designs, and their personalities are fairly one-dimensional, but the same goes for Fury, no matter how hard the script tries to convince you of her character growth.

You are massively rewarded, for the most part, for dodging enemy blows and projectiles via the arcane counter mechanic. Even on Apocalyptic (I am assuming the same applies for Reckoning), you are able to steamroll through the entire game by dodging attacks into arcane counters, or "parries", for massive damage, as long as you've been investing your stat points into Arcane. HOWEVER, dodging can be inconsistent, as the window for a perfect dodge during attack animations, at least according to my own observations, can vary massively from one mob to another -- bosses, on the other hand, are fairly straightforward, as they all attack at consistent enough speeds, and some also have explicit cues that tell you there is going to be an opening for a perfect dodge into arcane counter.

IMHO, I don't think the Souls-inspired gameplay was the best direction for Darksiders III, as the other Darksiders games are very casual-friendly and not too difficult to beat, whereas this one has one too many moments where you just want to uninstall the game. In spite of that, this new-to-the-series difficulty curve can be enjoyed, as long as you have the time to invest.

Story-wise, I believe that this game can be skipped entirely, because it doesn't expand on the Darksiders story all that much. The only important plot threads are, 1. Fury coming to the same conclusions as War; and 2. the not-so-explicit confirmation that the overarching antagonist from Genesis is the same being who is, to a large extent, responsible for the majority of the events in the Darksiders universe. With that said, it is still somewhat enjoyable to play through the story for the first time, if you're a fan of the series. 

Not bad, not great, buy on sale only.

The game would have been better served by having fewer potions and combining the effects and then binding each of them to a direction on the d-pad or giving the play the option to choose which potion was bound to each direction.  Anyway, the point being that it's clunky and it doesn't really work but it can also be ignored (at least on easier difficulties).

There's some unnecessary inventory management required.  This is a minor thing and it didn't bother me that much but why have a section where the only purpose is to go in there and "release" the souls for use?  Well, it actually does make some sense.  If you die, you lose the souls you have collected but you can return to the spot you died and recover them.  So in that context, having a collection of stored souls that can't be lost *does* make sense.  But it seems a like a system that didn't need to exist.  Just make it so you don't lose souls and add those caches to your total souls. 

The weapons were fine and I found myself using most of the base weapons in different scenarios.  However, the DLC weapons didn't seem unique enough to warrant bothering with.

Similarly, there's too many different types of armour in the game, and each buffs a specific type of damage attached to a weapon.  This is kinda clunky because if I want to ensure that I'm not gimping my damage output I need to pick a type of armour and then not switch weapons mid fight... unless I want to pause the game, and equip the armour that buffs that weapons.  You can see the problem.  

Still it didn't stop me switching between weapons in combat but it would have been better if there was just one armour that upgraded to add the buffs for each weapon damage.

There are no maps of any kind in this game and the fast travel system is confusing (possibly because of this).  I've read that this was a deliberate design decision because the developers wanted players to feel lost.  They achieved their goal... and I hated it.  Especially on the second play through where by that time I'd had a decent idea of the places I wanted to visit, but I had trouble extrapolating which fast travel point was the best or quickest to get me there.  It's even more confusing when there are many shortcuts and connections to different zones/areas.  

They obviously noted this because they have tried to incorporate little quality of life tweaks to make it easier.  For example there are markers to the last place you travelled to/from but it's not enough.  They also give you a compass which points you in the direction of the bosses but I didn't use this at all.

This is even more annoying when you factor in that the game wants you to revisit previous areas to find secrets and spots made accessible by new abilities.  All in all, they could have saved themselves (and us) a lot of headaches by just implementing maps.

The dodge mechanic.  I played through on Balanced Difficulty with Classic mode turned on and for the first third of the game I pretty much ignored the mechanic completely.  There's nothing bad about that.  I just prefer it when Darksiders game play embraces it's Hash and Slash roots and I enjoy that.  

However, through out the middle of the game, the bosses become more difficult and I found that I had to start trying to mitigate the damage coming in by dodging.  That's when the frustrations begin.  The problem is - it just doesn't feel good.  If I did a perfectly timed dodge to allow a counter attack, it felt more like luck or a fluke.  I did eventually get better at it but I think it took way too long.  It also seemed off that often the toughest enemies in the game weren't the bosses.

In late game, you start seeing a lot more "mobs" that block.  Combat becomes tedious at this point and after awhile I started running past them because it wasn't worth the time or effort to kill them.

And this brings me to the single biggest problem in the game.  One that had me raging so much on so many occasions that I began to understand why controllers end up embedded in tv's/monitors... the response time or lack of response when attempting to trigger a heal or a special ability.  This drove me absolutely insane.  I'd be mid fight and notice I'm getting low on health.  Press up on the d-pad and continue fighting.  Next thing I know I'm dead. What?! This happened a few times before I noticed that the game was not responding to what I was doing.  In my second play through almost all my deaths were because I died before I noticed that a health power up hadn't worked.  I had similar issues with Wrath and Havoc mode.  

I don't think there's any excuse for this problem and if you've going to make a souls-like game when the play is trying to do something, that thing should happen the first time you do it, every time you do it.

Anyway, as I said at the start, if you take away all these problems the game could have been great instead of just good.  I think this is a game where less would have actually been more.  As shown above, over and over, they built convoluted and/or unnecessary systems where a simple one actually would have served the game better.

I loved the story, the tone, the aesthetic and just generally that I was once again playing as a horseman (which is super cool) so this concept has legs.  I wasn't sure about Fury as a character to begin with but by the end she had grown on me.  It says something about the game that I played through it a second time (something I never do these days) despite all the flaws I've mentioned (and some I haven't).  

The music is understated but well done.  The voice acting was fine.  At times, I found myself getting confused about who was speaking (Fury or the Watcher), but not a big thing.  

I absolutely loved the ending.... and I'm hoping that THQ continues the story with a stand-alone game involving Strife or a final game to bring the series to a conclusion with all horseman being playable.  Even better if they can find a way to make that game Co-Op.

146031340.review:
Darksiders 3 is the black sheep of the Darksiders franchise as some say.
That doesn't mean it's bad, it's still good enough to warrant playing.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]Combat[/b]
No blocking here, only dodge, when you dodge on time you can use a counter attack, dealing a lot more damage and guaranteed to hit. This mechanic is leaned into too hard and becomes a problem later, I'll go into detail on this further down.

Left click to use your whip, right click to use your selected Hollow weapon.
You get four abilities(Hollows) spaced throughout the game, these are primarily used for exploration and puzzles, but also each have their own weapon and wrath attack, you need to have the Hollow selected to use them.

[b]Equipment and Consumables[/b]
You're expected to upgrade your weapons to increase their damage as you progress, but the materials to do so are also very limited, you're better off just upgrading one weapon and nothing else, I suggest the whip because it's always available no matter what Hollow you have active.
Eventually you get a chakram you can throw own its own button, but the same problem applies and it also doesn't have a dodge counter attack.

As for consumables, you have a choice between damage and survivability, no matter what you choose they all go on a shared cooldown, but the items that give you more damage last longer than the cooldown so you can still use something else before it's done.
You start with a two use healing potion that recharges by killing enemies, you can find upgrades for it scattered throughout the game.

There are four armors you can buy in the base game, they all share the same stats except for their bonus damage to their corresponding Hollow.
Abyssal Armor is obtained in a DLC.

[b]Dodging for Damage[/b]
Some enemies can block, you cannot break this blocking and it completely negates damage.
The further into the game you go the more common these enemies are and the more they block.

Later blocking enemies can only be effectively killed by waiting for them to attack so you can counter, this becomes increasingly annoying the more you encounter it, to the point where I just started ignoring enemies when returning to an area.

There is one boss in the game that technically blocks your attacks because it has a lot of moves where it cannot be hit by melee attacks.

[h1]Graphics, sound, and writing[/h1]
Very good, none of the music stood out enough for me to remember it.

[h1]Secrets and Collectables[/h1]
There's a bunch of secret boss fights to find, most I imagine require backtracking once you have the necessary Hollow.

As for collectables, there's humans to rescue and pickups to find, some of which are direct upgrades to your healing potion or a bonus attribute point.

Darksiders, a series that piqued my interest since the first game.. Jumped straight into 3 as soon as I upgraded my PC this year, and I'm having a blast 100% it! The Horseman - Fury is yet another cool as hell protagonist, the comic art style and animation are a feast to the eyes just like any previous Darksiders game.

The game world is well-crafted and it was fun to traverse & explore with Fury's different unique form (Gotta map the run button to an easy click though, I used one of my mouse's side button). Combats are engaging & mostly fun, that is once you get the hang of it I guess, I personally am not too bothered by the mixture of Souls-like elements, it is an acceptable change to the series for me as I feel not all Horsemen have to rely on the same fighting style, Fury being more focused in dodging, utilizing mid & wide-range attack with her whip and no block feels right since she's less "bulky" than the other Horsemen. Story is great too and is a continuation to the series (though it kinda cliff-hanged at the end...).

The one and only thing I frankly dislike is the brutal 'difficulty' at the EARLIER stage of the game, it sadly, does make me feel as though it is more or less 'artificial'... Playing through the entire game makes me realize the pacing curve and balance are really not too well done. Let me try to elaborate - firstly, the creeps at the earlier stage are strangely, VERY aggressive and quick, coupled with their immensely painful damage, Fury can die in just a few quick hits (and they also tend to gank you, plus you can hardly outrun to escape from them..) so it's pretty frustrating while you are still learning the combat, it leave you no room to breathe (and Heal), unlike many other games where they would normally start slow and introduce you weaker enemies at the beginning. And then as the game progress.. More enemies variant that actually attack SLOWER appears, those that are actually less painful to dealt with as you have more reaction window to time your dodge and heal... Odd isn't it..? Also, due to many enemies & bosses that could outright kill Fury in a few hits, DEFENSE are probably the most important stats in the game.. But it was almost non-existence at the earlier stage. The tide only turns once you proceeded pass the game where you can obtain and upgrade the Enhancement that boost your Physical & Arcane defense, then only the game become MUCH MORE tolerable, much much less frustrating stupid death moments due to minor mistakes. The difference gap is so huge it makes me feel like it wasn't really balanced properly, and that is also probably why many players rage quitted the game and calling it "not" Darksiders; I blame it on the bad difficulty curve really.

Oh and I was also baffled by how on earth they don't allow free "Heals" refill at save point, kinda stupid since dying can refill all heals for free..? lol Why would we even pay to buy the "refill" (unless you are a masochist that would play on Nightmare mode)? This again, contributed to the lack of breathing room while you are starting out and still learning the game...

Ugh anyway, rant over and overall I would say it is still a great game at it's core, definitely worth a playthrough if you like combat-heavy action RPG (with a bit of puzzle and platforming). And now, we pray for Darksiders IV...

143133035.review:
Darksiders 3, the first one to depart, more or less from the classic formula the 2 games sort of had. And that's why a lot of people give this game a bad rep. But after finishing it, I disagree on the notion that this is a bad game, since "It's not a darksiders game!" argument holds little weight when this franchise never really had a concrete identity in terms of gameplay style and mechanics, that were 100% its own. 

Now then, the biggest change arguably comes to combat. If you're familiar with Dark Souls, Darksiders 3 follows a similar combat style, with perfect dodges being rewarded with even better counters that do more damage and so on and so forth. If you come into this game from the first 2, without any Souls-like experience, you might find it frustrating at first. Fortunately, the devs listened and added a "classic" combat style for those who preferred the more hack-and-slash nuance from D1 and D2, so it's your choice which combat you go with. Still, the option being there is nice. 

Darksiders 3 also seems to combine bits and pieces from D1 and D2 when it comes to gear progression. You have some form of skill points to invest, though there's no actual talent tree like Death had. The gear itself is gathered by playing the story like in D1, but upgrading it requires materials that are scattered throughout the world. So they don't get stronger just by using them like in D1. I find this balance to be sufficient to be enjoyable without becoming a chore. You can go through the game on any difficulty with upgrading at a normal pace, i'd say. So i never really felt like I suddenly hit a wall. I will say though that the game encourages you to replay it several times, as it gets even harder but with different enemies and loot in the world, so they're really in it for the long run, if you want to max out Fury. The bosses are way more fun mechanically than in D2, simply due to the fact that in D3 the cycle of dodge-and-counter is baked into the core combat system now, which makes it seem less tedious, especially since bosses don't rely on adds anymore. And the combos between the main and secondary weapons flow really well. Overall, even though many hated it for being different, the combat of Darksiders 3 is quite nuanced and deep in my eyes, so it's good enough to be enjoyable. I do miss executions however, and i'll get to that.

Traversal has taken a bit of a hit, due to the nature of a souls-like game. They're not exactly known for parkour sections. That's not to say there's none. Fury is quite agile, able to swing with her whip for example, but I do think she has less options than her brothers, who run across the wall and hang on pillars. The game also never really challenges traversal that much, i think, until the Keepers of Void DLC, but that's fine. Because what Darksiders 3 has over 1 and 2 is the sense of vertical exploration. This map is probably the one who allows to travel you the highest in terms of height for exploration purposes. That comes at the cost of a smaller and closed off overall area compared to something like 2, but i think it worked for the better, considering the circumstances of this game, since we might have never gotten it at all. That being said, many areas can be entered only after progressing further in the story to get a tool/power, so it's encouraged to return. Keep in mind you don't get a map anymore, so better unlock all the Serpent Hole fast travels.

Puzzles are unfortunately, very easy compared to the previous entries. Some probably prefer it that way, but I still felt somewhat empty that nothing in the game really came close to something like the dungeons of the Forgelands, let alone the Ivory Citadel in D2. Alas, not all aspects can be comparable. Not even the dlc puzzles are that challenging to be honest.

Speaking of DLCs, they're fine. As good as the ones for D2 (that were later included in the remaster). I especially like the Crucible for convenience, since there's a lot of cool items you can get from it that helps in regular game. The keepers of void is more about dungeon crawling, but [spoiler] if you want the abyssal armor, you need to get this [/spoiler].

Lastly, Fury herself. In the beginning, I really thought I'd hate her character, especially how she's so full of herself at first. However, the story manages to make her a likable protagonist for this franchise. It's not a ground breaking story by any means, but it's enjoyable and fits the franchise theme. At the time of release for this game, I'd say Fury was a better character than War, since she got way more personality (Still pales compared to Death), but after Genesis, they rank about the same. The dialogue with Strife really elevated War's character.

One gripe i have with this game. Granted, it's something more cinematic related than gameplay. It's that Fury doesn't really seem as visceral as War or Death, which seemed odd considering her personality when she starts the game. Remember how each boss defeated in D1 and D2 had War and Death execute them in a flashy cinematic with signature moves and such? You don't really get that here, and it's a shame. I would have loved to see Fury pull something like that off. The closest thing we get are the perfect counters on fodder enemies, but even then, they're not the same as the executions in the previous games.

Also, if you play this game on a 16:10 aspect ratio or a big resolution in general, you might encounter a bit of a problem where the game screen is very zoomed out. Just fiddle with the settings a bit, and after a few restarts it should be fine. I have encountered a few crashes at certain points, but nothing too bad to make me consider quitting (Like the Kingdom of the Dead in D2). 

Overall, If you love this franchise, I recommend this game wholeheartedly, with both its ups and downs. And throw out the notion of "Darksiders games aren't like X or Y" and just enjoy it. Because Darksiders was never a strict formula, it was always a constantly evolving franchise. So not being the same isn't in any way a valid critic to this game.

As someone who thought Darksiders 2 was a downgrade from the first game, 3 came as even more of a disappointment. At this point the pattern is clear - the developers are more interested in mimicking other games than really finding a voice of their own. They got lucky with 1, overconfident with 2, and 3 proves they're just being lazy.

This time around the gameplay is cribbing Dark Souls - and that's according to the developer. The combat returns to hack and slash mechanics but the souls influence means damage is volatile. The game wants you to make use of evades and counters which do more damage, but enemies also have large HP pools so every fight turns into a slow slog. 

If you try to combo enemies block so you're stuck in the position of playing this anger fuelled character who can't be pro-active in combat and you get punished for trying. This also means Fury comes off as strangely weak and fragile, and don't get me started on the contradictions in her development. Speaking of the story, it ends up being even more filler that throws empty twists and needless turns in that make no sense.

As for gameplay there are a few weapons but none of them are better than the whip so expect to use that the entire time. Most of the movement has been stripped out besides swinging with the whip (what a cop out). The power ups are now just 4 elements each of which let you solve one or two types of puzzle and each puzzle is the same every time. Every environment is the same usual brown, green, and grey boring setting from the past game, as all the colour is now in Fury's hair.

I gave up on this one around the time you get to the scar. It's such a boring and slow paced game that I truly lost any interest in the conclusion. The only message at the core of this game is mixed messaging and trying to create something without having to actually put anything unique in themselves. To think this is where it ended up after such a strong start. Disappointing.

141552622.review:
Al comenzar este juego me pareció como si la saga Darksiders fuera en decadencia, al principio me pareció un combate super simplón sin apenas interacciones con los combos, o formas de alternar entre ataque fuerte y rápido, o entre las propias armas (cosa que no habría estado de más la verdad). Esto viene porque en el Darksiders 1 me pareció bastante profundo el esquema de control para los combates, teniendo una buena cantidad de combos desbloqueables mediante puntos, cosa que ya se perdió en el Darksiders 2 pero si que tenía esa interacción de combos entre la guadaña y el arma secundaria equipada, sin embargo en este Darksiders 3 no tiene eso. Sin embargo, conforme fui avanzando en la aventura vi que esa simpleza a la hora de ejecutar combos se debía a que el foco en el combate hay que ponerlo en otro sitio: La esquiva perfecta e incluso el contraataque tras la esquiva (una especie de parry). 

Este juego castiga bastante los errores, sin haber jugado aún en profundidad a la saga souls me atrevería a decir que bebe bastante de ella, salvando las distancias ya que no hay barra de energía y podemos hacer tanto esquivas como ataques infinitos, sin embargo de lo que si ha tomado inspiración de dicha saga es en la observación del timing en los ataques de los enemigos, aprender a esquivarlos correctamente y después atacar. En las dificultades bajas los enemigos ya pegan bastante duro e incluso los enemigos más débiles pueden suponer un problema si te pillan con la guardia baja.

Esta dureza en el combate es lo que me ha atrapado finalmente, de hecho comencé a hacerme una build a fuerza ya que los ataques principales es lo que más se utiliza durante la aventura, y por lo tanto sería la opción más equilibrada si queremos progresar en el juego. Pero me encantó ese riesgo-recompensa del parry, y por primera vez en la saga me he decantado por el estilo Arcano, donde se potencian los ataques cargados, ataques de esquiva y ataques especiales. Quise jugar buscando no sólo esquivar para evitar el daño, sino esquivar en el momento exacto previo a recibir el impacto para poder aprovecharme de este mayor daño que me brinda esta especie de "contraataque". Equipando las mejoras de daño arcano a las dagas de fuego (mi elemento favorito al jugar con Furia), mejorando su nivel en la forja de Ulthane Martillonegro y todo ello junto los talentos fuertemente hacia arcano, he llegado a hacer más de 1000 puntos de daño tras una esquiva, más luego la quemadura que va desgastando lentamente la vida del enemigo.

Sin embargo como decía antes, no es un juego fácil. Mientras que otros Darksiders he podido jugarlos en dificultad apocalíptica (si no me equivoco es el penúltimo modo más difícil), aquí sin embargo he tenido que jugar en Exigente e incluso a veces bajarlo a Equilibrado (esto sólo me pasó en un tramo hacia el final del juego donde por un error muy tonto, morí hasta 2 veces, siendo una zona sin apenas puntos de guardado respecto al resto de la aventura, y con una gran cantidad de enemigos bastante duros por el camino y en grupos grandes). El tema de la dificultad no es una constante a la hora de jugar a los títulos, en la gran mayoría de los que me causan frustración o sólo quiero avanzar para poder terminarlos (si, ese es un problema que sé que tengo, el querer terminar todos los juegos que empiezo), los acabo jugando a mínima dificultad, para que no me supongan un mayor quebradero de cabeza. En cambio en juegos rápidos tipo hack and slash, acción o plataformas, me gusta ese puntito de exigencia que le dan ese picante al juego, y me hace disfrutarlo más.

El problema es que en este Darksiders 3 (al igual que el resto de la saga), la dificultad simplemente es subir la barra de vida de los enemigos y hacer que sus ataques hagan más daño, dandote un menor número de oportunidades de error, y cuando es de esta manera tampoco me hace disfrutarlo bien. Por eso, entre Exigente y Equilibrado me sentí bastante a gusto, teniendo las oportunidades de error en un valor bajo pero sin ser excesivamente bajo para evitar la frustración y la repetición excesiva.

Tengo que decir que me ha gustado bastante más que Darksiders 2, y se pone prácticamente a la par que el primer Darksiders, siendo bastante diferentes el uno del otro pero siendo muy buenos cada uno en lo suyo.

Entrando a analizar un poco más el resto de apartados del juego, se nota un gran salto gráfico y el trabajo que se ha realizado a nivel técnico, jugándolo ahora casi 6 años después de su lanzamiento, en una Steam Deck proyectada hacia una pantalla de 70" (eso sí, con interpolación), hay que decir que se veía muy espectacular en todo momento, aunque con alguna rascadita de FPS.

La historia me ha parecido muy muy buena, la del primer Darksiders me gustaba mucho la premisa que tenía, pero la de este Darksiders 3 creo que me gusta incluso más, además que al final del juego tiene un buen cierre, dando a Furia un nuevo propósito como protectora de los pocos supervivientes de la raza humana. Sin embargo el personaje de Furia, aunque consigue transmitir la energía y rabia propios de un personaje de este tipo, tengo que decir que a veces me chirriaron los diálogos que tienen ella y la vigilante (se veía a leguas que era la mala, aunque no supuse que fuera uno de los pecados capitales) o incluso ella sola hablando del resto de los jinetes, con comentarios no se si tirando a infantiles, o intentando hacer bromas y chascarrillos que ni hacen gracia ni le pegan al personaje.

De la música, no me ha parecido tan memorable en general como en las otras entregas, pero si tengo que hacer especial mención a la música que suena al iniciar la conversación con Ulthane, mientras realizas las mejoras a las armas. Esa zona de Refugio, es un remanso de paz rodeado de un mundo apocalíptico y repleto de enemigos, y esta música lo transmite muy pero que muy bien, a veces me he quedado en el menú de la forja simplemente para poder escuchar la composición de forma extendida.

Es una pena que parezca que la saga Darksiders esté muriendo. Me gustaría jugar a Darksiders Génesis, que es el que me queda por jugar de la saga principal, pero cambia el tipo de juego a un Hack and Slash de vista isométrica en lugar de en tercera persona (no por desmerecer estos juegos, sino porque cambia completamente respecto a lo que venía siendo la saga), además que es una precuela del primer Darksiders y a mí lo que me gustaría es poder controlar a Lucha en un Darksiders 4, con un esquema de control clásico y una historia potente, que de un buen cierre a la saga. También sueño con un posible reinicio de la saga, donde podamos controlar a todos los jinetes en una aventura en la que estén los 4 implicados al a vez.

Story is signiicantly better than 2's "do fetch quests until the credits" style with Fury actively pursuing the Seven Deadly Sins and learning more about the apocalypse on the way.

Gameplay is slower than its predecessors. People call it "soulslike" but I disaggree with the sentiment. There is no stamina, you don't get healed/potions from save points(you get potion uses from enemies, just like how they dropped health in previous Darksiders games) and using save points don't spawn enemies like soulslike games. Only common points I can say is dropping your experience when you die. However, if you die several more times afterwards, your exp points don't disappear and you can still claim it no  matter how many times you die. You can even have several dropped exps in different points of the map. Game also has stuff like arcane counters (counters caused by dodging at the right time, similar to Bayonetta's witch time), tons of platforming and verticality (where you get powers to open up new paths like a metroidvania) and a literal devil trigger/transformation. As someone who's kind of experienced in soulslikes, this doesn't feel like a soulslike to me, but I like the differences it has compared to a soulslike.

Sadly, you can occasionally feel the lowness of the budget in several places. There are 2 types of cutscenes, and the one using in game engine has extremely stiff models. You might also encounter some bugs (died twice due to my character getting stuck randomly while t-posing). There are also some stuttering, mostly when you're chanhging regions. I've had my game stutter like 10 times during the playthrough (and those stutters last for several seconds).

Overall this was a really pleasant experience for me after seeing some negativity about this entry. If you are a Darksiders fan, this is a game you don't want to miss out. If you are a newcomer looking for an action game, starting with this entry is an acceptable choice. This is a hidden gem and I hope we'll see more of Fury(and the other horsemen) in the future.

- The puzzles were surprisingly good, they aren't that hard but sometimes they made me think a bit. I didn't find myself getting bored of them which can easily happen for me since I'm not that big on puzzles.

- Platforming in the game is fun, once you get all the abilities you have so many ways of platforming which made the platforming pretty versatile.

- Graphics are gorgeous, I really love the art style in the game and playing the game on ultrawide (humble flex) I just couldn't stop admiring the views, that is until I reached Bonelands (its the "swampy miserable" looking place of this game). - Soundtrack is fine, not as great as Darksiders 2 has but I still found myself enjoying it.

- The performance of the game sadly isn't too great; at least, it wasn't for me. It was actually a reason why I stopped playing the game on my first playthrough, I just had a lot of stuttering that I couldn't find a fix for. I think it was caused by my cpu bottleneck, since after upgrading my cpu the game was a lot more playable. There are still some stutters but nothing that would make me stop playing the game.

- I'm not sure if I would really recommend the DLC for Darksiders 3, especially the Crucible dlc, it honestly is just a waste of time. The amount of grinding required to unlock everything is just a bit too much and the rewards aren't really worth the grind. You get some enhancements for the weapons but I only found one of the four worth using and then there are some armors to unlock but they aren't worth it if you already have the abyssal armor which you can get in the other dlc. Keepers of the Void is bit better and does give you better rewards that are actually worth it. It is a very puzzle heavy which at the start is pretty fun but they do end up getting a bit old. The new level also isn't that interesting to look at and the enemies are just reskins from the base game. It has five bosses. Four of those bosses are pretty much the same boss just with newer moves. Overall you get some weapons and abyssal armor which is nice but if you already played the game this dlc is quite pointless, only worth it if you really want that armor or you are doing the dlc while completing the game.

I am surprised by how much I ended up enjoying this game; it might even be my favourite in the series, I will have to replay Darksiders 1 and get to finishing Genesis to find that out for sure but overall it is a great game and I had a lot of fun 100% it. I hope that we will see more Darksiders games in the future, a proper Strife game is something I just strife for.

So where does the game fail? Technical problems. It continues the tradition of unstable PC ports. Darksider 2 had lots of problems (lots of crashes, some script were not started, you could soft-lock the game, the last boss could be bugged so you couldn't beat it because it kept crashing). 
Darksider 3 comes with: crashes (some people have them rarely, others often), some cutscenes you have to watch on youtube as you are forced to skip them (they crash the game, especially the ones at the end), game on lower settings is constantly flashing white screen (it looks like it is constantly inserting between frames completely white screen), game also have a problem with overall performance.


Overall, from gameplay perspective I had a lot of fun, if not for those technical problems I could easily recommend this game to others. But in the state as this game was left ... play only if you have lot's of patience for technical issues.

NOTE:
DLC are not worth it.

The game came out in 2018, in the height of souls games and probably started develpment in 2015 or 2016, which, if you guys remember, was when Bloodborne and Dark Souls III came out, so there's more than an influence from Fromsoftware games in Darksiders III. The combat is methodical, but you regularly find yourself being attacked by all directions. The game tries to mitigate this with a danger pointer around fury, but sometimes you're locked in an attack animation and you won't be able to dodge that incoming attack from the back. Or the front, for that matter. In the DLC Keepers of the Void, the last boss has some pretty fast attacks that will 1hko you if you're playing in the Apocalyptic difficulty and sometimes you'll me stuck in an attack or dodge animation when an attack that can only be avoided through a jump comes crashing om you. And, boy, will you find A LOT of enemies with 1 hit ko attacks. You can change the combat system to the classic hack n' slash tho.

The level design is very reminiscent of the souls games and you will usually find some simple puzzles to solve, unlike in Darksiders II where they were obtuse and happened way too often for its own good. 

The story itself is... kinda the same from Darksiders I (?) but with some different plot points and an interesting intrigue being revealed by the end of the game. The good thing is that every character in all the games evolve and Fury is the one that grows the most during her journey.

134299752.review:
Pre-Game stuff:
No button remapping, AA is always on with TAA (which leaves visible artifacts when moving the camera), and the buttons mapped were very uncomfortable to me (dodging on RB, but attacking on X and Y feels clunky if you've played any action game with dodging). 

In game:(spoilers ahead)
Without getting into details, the most character development is Fury downplaying her own emotions, which I felt both betrayed the character and was weirdly ideological in how it centers detachment and rationality as the only ways to achieve goals.
The only prominent black characters was an imposter and someone who was led on by the villains, which is shit rep, imo. The only sort-of queer character was Lust, who is of ambiguous gender, and only in so far as Lucifer being betrayed in catholic frescos as having both boobs and a penis is, i.e. also bad rep.
The characters overall were uninspired, including the bosses, and the their motivations were vague at best, and utterly incomprehensible at worst. The twist reveals about any of them were also superficial and not built-up at all.
(spoilers end)

The gameplay was mediocre and unrefined, with a lot of conflicting design goals. Implementing quasi Dark-souls-esque combat, with enemies hitting hard and combat focused on learning their patterns, while also having multiple segments where you are flooded with enemies or just standard traversal past enemies being impossible because they outpace your running speed will leave a lot of players feeling stranded. The fact that attacks aren't telegraphed but still wanting players to focus on dodging because face-tanking isn't viable shows a misunderstanding of the inspirations of the series, be it Dark Souls or Legend of Zelda.

Overall, I played this for the story elements revealed, as I finished the first two roughly a decade ago. I will say that it was not worth it, as the story doesn't expand on what the horsemen were doing during the other games, or who the actual villain of the whole story is. It feels like the "typical" pre-sequel story, where it cannot deviate from the story of what comes before and after, while also not carving out an interesting story on its own.

Some ratings in numbers:
Accessibility: 0/10. I don't think I found any options to improve accessibility.
Combat: 5/10. Rough with corners, and not in an interesting way.
Story: 4/10. There was one moment I liked, and it was basically at the end of the game.
Button-mapping: 6/10. Unintuitive, and even Steam Remapping didn't help too much.

133486035.review:
Long Review below:

So, finally to Darksiders 3...

You know, usually when developers move on to make a sequel to their game, they go back to the drawing board, they look at what worked and what didn't, they improve on success, remove what failed and then add new elements to the already great ones. Usually that's how sequels improve on their prequels.

But with Darksiders 3 I feel like the developers just scrapped everything that made Darksiders 1 and 2, a Darksiders game and decided to add elements from scratch without keeping either successes or failures.

Darksiders 1 took inspiration God of War and Devil May Cry with tons of puzzles that were quite annoying but had great execution moves and combat.
Darksiders 2 took inspiration from Prince of Persia while adding RPG elements such as armour, plenty of weapons and a skill tree that defines the way you play. Perfected the puzzles and made them fun, lowered the gruesome factor and the executions that DS1 had but worked on world building and characters.
Darksiders 3 drops the Prince of Persia elements, drops the major puzzles, drops the dungeons and the god of war combat like elements and decides to draw inspiration from Dark Souls and while such a genre is very difficult to draw from, (Darksiders 3 didn't do a great job at that) Fury is probably the most interesting horseman/horsewoman that we've gotten.

Now leaving my confusion aside Darksiders 3 is a decent, quite fun game, where you take control of Fury.
Out of all darksiders games, she's pretty much the only one who has a character arc that I've really enjoyed.
She starts off as a self-righteous, selfish, power hungry character that's indifferent to her brothers but you'll soon come to realise that she just wants to be acknowledged and she's wiser than she initially lets on.
While not all of the jokes land, there's much more character development here and chit chat between Fury and her Watcher which War severely lacked in the 1st game.
Fury doesn't feel floaty/light or going on ice skates when you're playing like War and Death did. 
You can feel how heavy she is and I believe that's how a horseman of the apocalypse should feel like.
I really hope that these aspects aren't going to be dropped in future Darksiders game. Fury's a character done right, probably the best out of all horsemen which is refreshing to see.

The world in 3 is pretty good looking and feels very metrovenia like. You'll unlock new skills and abilities that allows you to travel in places you couldn't access before.
Fury's mission is to hunt down the Seven Deadly Sins and unfortunately that's more interesting than it sounds. The Sins are pretty boring and very defined by what they represent in a cartoon villain like fashion with only 2-3 sins standing out more such as Lust, Pride and Envy that had more dialogue and scenes.
There's no real build up to fighting the sins besides little snips of dialogue here and there, and they're just wandering the world with no clear purpose. They're like lost children wanting to do stuff and the Council sends you to pick them up and kick them back home.

The combat is serviceable and credit goes to the accessibility of the game. You can pick between Classic and Default combat from Story difficulty to Reckoning. This will impact how good the game feels but overall it's challenging. There's also enough enemy variety to keep you on your toes. Fury's abilities feel good to use so you'll find yourself using most of them through the journey.

The boss fights aren't Dark Souls level but out of all Darksiders game they're the ones that are most fleshed out which makes them more challenging. Depending on what difficulty you're playing, observing their patterns and moves, it'll make you play more methodical than before.

There are some downsides and bugs that hold the game back.
1. The impact of combat that Darksiders 1 and 2 had is pretty much gone. Even though you're still fighting demons and angels in many stages, Fury's whip feels like it's hitting metal, not living fleshy things.
2. There are 0 execution moves in this game.
3. The puzzles are there but toned down significantly with only 2-3 that are at least remotely interesting.
4. No more RPG elements. There are some armours in the game but the only difference between them is a few stats and colour patterns. If you want the coolest armour set, the Abyssal armour, you have to play through the DLC to get it and it's the only one that really changes the appearance of Fury and not just the colour.
5. No map - On your first play through you'll lose the sense of direction. I understand that the game wants you to remember the places you visit and make them memorable but this isn't Dark Souls or Bloodborne. 
The areas aren't masterfully crafted. Some of them are wide open spaces (forests, deserts, cities) and besides their colour pallet they're not much different. 
Darksiders 1 and 2 had a map and that would help you figure out where you're going, what you've explored or what you should keep on exploring. Here, you only get a compass that will direct you towards the next boss and that's it. 
For example, some areas have certain points where you can fly. However, you haven't unlocked the ability to fly yet so you're progressing through the main path. Then, you unlock the ability to fly and you'll have to remember where the heck you've seen the flying spots you couldn't use before.
Had it been on a map, it would've been easier to just check rather than wandering around aimlessly. Not a huge issue but an annoyance for sure.

All in all, great game.

If I were to score all Darksiders:
Darksiders 2 : 8.8/10 - Great puzzles, great world, decent RPG system, beautiful graphics, atmospheric.
Darksiders 3 : 7/10 - Interesting character, good boss fights, challenging game with the right difficulty setting
Darksiders 1 : 5.5/10 - Fun combat, amazing executions, classic game

Excited for Darksiders 4.
Considering how many times these games have changed, I hope Strife won't drive a car through the Grand Prix to stop the Charred Council.

As a long time Darksiders fan, Darksiders 3 is an alright-ish game over-all, but a terrible Darksiders game. The franchise would have been better off without it.

It's clear to me that they hoped to capitalize on the Soulsborne hype by copying many of the core mechanics from those titles. As a product of this, Darksiders 3 is a poor man's Dark Souls.

The concept of hunting down the 7 Sins is decent, but otherwise the story is rather uninspired and bland. There is a serious lack of new and original characters.
Original Darksiders 1 characters were: Samael, Abaddon, Lilith, Azrael, Ulthane, Uriel, Vulgrim, and The 5 Chosen.
Darksiders 3 has, what, Abraxis (Who appears once and has lit-er-ally no character development), Lord of Hollows, Usiel (who appears twice) and the 7 Sins? There's also 5 forgettable (and optional) Chosen, but I don't remember doing most of them. Otherwise there are many recurring characters, which is fine. But it shouldn't be a replacement for original characters.

Another thing which isn't a huge deal but kind of rubbed me the wrong way was the lack of over-the-top comical graphic violence that the series is otherwise known for. I remember watching War tear off Tiamat's wings, then doing a backflip mid-air while holding her severed wings, and then finally tearing out her still-beating heart in a fountain of blood while Tiamat screams in agony.

In Darksiders 3, by comparison, the most graphical thing I remember, is Fury catching an axe mid-air and throwing it back, hitting the target. Not a drop of blood to be seen. What a let-down.

4/10, would not recommend.

I've set out to 100% each of the Darksiders games- 1 and 2 were a joy to 100% on ps4, and 100%'ing DS2 on pc was also very enjoyable......but Darksiders 3 is so awful it's actually insane the amount of praise it's gotten. 
I think all of the boot licking and bum kissing this game gets is by people who desperately wanted the series to continue so they ignored how terrible this particular entry is so they could get back to the fun stuff.
The biggest issue is the combat. The first Darksiders game was GOW + Zelda, Darksiders 2 was GOW + Zelda + Diablo, and finally Darksiders 3 is Dark Souls + Bayonetta + Metroid. You might see how there's quite the departure here, but not only that but it's like this game was made by people who'd watched a let's play of Dark Souls and had maybe overheard the general idea of what a metroidvania is. It's so incredibly laughable. 

Your estus flask (Nephilim's respite) is super inconsistent. Sometimes I can't use it while attacking, sometimes I can. Sometimes I can't use it while dodging, sometimes I can. Sometimes I'm mashing the heal button and it works or it doesn't (never had any issues with healing in Darksiders 2). And in a game that claims "Hack-N-Slash" you'd think the healing would operate like 2 where you could heal at any time in or out of comboing.
One of the biggest combat flaws, and this ties in to me saying that this feels like a Dark Souls wannabe that was made by people who had only watched a let's play, is that there's no poise system. Fury is basically a character who has 0 poise and every enemy has 100 poise. If an enemy begins blocking you cannot break their guard with attacks and if you try to use a heavy attack, which people claim will break guard, you will be hit because your heavy attack takes too long, so it's better to just use the one combo that lets you stun lock and constantly throw an enemy in the air and pull them back down, but the intended method is to stop attacking and wait patiently as they attack and then you get your "MUH EPIC SLOW MOTION DODGE ATTACK TIME". It's mind numbingly bad. On the note of the "Muh epic bayo dodge" it's really annoying when you do a perfect dodge and get hit by the end of attack animation anyways. Very epic.

Enemies have way too much health, they don't drop hardly enough souls, items rise in price if you buy them (really cool to punish the player with "Muh hard game" amirite?), AND OH MY LORD the fact that there's no bonfire system to refill your Estus is insane! It's almost like this is a Dark Souls clone made by people who haven't played Dark Souls! Color me surprised! Wanna know how you get to refill your healing? There's literally a button in the options menu to kys and respawn refreshing your Estus. Just awful.
Can't charge your projectile attack while dodging.
Lots of enemies cannot be singled out to face 1v1 like Dark Souls.
Enemies literally can chase you down faster than you can run away making entire sections of the game a slog when it throws 4 enemies with 100 Poise, a bajillion health points, and unbreakable guards who all kill you in 2 hits.
Can get hurt by enemies during tentacle scenes.
Have tiny flying enemies ->Have no ranged attacks like the guns in Darksiders 1 or 2 ->have to keep jump attacking to effing hit them = Genius Design. Technically this is resolved with 2/5ths in to the game you are given a long range weapon.
also, forced slow walking sections cuz "Muh story".

Okay okay, so maybe the combat is terrible and the game has lots of generally bad gameplay choices, but that's just a large portion of the game, but what about the metroid part?
Not terrible, but underwhelming. I think the thing that disappointed me the most was no form swapping mid air to have complex platforming. It would've been really cool if you use the fire ability (High Jump) and then swap to Electricity (Float) and then swap to Force (?) (Purple ball form) and slap on to something, but no. It's all very simple and plain with basic platforming and basic puzzles. I hope you also like grabbing ledges because Fury's jump is not high enough on it's own to let you not have to watch that "grabbing the ledge and climbing up" animation a billion times.

I'd like to also take a second to say the bosses range from really fun and fair to just annoying and bad whether its due to mediocre attacks/awkward attack timing, bad hit-boxes (I'm looking at you gluttony), or general sponginess. 
I think the most fun fight aesthetically and mechanically has to be Greed. I never felt like any of his attacks were unfair or that he was at fault. His boss fight literally had me only blaming myself for anything that happened.
I think the worst boss fight is a tie between Gluttony who has undodgeable attacks due to the tentacle being so huge OR Lust his/her strange/awkward timings and the jab attack that has 0 build up, and the fact that it replicates the worst boss fight from Dark Souls 1.

I'd like to take a second to mention I encountered a myriad of visual bugs and oddities. In the warehouse zone boxes would not load probably and I'd see the Unreal Engine props. Constant pop in. etc etc. You can definitely tell these are the same guys who "Updated" Darksiders 1 and 2 for last gen and pc cuz it's poorly slapped together. 

Boss tiers :

Great Tier
Greed
Wrath 1

Okay Tier
Wrath 2
Pride
Sloth

Bad Tier
Lust
Envy 1 & 2

And the thing that ABSOLUTELY DISAPPOINTED ME THE MOST was when starting a new game+ I thought to myself "Oh man, it'd be really cool if when I do NG+ I start the game with all of my abilities and I get to tackle the sins semi out of order/in an order I'd find more fun" but nope. Not happening. You are forced to play slowly and unlock everything again despite the game actually picking up once you receive all 4 forms.

Darksiders 3 is a solid 4/10 maybe a soft 5/10.

I went for the 100% on the highest difficulty out of curiosity. The game is not absolute garbage, but at best it's only worth 1 playthrough on normal.
Skip both DLCs, both are garbage. The Crucible doesn't feel like it was tested due to the amount of bs that can instantly end your run, and the Void is mostly platforming that overstays it's welcome, followed by "5" bosses that are just reiterations of the last one but with more moves.

The game itself has problems in multiple places. Feels like it was missing a good year in the planning stage, someone to tell them that the combat doesn't work as it is, and better writers to not make the protagonist completely unlikable.

The stage design is closer to the 1st game, but nowhere as interesting. So much of the game feels like underground tunnel/hallways that it's easy to forget where was that one puzzle in the back of your mind. The puzzles are just ok, but they don't try to do anything interesting like 1 and 2 did. It's overall pretty generic.

The combat just feels bad overall.
The damage received is stupidly high and you die in 2-3 hits. This means that in a group fight you get staggered once by the enemy in front, and then the one next to them gets a free attack. Or a projectile hits you from out of the screen and whatever you where attacking gets a free hit. Or an enemy spawns behind you. Or you get cornered and you only options are to die, get lucky, or have enough Havoc to iframe your way out of there. 
You're mashing X most of the time vs trash enemies, or just baiting counter attacks on bosses to play it safe because you can't cancel out of every attack and you can't block either.
Despite the fact that you unlock 4 more melee weapons, all of them feel the same except for the charge and counter attacks, where only 2 of them are particularly useful. In fact, the game doesn't tell you that one of them is the only way to get behind endgame enemies that never lower their guard, otherwise forcing you to wait for them to attack so you can counter attack about 7-10 times per encounter until they finally die.
The biggest offender is that one of your counter attacks (that will most likely happen at random) can force you to jump. You have no defensive options in the air. This means that fighting more than one enemy, or an enemy that has super armor, will most likely end with you getting hit out of the air because there's just nothing you can do. And like I said above, you will be countering a lot in boss fights.

There was no need to force you to switch to a different form every time to solve a puzzle. All of those new mechanics can fit perfectly fine with a better controller design. And speaking of controller design, they somehow manged to fuck up the dark souls item selection by forcing you to scroll through all your items instead of letting you equip them, and forcing you to tap down to "equip" the healing instead of just letting you use it right away... in a game where you die in 2-3 hits.

The Crucible DLC is a 100 stage gauntlet in a boring circle arena.
Why it's bad:
Enemies constantly spawn behind you mid stage and out of camera... in a game where you die in 2-3 hits.
Enemies can spawn in platforms above you that you have to climb... in a game where you have no air defensive options usually forcing you to eat a hit as you climb, unless you wait and wait and wait until they decide to shoot the ground AND THEN you can climb.
Both of these are pretty easy problems to spot had they tested it. They clearly didn't or at least they didn't outside of the easiest difficulty where you can stomp everything with endgame gear for your dirty chievo.

The Keepers of the Void DLC is a long series of puzzles using the mechanics you unlock through the game.
It's not bad, but there's nothing special and overstays it's welcome so not really worth the time.
At the end of each section you fight a boring boss. Each section has the exact same boss but with more moves. Bosses 3 and 4 where the closest thing to fun due to how much more active those fights where compared to the main game BUT the damage was so stupidly high that they demand a lot of pattern learning and counter spam. Then the 5th boss is the most different, but the damage is so high and it has so much HP that it's just not fun to try over and over. Eventually the AI broke and I got a free win which tells me how much they tested this DLC.

128802974.review:
I delayed playing this one because of the initial backlash and negative reviews. Having replayed the first two recently I wanted to see where the story continued and I was very pleasantly surpised by this game.

It's a very good Darksiders game and I never got bored (except maybe for that one boss), much better than what it presents itself to be in the description or the screenshots.

Graphics, level desing, lore, music and sound are all well crafted and in line if not improved from the previous games.

At first the game feels stripped down if you compare it to Darksiders 2. But in reality it's just different and while it lacks depth in character progression and loot I think ends up being a more focused experience this way.

The combat and gameplay loop is inspired frome recent "Souls LIGHT" titles, in fact this game reminds me of Jedi Fallen order in its atmosphere and gameplay.

Here are the main aspects that change from previous titles, none of them detracted me from finishing the game :

- Only 3 main attributes to level up. Meh, but Okay. You can also level up weapons choose different armors and enhancements but it's more about personalising your gameplay experience.
- Only 4 acrane abilities that are tied to only 4 secondary weapons (and I actually liked it this way).
- Loot mainly consists of currency and crafting components. On one hand it gives you the freedom to upgrade the weapons and the attachments you prefer. On the other hand it's sad to never be able to find unique weapons or armor. I think this helps keeping you focused on mastering the 4 secondary weapons but otherwise I can see why this is percieved as a huge step back.
- There is no map. It's OK, in part because when you revisit old locations you will have outleveled the enemies there so exploration is actually fun and not a chore.
- The "souls lite" elements : one health item that replenishes as you die or randomly after certain enemies die. When you die your souls are left where you died and all enemies respawn. I think it fits the depressing post-apolcalyptic atmosphere, and I liked the slower pace in general (like Jedi Fallen order).
- Combat requires more precision, perfect dodges meaning learning enemies patterns. Again, good change of pace and I felt it was fluid and had a lot of fun with it. It is not hower as hard as a true souls title, far from it.

All in all, very fun game. Felt like Darksiders, juste a little different.

There is two things that I like about the darksiders series, the first thing is the whole world, lore, story and all of the characters that were set in those games, for me its one of the most intriguing and interesting settings in any game ever and the fact that in each entry you play as one of the different horsemen of the apocalypse is just an amazing concept and each of them have their own personality, traits and play style which ties to the second thing I like about the series is that they try something new in each entry, they are all action games but each of them tries to mix other subgenres into it, darksiders 1 had a zelda-esque gameplay, darksiders 2 went into more of an open-ended rpg with loot mechanics and better character building, it was also a very big and long game, which bring us to darksiders 3.

Well, while darksiders 1 is the best game in the trilogy for me because of the story and being the great introduction of the series it is, darksiders 3 is my favorite to play, this time they decided to mix ideas akin to a metroidvania-like design mixed with dark souls, altho it does still its own thing, its not really a souls-like but it borrows ideas from that subgenre, the gameplay may have its flaws and feel a little unpolished at times, sometimes you dodge an enemy and it doesnt register, sometimes the camera fucks up and sometimes you glitch or get stuck and it definitely shows that its the game of the series with lowest production values but for me, it brings a very personal story with fury, my favorite of the horsemen who develops into a good character as you play and the gameplay feels more focused and compact than the one in darksiders 2 which dragged more than it had any right to be, darksiders 3 doesnt overstay its welcome, it came knowing exactly what it wanted to be and thats why I ended up enjoying it so much despite some shortcomings.

[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Darksiders III falls within the adventure and action role-playing game developed by .

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2884135197

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

Darksiders III marks a departure from the previous games by borrowing structural and gameplay elements from Metroidvanias and Soulslikes, the game is seen as a mix of elements from previous games and a new direction. Players take control of Fury, the sister of War and Death, two of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, from a third-person perspective. Fury, a mage described as the most unpredictable and enigmatic of the Four Horsemen, relies on whips, swords, flails, daggers and magic in combat. Fury can take on several different elemental forms to enhance her combat abilities, giving her new weapons, attacks, and locomotion abilities.

Combat is described as methodical and straightforward, not focusing on large clusters of enemies and removing the hit counter like in the previous games. Enemies are stronger than in previous installs, but spawn in smaller numbers in encounters to make combat feel more personal. Some enemies return from previous games while other enemies are new. Gated Combat isn't a feature in an attempt to make everything contextualized and connected within the environment like it was in the Dark Souls series.

Darksiders III focuses on its leveling system, where Fury's damage, health, and arcane damage can be upgraded. The threats to the world of the game grow stronger as the player progresses through the story. Similar to War but unlike Death, Fury collects souls from enemies and objects in the environment as a form of currency or as a consumable resource. The player can attach "Enhancements" to Fury's weapons to gain various perks and damage increases.

The game takes place in a continuous environment where exploration plays a big part in collecting more Lurchers and materials to improve Fury herself and her arsenal. As she explores, Fury must solve simple puzzles and overcome platforming obstacles, some using her whip. Such puzzles include using bombs to blast blocked paths or Fury's Forms to interact with the environment.

[h1] Per [/h1]

+ Zelda meets Dark Souls
+ large, connected world
+ nice comic style
+ successful background music
+ Small but fun arsenal of weapons
+ varied skills
+ challenging opponents and optional bosses
+ Achievements and trading cards

[h1] cons [/h1]

- weak textures
- Puzzles are too simple

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Darksiders III offers fresh new approaches and fun gameplay that is well translated into a story full of twists and turns.


[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

Darksiders III fällt ins Adventure und Action-Rollenspiel, welches von entwickelt wurde. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2884135197

[h1] Gameplay / Geschichte [/h1]

Darksiders III ist eine Abkehr von den vorherigen Spielen, indem es Struktur- und Gameplay-Elemente von Metroidvanias und Soulslikes entlehnt, das Spiel wird als eine Mischung aus Elementen früherer Spiele und einer neuen Richtung angesehen. Die Spieler übernehmen die Kontrolle über Fury, die Schwester von War and Death, zwei der vier Reiter der Apokalypse, aus der Third-Person-Perspektive. Fury, ein Magier, der als der unberechenbarste und rätselhafteste der Vier Reiter beschrieben wird, verlässt sich im Kampf auf Peitschen, Schwerter, Dreschflegel, Dolche und Magie. Fury kann mehrere verschiedene elementare Formen annehmen, um ihre Kampffähigkeiten zu verbessern, indem sie ihr neue Waffen, Angriffe und Fortbewegungsfähigkeiten verleiht.

Der Kampf wird als methodischer und geradliniger beschrieben, der sich nicht wie in den vorherigen Spielen auf große Ansammlungen von Feinden konzentriert und den Trefferzähler entfernt. Feinde sind stärker als in früheren Installationen, erscheinen jedoch bei Begegnungen in geringerer Anzahl, damit sich die Kämpfe persönlicher anfühlen. Einige Feinde kehren aus früheren Spielen zurück, während andere Feinde neu sind. Gated Combat ist kein Feature, in dem Versuch, alles innerhalb der Umgebung kontextualisiert und miteinander verbunden zu machen, wie in der Dark Souls-Serie.

Darksiders III konzentriert sich auf sein Levelsystem, in dem Furys Schaden, Gesundheit und arkaner Schaden verbessert werden können. Die Bedrohungen der Welt des Spiels werden stärker, je weiter der Spieler durch die Geschichte voranschreitet. Ähnlich wie Krieg, aber anders als Tod, sammelt Fury Seelen von Feinden und Objekten in der Umgebung, als eine Form von Währung oder als verbrauchbare Ressource. Der Spieler kann „Verstärkungen“ an Furys Waffen anbringen, um verschiedene Vorteile und Schadenserhöhungen zu erhalten.

Das Spiel findet in einer kontinuierlichen Umgebung statt, in der die Erkundung eine große Rolle beim Sammeln von mehr Lurchern und Materialien spielt, um Fury selbst und ihr Arsenal zu verbessern. Beim Erkunden muss Fury einfache Rätsel lösen und Plattformhindernisse überwinden, von denen einige ihre Peitsche verwenden. Solche Rätsel umfassen die Verwendung von Bomben, um blockierte Wege zu sprengen, oder Fury's Forms, um mit der Umgebung zu interagieren.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ Zelda trifft Dark Souls
+ große, zusammenhängende Welt
+ schöner Comic-Stil
+ gelungene Musikuntermalung
+ kleines, aber spaßiges Waffenarsenal
+ abwechslungsreiche Fähigkeiten
+ fordernde Gegner und optionale Bosse
+ Errungenschaften und Sammelkarten

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- schwache Texturen
- Rätsel sind zu einfach gehalten

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Darksiders III bietet frische neue Ansätze und ein spaßiges Gameplay, welches gut umgesetzt wurde in eine Geschichte voller Wendungen.

VERDICT:
Darksiders III has a slight twist compared to the previous games, instead of Hack and Slashing through your enemies with a combat meter tabbing up your combo, they've scrapped that part and gone with a more Dark Souls feel. Which in my option is just what the franchise needed, you can still Hack and Slash but with no combo meter, there's no pressure to keep your attacks moving. This has left a lot of Darksiders fans annoyed but it's a risk Gunfire took. If you haven't played the previous two Darksiders, this won't make much difference to you, but I felt the strain playing this for the first couple of hours. Once you get the hang of the new controls/combat, it feels like a breath of fresh air, has been put into the franchise.

They've improved drastically with how the story is portrayed, it's almost identical to the previous games but explained so much better, perhaps it's the cinematic scenes and the raw emotion you feel of Fury that brings this story to life, or it's how the Seven Deadly Sins try to explain themselves before and after going into battle with them. I'd say it's both of those concepts that made this game a little more advanced than Darksiders 1&2.

There is a slight hiccup that needs to be talked about, the frame rate when going into a different area drops drastically for a couple of seconds before returning back to normal, this would be more of an issue if this happened in combat but luckily it's only when you enter a more scenic area.

Without upsetting you huge Darksider fans, I'd recommend getting this on a slight discount, 15% sounds pretty reasonable, if you're new to the franchise and you're playing this before the others, you'll enjoy Darksiders III immensely.

In their quest, players can use a variety of melee and magical weapons and gain experience points and currency to upgrade Fury's powers and weapons.

Oh boy how to begin with this one, I can't honestly give this game a negative review because it wasn't bad but it wasn't good either it was merely just ok. Darksiders 3 sees a new dev team take on the mantle and the change in style really shows, also the lack of budget. Before we begin I did play this game on classic mode so combat was more like how it was in darksiders 1/2, that being said the game originally had comabt which was more akin to dark souls and the game is heavily inspired by the souls genre in general which means this game is quite the departure from the series (even genesis still feels like a darksiders game despite the camera perspective change.) and because of the change the game is easily the most polarised in the series. 

For this review I'll list pros first as I don't have many. 

Pro 

Combat feels pretty ok, it's weighty and has some decent impact and changing weapons mid combo feels nice, also the selection of weapons is pretty decent as well. 

The abilities that change fury's apperance was pretty decent and a fun way to add to her arsenal, sorta reminded me of Primal.

Cons

Pc performance should not be this bad, at points the game would run at like 15fps and would wildy swing from that to 60fps causing stuttering and slowdown, I have a 3070 so shouldn't really be seeing issues like this especially for a game as basic as this, what a shame this port is so weak when I played remnants perfectly on a rx 580 

Fury is a lame character, I found her rage to be annoying and a bit like a diet war, her journey and change in character felt undeserved

No horse

Music was mostly forgettable 

In conclusion this game was obviously made with passion by a small team of devs working with a shoestring budget but these games need to have an epic feel to them, I just hope if we ever get another game in the series they drastically increase the budget and ditch the wannabe souls vibe

This game is a let-down for five major reasons.

First, it's not as good as the first entry in the series. Darksiders 1 (released almost twenty years before this game) was just a more well-thought out game with tighter controls and a better story. It was released in an era where it was—if not innovative—at least a solid entry of its type. This one feels outdated at release and its story feels pretty derivative and contrived. The controls feel floaty and disconnected. 

Second, it's trying to be something that it's not. The first Darksiders was a lot like Zelda Ocarina of Time in gameplay. The second Darksiders was a lot more like Zelda Twilight Princess with a randomized loot system layered on top. This third Darksiders, like a lot of games these days, is trying to be Dark Souls and it just feels off. It doesn't even pull off Dark Souls very well.

Third, there's a lot of regressive design. This is a game that, when you die, doesn't respawn you near where you died, but instead makes you run all the way back through a mostly deserted level to get back to you were. If you died on a boss, I hope you enjoy a 5-minute run back to the boss arena.

Fourth, some of the Metroidvania progress blockers feel heavily contrived. The main character is supposed to be a supreme badass heavenly warrior, and yet some of the early "you can't go here yet" walls are literal cobwebs wafting in the breeze. You can see right through them and they look like real-world cobwebs. There's no explanation as to why you can't just tear through them like you do with much of the other scenery.

Fifth and finally, boob-armor and battle stilettos are the *only* armor options. I'm fine with cheesecake in games, but not having a "realistic" armor option for people who *don't* enjoy cheesecake is a massive oversight. And all of those armors appear to largely just be recolors on the base armor that you start the game with. Why bother adding in different armor sets at all if they all basially look the same? 

Overall, I recommend taking a pass on this entry.
