There is something to be said about my masochistic tendencies because, for whatever reason, I was willing to play Darksiders III at all after experiencing the endless torture that was Darksiders II and its ability to drive anybody to murder. What it really says is anyone's guess, I suppose.

Darksiders III is of course the sequel to the previous two titles of the same name. Mind you, what the title has to do with the actual plot of the games is a matter of question, as I can't find a cohesive connection between them to save my life. So, to recap the basic plots of them, here ya go: An overly dressed Wish version of Kratos comes to Earth early for the Apocalypse only to find out that Armageddon wasn't scheduled for some time. He gets into a hot bed of trouble, then promptly breaks the Seventh Seal. Then a being that happens to be named Death (not to be confused with the actual personification of death, because that would be confusing) attempts to clear knock-off Kratos' name only to add further to the body count and cause more trouble all around. Are you with me so far? Great. So, it turns out that there are two other Horsemen, just not who you would expect. It turns out that in this mess of a universe, Famine, Pestilence, and Conquest are retired or on vacation or something. Instead we get Mildly Frustrated And Extremely Impatient (Fury) and her brother, Irritated Contrarian (Strife). Darksiders III deals with Mildly Frustrated and her journey to find and capture/kill the Seven Deadly Sins: Jealous Spinster, Angry Beefcake, Antisemitic Jewish Caricature, Obese American, Red-Flag Mommy-Domme, Tentacle-Porn Monstrosity, and Arrogant Angel. Without getting into the nitty-gritty, that explains as much as you need to know about the story.

Now, much like it's predecessors, Darksiders III suffers from the same identity crisis that they did. The first game played like God of War with a boatload Zelda puzzle mechanics and a stolen Portal Gun; the second was an action looter with some Zelda puzzle mechanics, a Doom gunfight sequence, and a stolen Portal Gun; and this game feels like a rip-off of Dark Souls with prettier set-dressing, significantly less Zelda puzzle mechanics, and no return of the aforementioned Portal Gun. While this isn't necessarily a bad thing, having a narrative connection but no solid game structure in common puts this series in an awkward place that doesn't really allow for accessibility to most players willing to experience the titles without experience whiplash. All in all, Darksiders III in comparison to its counterparts feels rather stripped down, which actually makes the entire experience all the more tolerable and surprisingly fun.

That isn't to say that this game is without fault, because it is a bit of a mess in places. The currency system is effectively broken and incredibly easy to manipulate and outside of increasing character level, it's useless. Drops of helpful items are plentiful and easily obtained, provided you're willing to slaughter whatever monstrosity happens to be around. The combat returns to being a torrid affair between two buttons, which makes the overall experience stale after a while. Fortunately the game is rather short, able to be completed in about 14 hours, and that is without skipping content. Mind you, I'm not about to purchase the DLC. If there's one thing I've learned from this series, it's that the added material is often not worth the trouble. Completely unrelated to the above complaints, I feel it is absolutely absurd that the characters of the first two games can easily destroy cars while Mildly Frustrated can't manage to do so unless she's in a fancy glowing rampage. Whether that is misogyny on the developer's part is a matter of supreme mystery.

After weighing how I wanted to present my feelings of this title, I can't in good conscience say I would actually recommend it. While, yes I did enjoy it, and it does a fair job of functioning as a standalone game if you squint really hard, it still carries the baggage of its predecessors which are cumbersome to say the least. I suppose it would fair well as a bargain purchase, just don't try to backtrack to the first two unless you're as much a glutton for misery as I am.

I ended up enjoying this game way more than I initially thought I would. I first played it a year or two ago, but only got a few hours in before it sort of just faded into my unfinished games pile, but I'm glad I decided to come back to finish it.

I won't risk spoiling story stuff for anyone considering playing it, but I will say I was pleasantly surprised by the story. I wasn't expecting much from the outset, considering Darksiders stories and lore only really exist on one of two levels: completely absent or so mind bogglingly convoluted it physically hurts your brain to try to comprehend. This game though, it keeps the story as a subtle presence for a while before ramping it up more in the later stages, and while some of the connecting elements did lose me toward the end, I actually came away really enjoying Fury's character arc, and how she reacts to the things that happen to her. For once a Darksiders protagonist has character growth, something I'm fairly certain War and Death were missing in previous entries. While the story isn't earth-shattering (since this is a prequel game, kind of easy to see some twists coming when you already know them from previous titles), it's a big plus for continued interest in the story imo, Fury definitely takes her place as my favourite of the horsemen seen so far.

I'll also give them props for doing so many of the side characters so well, especially the seven deadly sins you're hunting. Each is very well acted, and in the short time you have with each before their boss fights, they get personified excellently. Lust was my favourite; quite refreshing to have a game depicting the embodiment of lust as something other than a scantily clad, permanently horny woman, props for that! The other supporting characters are great too, the Lord of the Hollows, Ulthane, the Watcher, they all play their parts wonderfully, and the voice acting is superb, most especially Fury's.

I know some people were turned off by the switch in combat / gameplay from DS1/2 to a more meaty, slower, dodge-focused style, and I'll say I can definitely sympathise with those opinions. On the whole, the gameplay is probably the weakest part of Darksiders 3. It's fine, but it's plagued with issues, principle amongst them is the overtly high difficulty of the game that turned a lot of people off, but just to sound off on the others real quick: flying enemies are a chore, groups will easily flank/stunlock you from off-screen, dodging doesn't work against groups even if you time one attack right, the others will still hit you mid-dodge, inputs frequently get dropped mid-combat due to staggers + lack of animation cancelling, dodging is the only method of avoiding damage which funnels the entire design of the combat through a single mechanic and stunts any potential the game could have had for interesting evolutions to the gameplay over-time.

I got used to the combat after a while, but I'm not blind to it's inherent flaws, the game IS too hard for most people on the normal setting, it turns too many people away and has led to most of the negative reviews that I can see. I know Dark Souls d**k riders like to act as if beating a hard game is some right of passage to judging others who can't manage it, but I'll remind the rest of you; it's okay to acknowledge that a game is too hard. It's okay to criticise a games difficulty. It's completely valid to not like game because it's too tricky to get into, and no amount of morons on the internet trying to denigrate you with 'git gud' will excuse the fact that some games are only difficult because of poor design. This is definitely one of those. I beat it because I stuck with it long enough to get into the groove of the combat, a lot of people don't have the time or simply don't want to bother with that. Toning the difficulty down for the normal or easy settings would only have helped this game imo.

Speaking of combat, let me briefly touch on the DLCs for this game. There's two; The Crucible and Keepers of the Void. Hard pass on the crucible; it's complete tosh. It's just 100 waves of combat against different enemies; it's tedious, boring, unfair at times because of stunlock instakills, and not worth anything it rewards you with. I only beat it because I'm an achievement wh*re. Keepers of the Void is decent though, and the reward armour you get is top tier imo. It's something you need to play alongside the main game though; don't pick it up for playing after because it will not offer much. But the bosses are neat, the new areas are fun enough if a little samey, it's a decent addition to the game for what it is.

I'll confess I wasn't super into the semi-open world thing at the start, but it's honestly a nice edition. Multiple times I took a break from the story path to travel back through old areas, using new hollows to open up paths and find loot. It felt good, even if in the end it wasn't all that grandiose. Most all the loot in this game falls into one of three categories; shards, lurchers, or upgrade materials. Shards are consumables to use at-will during gameplay, lurchers are basically the exp currency that you can use to level up or buy other items, and upgrade materials are used for the bulk of the games progression. The latter is the best to find, since upgrading your weapons and enhancements can confer some pretty nice and noticeable boosts to Fury's power. All in all, the upgrade and levelling up systems are quite shallow; there's not a great deal of depth to them besides just make the numbers bigger, but they allow just enough dopamine release to make finding these things feel fun and rewarding, at least for me.

One last thing of note, the game has a very nice new game plus system called Armageddon mode. Essentially it's just NG+ but the game will get progressively harder each time you clear the story, with nine total levels of difficulty. But what's neat about it is that NG+ actually introduces new items and enemy spawns, and opens up new progression like being able to upgrade armours. It's a really neat set of additions imo, and I'm already committed to doing another run of the game thanks to it.

I think this is definitely my favourite of the core Darksiders series so far. I've not tried Genesis yet, but this one certainly left a better impression on me than DS1/2 did. If you're into third person hacky/slashy combat affairs, it might be right up your alley, so long as you can adjust to the difficulty and get used to having to dodge enemy attacks 30 times a minute. Looking forward to what they might do with Strife in Darksiders 4!

Short and sweet: The game is a downgrade to the two previous games in basically every way except graphically. You only want to play this if you are desperate for more Darksiders, otherwise just play the two previous installments.

More specifically:

The protagonist, Fury, is unlikeable and mostly boring. The game makes some character development noises, but if it comes at all, it comes too late. To be fair to her, War had similar issues. In that they are both very one-note and not interesting to listen to. But they had fixed that with the sequel. Death was charming and could swap neatly between humour and being more serious. Fury, meanwhile, goes right back to basically being no character at all.

Here is how practically every exchange in the game goes:

Enemy: "Dismissive insults."
Fury: "Dismissive death threats."
Enemy: "More Dismissive insults."
Fury: *Does a big angry*

And thats about it. Copy paste this about a dozen times and you already know the story. There are the occasional good lines here and there, but it is nowhere near the quality of DS 2.

The Gameplay has the same boils that a lot of the rest of the series does. Namely, it's one good hair is to be found in combat, yet it is too averse to actually give you enough of it. Combat arenas are often interspaced with meaningless, boring platforming. The chain grab in particular is a dramatic little madam, and has a solid 50% chance not to work half the time. The puzzles have the usual issue in a game with ability unlocks, in that you will frequently be staring at something for a while, unsure whether you are just missing an ability or are actually capable of solving it in your current state.

In cases where you do have the needed ability, most of the puzzles are still unengaging. usually its just rubbing yourself against surfaces until you find the thing you can interact with, be that a wall, switch or some of the chain hangers. Optional side areas will to rarely lead to any interesting combat, and too frequently to a dead end with a bit of loot or a human to save.

The actual combat is, as stated, the best part. But it too has issues. Playing the game in the "default" mode, which I strongly recommend against, no longer lets you cancel out of attacks with dodges. This in turn generally makes a careful approach more successful. Sadly, this makes many fights really boring. The combat works best when you are in the enemies face, weaving moves and dodges. But the telegraphs are so quick, and the punishment for dying often harsh, that its just not worth it.

The game also jumped on the "Let's steal some DNA from Dark Souls" bandwagon. You now have corpse runs, and lose a needless amount of time when dying to get back where you were. The game also doesn't mark teleport locations in terms of how close they are to objectives. So if you lose track of the 6 teleport locations in an area, that all look the same, you'll be backtracking a lot.

There are other niggles. The attribute point rewarding items also increase your level, and thus the amount you pay for leveling up. Making you averse to using them. The upgrade character has a completely pointless hammering animation, that forces you to wait 5 seconds before you get to talk to him. In cases where you are going between him and the shop demon, you constantly have to wait for either of them to finish their dumb animation before you are allowed to interact.

All in all, the game is actually just kinda bad in most ways. And it takes a bit too much effort to get what few good parts there are.

I got this game since the first two games were so much fun. Though it is a bit difficult to recommend this game. I know when it first came out a lot of Darksider fans weren't as happy with it.

But I wanted to support THQ Nordic so we could continue getting more Darksider games especially a fourth one and/or maybe one where you have all 4 of the horsemen fighting together? idk.

I stuck it out and although it was clear this game was a lot harder then the previous 2 games it still was a concurrent/tandem story to the first 2 games. But there were quite a few changes which made it less appealing. Like getting rid of some of the loot, making some parts of it more simplified.

Also the fact it made you feel weaker with the fact you had to dodge SO much. Also it seemed like they went out of their way to make the game harder. Like making it so you do less damage. But can get more damage even from usually weak enemies. 

This also didn't help they made the main character a girl thing in a way. 

I was fine/had no problem with that, and actually kinda happy they made one of the four horsemen (well I guess should say horse.. people? lol) a girl/woman/thing? But now the game that suppose to have a strong female character seems weak? :S She definitely looks bad a$$ but her attacks barely do anything. :( Kinda not fair when the previous 2 games the boy/man/things could easily tear through demons etc. But who knows.

I did end up playing through and beating the game though I know at least a few times playing through a level a number of times pissed off cause I kept getting cheated out of a win. 

I think even to this day if you play through the games starting with 1, then 2, and then start this one (3) you will find yourself struggling for a little while to get used to this big change to the gameplay. Though I know after the first time later on it was a bit easier to get back into it. This game just wasn't as much fun as the first two that I can remember.

And while waiting for a darksiders 4 (and still waiting for even word of it, as of writing this review) I know they did come out with another darksiders game after this one but it was also a departure from the FPS/RPG games. It is a darksiders top down fighting game which is more like the very old school SNES type games just with better graphics. As soon as I saw that game it really didn't interest me all that much. 
It reminds me of the Gauntlet Legends game that released on steam a number of years ago that I was all excited about to re-live my N64 gauntlet Legends days only to be let down with how bland/simple the game was compared to that old N64 game.

116534832.review:
This is going to be one of 'those' reviews that isn't really positive outside of the flat premise that the games' mechanics are all very well integrated and remain tolerable until the last seconds of the game. In essence, the game personifies the 'bare minimum' positive review I can give.

With that said, you can really tell the devs struggled with this one -which is super bizarre considering we're on the 3rd game in the series (excluding Genesis) and the developers still haven't really decided on any solid frame of the series outside that it needs to be Zelda-dungeon crawler with exploration elements. The combat system has been historically 'hack &  slash', but this one released with the slower 'Souls' combat formula. This seems super out of place in some parts, where no enemies have next to no windup on attacks (a staple in the souls like); but still deal tremendous damage. Contrastly, bosses themselves have massive 'h&s' sized health bars, which you'll need to whittle down while dodging - which feels much more akin to DevilMayCry than the Souls games. You can tell the devs were flip-flopping late in development because they released the classic form of the combat system out in relatively short order. 

Combat aside, Voice acting is middle of the road. Really nothing special to write home about. Everyone does a fine job. Music is subpart-average. The plot is profoundly underwhelming for an entry in the DS series, which usually has some really good plot points and characters. Fury is easily the most dull out of all 4 horseman (and we really haven't seen much of Strife as of now outside of Genesis). 

Conclusion: A decent romp.
 If you enjoy DS series; you'd might as well try this one. It doesn't add anything to the pre-existing canon, so anyone who wants wants this installment to move along the plot a little; you guys might be disappointed.

114329003.review:
Darksiders 3 (D3) is a platforming hack-n-slash game, in which you play as one of the Horsemen of the Apocalypse (or "The Four", as they are called in-game). It takes place [spoiler] after the prologue of D1 but before the start of D2 [/spoiler] and follows the story and development of Fury (I guess she is a stand-in for "Plague", who was the actual third biblical horseman, but for a combat setting this just does work better), who is tasked with catching and apprehending the seven deadly sins.
I say "development of Fury", because this is probably the first instalment in the series, where a character is significantly different from how they were at the start [spoiler] (War HAS uncovered some things, but he is pretty much the same persona he was at the start - big, burly, yet smart guy with anger issues and a propensity for excessive violence and Death has faced his demons throughout D2, but pretty much has the same resolve and same loyalties as he did when he started off) [/spoiler], which is honestly a breath of fresh air. Partly because character development is a strong selling point for me, and partly because at the start Fury is .... not exactly a mature person... :-) So if you like character development and/or didn't like a personality trait of the protagonist you saw somewhere - she will change. ;-)
One of the two main things you do in any hack-n-slash game is combat and I am pleased to say D3 combat is spot-on! It is dynamic, fluid, based around attacks, counter-attacks and dodges (there is no parrying or stamina, Fury is no wimp after all... :-D) and learning enemy movesets. The latter is quite important, as dodging involves either a "dodge" or a "perfect dodge". The former merely avoids damage, the latter lets you perform a counter-attack, either with Furys whip (her main weapon), or one of her Hollows. You start off blank, with only your base abilities (which contain the Chaos Form, more on that later), but as the story progresses you gain the ability to imbue Fury with Fire, Lightning, Void (basically the power of a supermassive black hole) or Stasis (basically Frost). Each comes with their own perks and lets Fury perform different feats. 
One thing that seemed strange to me in D2 was, that Death picked up equipment and you geared him up. In the lore The Four are presented as having been outfitted by the policing force of the Universe (called "The Charred Council") and given incredible powers and equipment and Death just strides off and picks up the first common item a skeleton drops, because it is better than what he has... In D3 this is no longer the case - enemies do drop things, but they are either consumables which can temporarily improve her stats, components which she can use to upgrade her gear, or soul shards (called "Lurchers" for some reason) which give her varying amounts of souls (a currency she can buy level-ups and other things with). There is no inventory or weight limit and, for the most part, drops for materials and gear are hard-set, while consumables, soul clusters and lower tier materials have a chance to drop from pretty much any enemy, meaning that there is no grinding for materials and when you want to upgrade your weapon beyond a certain point and do not have the materials for it, you will need to boot up New Game+ (NG+ is a game mode in which you start off with most of the items you had at the end of your previous playthrough, but otherwise "restart" the game with enemies more buffed than they were before. you can however change the difficulty level each time.) Whenever Fury dies, all enemies and destructible environmental objects respawn, meaning that if you want to farm souls to level Fury up, you can (but do not have to, you will get enough to have a good time of it). 
The gear is very dynamic, each hollow has its own weapon, with two varieties to choose from and each variety LOOKS different, but actually has the exact same moveset and combos, which is not necessarily bad, but it is kind of strange that Fury uses hand claws to smash the ground as if she were using flails... Other than that - each item has one slot, in which you can put one of the several Enhancements. These are basically "gems" and each one has a different effect. These effects are separated into active (only activates when you use the weapon it is slotted into) and passive (active regardless of whether you are using said weapon or not, it just needs to be slotted in a weapon listed in your inventory, even if that weapon is not activated by having unlocked the hollow it is linked to). So once you have unlocked all weapons, you can have up to 10 passive enhancements active (2 weapons per hollow, the whip and a throwing weapon you get later on). You can also get a number of armors, which either provide very specific bonuses (damage improvement of a certain hollow form, getting more souls when breaking open soul lurchers or mitigating damage. Varying quality levels of armors provide varying amounts/levels of bonuses, with the epic one being the most protective and the most buffing (you get it when finishing the "Keepers Of The Void" DLC, which also has pretty epic fights btw). Other than that gear is pretty unobtrusive and after a bit of customisation lets you focus on the games main selling points - combat, puzzles, story and exploration.
Unlike D2, this game takes place on Earth and sees Fury exploring the "immediate" ramifications of the Apocalypse. I put that in quotes because there are trees EVERYWHERE, so obviously at least 20 years must have passed, but I digress. I feel like the map is smaller this time then it was in D2, however it is less empty than it was in that game, with secrets and side paths all over the place - you can pretty much get anywhere from anywhere, with side-paths opening up as you get more hollows. Puzzles also very much rely on them, as some places will remain unreachable if you do not have the right hollow unlocked and equipped. Also - in comparison to D2, this time you have to walk everywhere, due to certain events which take place early on in the game, but I will not spoil it here. The exploration is, all-in-all, very satisfying, rewarding and easy to get used to.
Story-wise the game also ties up a few plot-holes [spoiler] (such as why a demon of greed like Vulgrim even helps War in D1 without asking for a fee, why a seeming loner like Ulthane doesn't seem to mind him either, why Strifes guns are no longer in his possession, .....) [/spoiler]. Talking about the games story without spoiling it is pretty much impossible, so I will just say that in true Darksiders fashion, there are a number of surprises and plot-twists, which I honestly did not see coming and are VERY much alluded to from the start of the game, [spoiler] such as that the Talisman of Sin only lights up when the first boss steps up before you, not when they are watching you from afar [/spoiler]. 
My final verdict is, that is you are looking for an action-RPG game with LOTS of combat, a very good story, high amounts of character development and a rather rich story, which will leave a fair bit to your interpretation, Darksiders 3 is a game I genuinely believe you have a high chance of enjoying. Do buy it along with its DLCs as they do give some interesting bonuses.

113560934.review:
[h1]“Just because I'm employing an Igor and working in a cellar doesn't mean I'm some sort of madman, ha ha ha!”
~[i]Sir Terry Pratchett[/i][/h1]

So, [b]Vigil Games[/b]. Founded in 2005 by some young blood (I'm talking about VG development experience, since the most experienced person there was probably [b]Marvin A. Donald[/b], who worked on 1999 RPG game called [b]Revenant[/b]), it quickly became a part of [b]THQ[/b] family. Which... turned out to be a terrible decision. Just because it led to their death after only two games developed. And it's [i]very[/i] unfair, because, let's just admit it – [b]Darksiders[/b] series was pretty good. Despite the fact that there was nothing original in it and the entire thing was just a bunch of stolen ideas mixed together? It was still good. Very good. Having a [b]Zelda[/b] game with [b]God of War[/b] melee combat, [b]Devil May Cry[/b]-like guns and [b]BLIZZARD[/b]-like visuals? It worked. [b]Darksiders[/b] games were very satisfying and it was easy to forgive them for copy / pasted approach.

Like I said, it felt very unfair when the guys died together with [b]THQ[/b], who slowly sank due to a long series of failures, which included [b]Red Faction: Armageddon[/b] and [b]uDraw[/b] gimmick nobody ever asked for. [b]Darksiders[/b] franchise, though? It survived. Unfortunately, it didn't go to [b]PlatinumGames[/b], that was interested in it (just imagine [b]Darksiders[/b] game from people behind [b]MadWorld[/b], [b]Bayonetta[/b] and [b]Nier: Automata[/b]). Instead, it was purchased by [b]Nordic Games[/b], together with two other [b]THQ[/b] franchises – [b]Red Faction[/b] and [b]MX vs. ATV[/b]. Naturally, they didn't pay for nothing, so... yeah. Here comes [b]Darksiders III[/b]. From a new developer - [b]Gunfire Games[/b]. There's a trick, though.

See, after [b]THQ[/b] died, [b]Vigil Games[/b]' CEO [b]David Adams[/b] was approached by [b]Cevat Yerli[/b], CEO of [b]CRYTEK[/b], creators of [b]Crysis[/b] franchise. [b]Mr. Yerli[/b] loved what [b]Mr. Adams[/b] and his crew did in [b]Darksiders[/b] and wanted to work with them. That's how [b]CRYTEK USA[/b] was born. Pretty soon, the guys announced their first game - [b]Hunt: Horrors of the Gilded Age[/b]. Which was supposed to be co-op oriented spiritual successor of [b]Darksiders[/b]. Even though [b]Crytek[/b] did bid on [b]Darksiders[/b] during the [b]THQ[/b] bankruptcy auction, they just didn't have enough money to win. So, spiritual successor was the only way for ex-[b]Vigil[/b] team to continue doing their thing.

Talking about money, by the way. Unfortunately for us all, [b]CRYTEK[/b] didn't do well financially. And pretty soon it turned out that they can't even pay their new employees on time. As the result, [b]CRYTEK USA[/b] was shut down long before [b]Hunt: Horrors of the Gilded Age[/b] became a thing. The project was soon re-launched by [b]CRYTEK[/b] and became [b]Hunt: Showdown[/b], while [b]David Adams[/b] founded yet another company - [b]Gunfire Games[/b]. And that's, ladies and gentlemen, who worked on [b]Darksiders III[/b]. In other words, in a way, the old [b]Darksiders[/b] team is back to work on their old series again. Sure, [b]Mr. Adams[/b]'s team underwent a lot of changes and wasn't really the same at that point, but still, quite a lot of people who worked on the originals (like [b]Nicolas Fikac[/b], [b]Kenneth Bassham[/b] and [b]Colin Bonstead[/b]) were still there. So... it's a happy ending, right? [b]Vigil[/b]'s back and they brought [b]Darksiders[/b] back to us?

Well, the funniest (saddest?) thing is – no. No, they didn't. Because when you'll see [b]Darksiders III[/b] for the first time, you'll be like “Say wha...”. Because despite everything I've said above, [b]Darksiders III[/b] feels like something made by people who had absolutely no idea about what the original [b]Darksiders[/b] series was all about. That's exactly why I thought that such a long history lesson is important. [b]Darksiders III[/b] feels exactly like one of those games, in which some new publisher purchases popular franchise and then hires some new guys to make a new game. Which feels nothing like the originals. Just because those new guys don't know a thing about the old titles, while publisher has their own vision. Remember how it was when [b]Fallout[/b] series became a property of [b]ZeniMax Media[/b]? That's pretty much what we're talking about here.

That's right. [b]Darksiders III[/b] is an entirely different game. With the entirely different kind of gameplay. And the only thing that connects it to the originals is the story. Which... was never the strongest point of [b]Darksiders[/b] games. I mean, seriously. [b]Darksiders[/b] games just threw some basic mythology references at us and called it a day. And as the result, I totally didn't care about the fact that the old characters (like good ol' [b]War[/b], for example) appeared here. I didn't care about all that blah-blah-blah stuff before and I didn't care about it here. Even though the writing does feel weird this time, since [b]Gunfire[/b] added some cheap humor for whatever reason (you know how there's that certain guy in your class who desperately tries to be funny without much luck? And it looks pathetic? That's what we talking about here), all I cared about is gameplay.

All I wanted is more of that satisfying [b]Zelda[/b]-like experience. Especially since even [b]Nintendo[/b] can't provide us with the old-school [b]Zelda[/b] experience anymore (you may like [b]Breath of the Wild[/b], you may dislike it, but let's just admit it – it's totally different from what we used to have before it). Guess what [b]Gunfire[/b] gave us instead? Well, they gave us [b]Dark Souls[/b]. That's right, people. What we have here is yet another [b]Souls[/b]-like game. Even though every second major game nowadays is [b]Souls[/b]-like, some smartass decided that we need yet another one. But OK. Broken expectations aside, maybe this game is actually good? Maybe, despite the fact that it's “yet another one of those” game, it does some really nice job? Providing us with some especially juicy, polished and satisfying experience? Maybe it's so good that it's actually worth to care? Well, the answer here is very short – no.

What we've got here is yet another “poor man's [b]Dark Souls[/b]”. I can't say it's completely unplayable, of course. Quite the opposite – if you're a die-hard fan of such games and is currently out of new titles to play, [b]Darksiders III[/b] will totally do. The problem is – there's nothing unique about it. Which, technically, was true about two previous games too, but while two previous [b]Darksiders[/b] games were surprisingly smooth and there was clearly not enough [b]Zelda[/b] clones on market, [b]Darksiders III[/b] feels pretty cheap and clunky, while, like I said, there are way, [i]way[/i] too many of such games around.

It's just that – core mechanics in [b]Darksiders III[/b] feel a bit cheap and clunky (the game feels almost like something from the seventh generation of video game consoles), level design is either too dumb and straightforward or forces some really cheap and annoying puzzles on you (which aren't hard at all, just... you know, annoying as heck and can even cause some cheap deaths), the weapons / tools are not satisfying at all, the bosses are pretty boring and uninspired, [b]DLC[/b] doesn't add anything interesting (seriously, one of those is just a ridiculously cheap arena), etc, etc, etc. In other words, [b]Darksiders III[/b] is totally playable and even has its moments now and then (I actually liked the fact that there are more puzzles than we usually have in [b]Souls[/b]-like games), there's just... no real reason to waste your time on it. There are way, [i]way[/i] better [b]Souls[/b]-like games on market, while [b]Darksiders III[/b] fails to provide you with a single strong reason to choose it over many others. Dixi.

This game is a combat style orientation with progressive level up, loot (in terms of collectables) and exploration. Menus are simple in design with a couple of minor annoyances (sometimes you have to exit one menu upgrade and then re-enter to get items to populate). Music was slightly on the short side with not much selection. Sounds and effects were done right with key moments being part of the game (ie: If you hear something either through an enemy or collectable, then consider yourself notified). Game does require some significant hardware upgrade (which is what I did - I'm now using an i7 12th Gen with RTX 3080) but ran very smooth. Loading, transition points were quick and in-game saves were plentiful. Another point to note was the camera: Allot of cheap, free shots from enemies because the camera didn't swing around fast enough, so take your time with playing...try to draw out one enemy at a time from a cluster either through noise or using your throwing weapon. Story was interesting to follow and your compass helped with navigation in case you got lost.

The combat is challenging in the first 20-30 levels, but once you figure the counter attack, you're going to use this ALL the time. You deliver both base damage and arcane damage (stacked) if the counter attack is done correctly. I was able to harness my chain and fire weapons to +11 for each before upgrading the rest. You are also going to find that allot of enemies are more predictable when you eliminate their range attack, so stay as close as you can, to help with the counter attack. Wrath and Havoc attacks are treated independently. Use Wrath for minor boss battles and Havoc for major. Using each at the appropriate time will go a long way. There is going to be moment in the game, when you realise that the saving grace to your character are going to be 2 things: running for avoidance and dodging for extra counter-damage.

The best part of the game was the exploration and collectables. Multiple types of puzzles with different solutions. You most certainly will use all 4 types of character forms. I spent more time trying to find all the hidden items than anything else. The game offers different scenarios and environments to explore. Don't forget to look for small tunnels or openings in the ceiling (that red glow you see in the roof probable leads somewhere important).

I'm looking forward to seeing whats next in the Darksiders franchise - maybe with Strife?

109212589.review:
Darksiders 3 is fast food 3D exploration / Metroidvania. Its not particularly deep, it’s not particularly complex and, while the skill celling is higher than the prior titles, its mostly gratuitous silliness that amuses for a weekend or two and that’s it. While that may sound damning, its not. It does not hold a candle to other classics in this style it is still a very enjoyable romp for those who are looking for something that reflects the old Soul Reaver games.

The whole Darksiders franchise is a great example of “imitation is the sincerest form of flattery”. The first game was 3D Zelda with God of War. The sequel added a looting system akin to Diablo to the mix. Darksiders 3 takes the prior basis (Zelda via God of War) and adds some light soulslike mechanics to them. As is, Darksiders continues to bring nothing new to the table and simply apes that which has existed before it. However while it does not bring anything new, what it does it does quite well. It also keeps the series somewhat fresh as, rather than just repeat the prior titles with new faces and locations, it always changes up the formula slightly, so each horseman is distinct from the last.

This distinction seems to have caused a lot of fallout on the game’s release and there seemed to be a strong negative backlash toward it. Yes, DS3 ditches the loot system from the second title and goes back to the more simplified and limited armoury seen in the first title (which I did not fully enjoy because of how broken it could be), but what it trades in for excess it is a far more skill based system. Now granted, there are soulslike elements, but they are frequently overstated. The main considerations are that Fury, the protagonist, is more of a glass cannon. The prior main characters, War and Death, were far more tanky and could take more damage, so while there were more nuanced layers to the combat you could effectively button mash your way through them. Here Fury needs to consider trying to mitigate the incoming damage as much as possible to survive. While War could block / parry and riposte enemies, and Death could whizz about in a flurry of blades, Fury needs to do timed dodges which grants her huge counter-attacks. This may seem annoying initially, but once it is mastered it is quite a satisfying gameplay loop to get into, but if you hope to just button mash your way to victory like in DS2, be prepared for disappointment.

Besides the more fragile protagonist the other soulslike elements are set reset points (vulgrim portals are the equivalent of bonfires) where on death the levels repopulate as well as grabbing ones souls from where you fell previously. Bar that things like stamina and VERY careful use of attacks are, thankfully, nowhere to be seen. Yes combat is far more risky here, but it still has the satisfying bashing of buttons to achieve their goals. Similarly, Fury is far more agile and spritely than any of the traditional Souls titles, with jumping, platform puzzles and general traversal. While a souls game tends to take place on flat surfaces that wind out from a point, Darksiders sprawls vertically in ways that requires you to take in your full surroundings to get the most of it. In this regard not only is Darksiders 3 less of a souls like, but the whole series is more akin to a metroidvania in 3D, or more fittingly, a Soul Reaver alike. Indeed if you are a fan of the old Legacy of Kain titles then Darksiders is, in my opinion, the best substitute there is.

So for a Legacy of Kain… like (?) how does Darksiders 3 fare? Its fine. Is it as good as the original or the sequel? No, not quite. Its good, and its certainly better than a lot of the backlash it got seems to indicate, but its not a classic. It’s a perfectly suitable middle game in a series that not only experiments with the systems it has as well as being a surprising title that many thought would never happen due to the death of THQ. If you want a good time killer for a wet weekend that is fun but not world changing, Darksiders 3 is very much that kind of game.

FINAL NOTE: If you do buy this, do so [i]only[/i] during a sale. The price is absurd considering the mid-grade quality it has, and considering it is a few years old now the fact it is the same price as a new game is absurd. That said it does plumet in price during sales periods, and for less then a tenner it is well worth it.

I went to leave a review the other day, and stopped so I could finish the game and see if it got better. Some of my thoughts changed, some didn't. Then I ran into a save file breaking bug that apparently cannot be fixed. I just have to start the game over according to every forum post I've seen. Waiting still on THQ support to help me. So here's my review as the game stands now.

Positives first:
This game is beautiful on ultimate settings.
The combat is fine. It's not as good as the previous 2 games, but it's fine.
The weapons you get are cool, they're kind of rip-offs of stuff in DS2 but they're cool.
If you liked how Dark Souls 1 strung areas together using shortcuts, you'll appreciate this game as it is very good at doing that. Not as good, but still impressive and cool.
If you like Metroidvania style games, you may like this? Lots of back tracking to get more items as you gain new abilities. If you enjoy that, you'll probably like this. There's a good bit of that. More on that later.

Negatives:

The story is lame. Makes no sense as to how it weighs into the rest of the story we've had so far. Would have LOVED to have finished the story to see if that rings true at the end, but I am roughly halfway through now with a busted save file, and besides felt no sense of purpose in the game. Why am I hunting the sins? Cause the Charred Council said to because literally everyone else is busy. Cool way to make me feel awesome, everyone else is busy so I guess you'll do. [spoiler]Why do I serve the Lord of the Hollows kind of? I dunno he gives me weapons sometimes and that's cool.[/spoiler] It's just not that good.

Fury as a character isn't interesting. Feels like they wanted to make her come across as this super tough badass but the whole time it just fell short for me since we've had War, the ultimate super tough badass. The beginning of the game is literally her whining about how she's so much more of a super tough badass than her brothers and that's kind of her only motivation this game. The first DS game, War was trying to figure out what happened, since he knew he didn't purposefully start the apocalypse. The second game, Death is trying to redeem his brother War and rescue humanity. The third game, Fury is trying to prove she's cool or something?? Half of the cutscenes are so beyond bland and dull I have to fight not to skip them. The story in them always becomes a demon trying to convince Fury to give in to temptation and she's just like "nah I gotta be the cool one" and that's literally the extent of it.

The boss fights are stupid easy with the exception of 1 so far. Even on higher difficulties, I am playing on the one just below apocalyptic and have burned through every boss no problem except for Lust.

The game is sorely lacking the puzzles the first 2 games had. Most of the puzzles are "go into this room, kill the dudes, hit a switch probably using the fire ability you got 4+ hours ago at the beginning of the game". 

This game tried to lean very hard into the Dark Souls thing and it just didn't work. The combat, again, is fine, but to me it's not fun enough or challenging enough to give the satisfaction a real Soulsborne game gives you. You level up using souls, you pick up soul items, you heal using essentially an Estus flask, die and you lose your souls, you upgrade your weapon with their equivalent to the shard/large shard/chunk/slab method, and putting fuck you ambush enemies hiding around corners because that's almost the only way you'll get hurt.

The Metroidvania bit I mentioned at the top: the items you backtrack for are absolutely worthless. The only items you get are single use items, most of which don't do much or it's just more souls. There are no hidden weapons, no better gear. Just single use items and XP.

On to the performance: This game runs like TRASH. I have a 3080, 32GB RAM, and a Ryzen 7 3800X and half the time can't manage to pull a consistent 60 frames if I have settings anywhere over Medium. The game is hardlocked to 60 fps, cutscenes are all in 30 so they look like butt (not that they're interesting anyway), and the game has MAJOR crashing issues. I've played 6.3 hours over the course of this run at the game and haven't had a session that didn't end in a crash of the game. Also, 9 times out of 10, if you start the game through Steam, it will just crash at the start menu. You pretty much HAVE to launch it from the install directory.

And to top off this steaming pile of garbage, I'm 6 hours into the game, was having a decently fun time. Suddenly, I go to load the game today and it's not detecting DLC anymore which ruins the save file. The file can't be launched till it decides to detect the DLC that I own, have owned, installed, and have had installed the entire time. I've reinstalled everything, checked windows updates, driver updates, all of it. This is an issue that has been around since the Crucible DLC released, and has never been fixed. Per the forums and subreddit, there is no fix. If it happens, your save file is dead and you HAVE to start over if you want to play the game more.

In conclusion, I want to like this game. I can deal with the things I found to be "meh" because there are fun things about it. There really are. But the constant performance issues, crashing, and such make it so hard. And to top it all off with this game breaking issue is just sad. I contacted support 4 days ago and haven't heard back yet. I love this series, 1 and 2 were incredible, Genesis is pretty fun with a friend, and I was enjoying this game. But to have a game breaking bug like this and not have a resolution anywhere at all is absolutely insane. I'd recommend avoiding it and just watching a story summary if you even care.

Darksiders III was a pleasant surprise. After reading the reviews on the web I would have expected a mediocre game, instead I can say that for me it deserves an 8. Exploration is composed by paths forced by the plot and other secondary ones to gain souls and objects. Personally, I recommend Darksiders III to those who play action adventures but, given the low cost when it is on offer, also to those who want to try a soulslike game, but easier than any Fromsoftware title.

6.3/10

OVERVIEW - 
A solid game to buy if you're a fan of the Darksiders series; although, I would only buy this if it were on sale as the detraction from custom skills, abilities, limited armor sets - makes the game unreplayable to me. A fun single playthrough game but otherwise, I'll never touch it again. 

GAMEPLAY - 
A big change in terms of gameplay to the previous installations which are more 'hack and slashy':
- enemies will be significantly harder, when playing above balanced and hit HARD. 
- if playing a difficulty above balanced, when intitially starting out - you will die a lot. 
- you can 'time' your dodges, and perform a counter if timed perfectly, leading to increased damage. 
- no customisable skillset was a bit of a shock, compared to DS2 creating a more simplified levelling system with the choices of; health, damage, arcane damage (counters, secondary weapons). 
- weapons can be enhanced with runes and the runes themselves advanced. 
- armor is only purchaseable from Vulgrim, enhancing a preferred style for your secondary weapon but again, doesn't give you the same ability to make a character of your own. 
- bosses can be a bit too simple at times and clearing to them becomes more challenging than the actual boss.

STORY - 
The initial introduction to the character made me have a heavy distaste for her, but over time she becomes a little more tolerable, relatable and eventually maybe likeable. So bear with it, if you found it difficult to stick around at the start - I know I did, but I enjoyed it for the most part. I found the order of the sins to be a bit predictable unfortunately, I always hope to be shocked but this had barely any-to-no surprise at all for me. It's decently written but rather predictable if you've been exposed to anything with the seven deadly sins as a writing piece before. If they turned the order, or power levels on it's head - it would've made for a far more interesting story.

If you by chance played the first and or the second game prior to playing this, you will, quite appropriately, get -whiplash.-I've only ever played the first game seeing as the second's Steam port is broken beyond belief. Because of this I'll be referencing the first game for my comparing and contrasting. The first game showed off an interesting world and an expanse of good characters with an average narrative. The combat was hack-n-slash and also featured some button mashing and some finishers. The world-building and story quality has either stayed the same or improved, I can't tell, the combat however is quite different. And while I don't think that's inherently bad it's pretty condemning if you go in expecting it to be the same. This is very much a 'souls-like', a term that gets needlessly tossed around a lot. I'm not too bothered by this change, personally. The new mechanics are great, it's the old ones that got removed that bother me, mostly. 

The idea of having a horse as a horsemen is completely absent in this game, which is questionably one of the better changes. In the first game it felt very tacked on and often offered the least engaging combat. "The Horsemen is not defined by the horse," or something like that was said in the game by the Watcher; honestly, this couldn't be anymore true. Mechanics aside, the horses have never added anything to the narratives in these games. They've only ever been there to look edgy and help you get around quicker.

 I really liked the finishers in the first game and I'd have loved to see what creative, animated kills Fury could have pulled off with that serrated whip of hers, but alas, these have been removed entirely. Well, technically, there is one boss in the game you can do a finisher on. I honestly don't know why they included it, but they did. It's cool, but when you realize it's the only one the game it's sort of salt in the wound. I don't really understand why they did this at all either. You can make a souls-like with finishers where they're not just insta-win button prompts on screen. Jedi Fallen Order managed it.

 The map was removed. The reasoning for this if I recall correctly was to "encourage exploration" and "allow players to move around at the their own pace." Now, I could be remembering that wrong, but I don't see why a map would deter players in doing this, if anything NOT having a map would be the bump in the road here. If a player wants to speed-run the game and or explore every nook and cranny of the world that should be their right, and a map would have been ideal for both. This sort of just came off as lazy to me. 

I can't really comment on the game's narrative. I thought it was more memorable than the first's, but I'd be hard-pressed to say if it's anything better than "okay." The dialogue is good, as well as the characters. I thoroughly enjoyed the banter between the Watcher and Fury. And of course, it goes without saying the game is damn gorgeous to look at it. I do genuinely enjoy the style. Some enemy designs look meh, but I think most of them work. Regardless of this departure from its previous titles, Darksiders 3 is still a great game.

105506074.review:
I received Darksiders 3 as an early Christmas gift from a friend.

I have to admit, for the first couple of hours, I did not really enjoy this game. A younger, even more impatient me probably would have refunded it. But eventually I came to enjoy this title a bit more then the first game, but less so then the second. That's the short version. If you're like me and lamented this series being cast into limbo years before by the collapse of THQ, it would appear to be not quite dead yet. I do wonder if the original idea of a four-player-coop title will ever come to pass, however.

For those unfamiliar, the Darksiders series is an exaggerated, comic-book reimagining of the biblical apocalypse told through a lens of brutal action, melodramatic dialogue and where-the-hell-is-that-last-collectible world design. It generally makes up for shortcomings in certain mechanics and aesthetic design elements through overall fun factor. Each title in the series thus far has cast the player as a different one of the legendary Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. The first game starred War, the second Death, and then things get weird- Famine and Pestilence/Conquest were replaced with Fury and Strife, with Fury taking center stage for this title. Strife would later finally be made playable in the top-down Darksiders: Genesis. The chronology is also non-standard- the first title is chronologically the last in the series, but opens before the events of 2 and 3.

Each title also notably different mechanics from each other despite a central unifying theme of hack-and-slash gameplay. The first was essentially a Zelda-like with God of War's combat The second expanded on this, adding much wider open maps to explore and action-RPG mechanics like dungeons and statted gear, and replacing the first game's block with a dodge. This third entry instead goes into left field, taking on aspects of Dark Souls: A health item with charges a la an Estus Flask, using currency to level up (which, funnily enough, was already souls), using found items to incrementally upgrade weapons, dropping currency when you die, and so on. There's also an evade counter mechanic wherein if you dodge at the right time to avoid in attack you can use a powerful counterattack. I highly recommend getting a hang of doing this as it will make your life much easier, especially if you upgrade and use the spear weapon to do so.

To be frank, Darksiders 3's weakest aspects are those taken from the Souls series, most egregiously the total lack of a map screen where the first two games did have maps. Thankfully there is no invasion mechanic- not that would make any sense in the game's context. Still, the game is significantly easier then any Soulslike I have played, you just might get saddled with a few cheap respawns until you can upgrade and/or figure out the timing for evasion counters.

In contrast to the dimension-hopping escapades of Darksiders 2, he player as Fury, much like War in the first game, is again confined to a ruined Earth for this adventure. She must explore an interconnected world of urban ruins, underground temples, intertwining tree branches and more, even including the poison swamp area that Soulslikes are contractually obligated to have, in search of the Seven Deadly Sins, who make most, but not all of the game's boss fights. In the questionable absence of a map is a simple compass that points the way to the closest Sin boss, and it works well enough to keep you from getting stuck. Usually. Scattered about the game are various items and upgrades, some of which are used to upgrade your gear in Souls fashion while others provide new traversal abilities that open up new areas and passages to older ones in the manner of a Metroidvania. 

As I gathered souls and upgrades and my overall power level began to comfortably exceed that of most enemy encounters, the game's feel shifted from cheap to enjoyable- becoming more like Darksiders, in essence. Still, the game's difficulty is at best inconsistent- large groups of regular enemies coupled with the game's low default field of view tend to be a much greater threat then any singular boss fight. Thankfully there is an easy way to extend your FOV detailed in one of the Steam Guides, though it should really be an in-game option.

DSIII also surprised me with the quality of its writing, perhaps surprising given its origins and emphasis on spectacle. Where initially Fury comes off as the exceedingly brash, uncharismatic virago her name might suggest, replete with ridiculous stiletto heels built into her armor, she undergoes a significant amount of character development that I will not spoil here. Suffice it to say that her personal growth was actually one of game's strongest aspects.

Darksiders 3 is an overall decent action title and I recommend it to fans of metroidvanias, character action games, Soulslikes and returning fans of the series.

103353485.review:
Conclusion and TL;DR:

I want to recommend this game, but I am currently unwilling to except to people already invested in the series, entirely due to the combat system. I explain my issues with the combat in the Gameplay section below. The story took too long to entice me, but I wound up liking the story in the end.

Intro:

I played Darksiders 1 several years ago on the PS 3. I didn't think highly of it, but I enjoyed it well enough to get the second game, also on the PS 3. I thoroughly enjoyed the second. I could easily recommend the first two games. I liked them enough to also get them on Steam, and I was eventually given the Warmastered and Deathinitive Editions of 1 and 2. I've yet to complete Darksiders Genesis as of writing this review so I will say as little as I can about it unless to convey any point I want to make. My time with the first two games encouraged me to get the third. 

Story: 

The Darksiders games are about the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, Fury, Strife, War, and Death. While drawing inspiration from the biblical Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse the games are a separate matter. Darksiders 1-3 basically take place concurrently with each game exploring the erroneous triggering of the Apocalypse and the roles that each of the Horsemen play during this concurrent time, in particular regarding War, Death, and Fury, respectively. Strife has no game yet, but hopefully one will come; Darksiders Genesis does allow you to play as Strife and War, but the numbered games are strictly about War, Death, and Fury. 

I wasn't particularly invested in Fury's story as it unfolded, but the ending and some character growth along the way really changed my mind on this matter and the game as a whole. It is because of this that I actually do want to recommend this game. 

Graphics:

No scenery stood out as memorable in a good way. A particular region is quite ugly, but that, presumably, is by design given that it's home to either insect or arachnid-like creatures, so it's at least justified. The game is prettier than bland but not particularly pretty. Darksiders 1 and 2 in contrast had some absolutely gorgeous areas.

Sound:

The game has some unpleasant sounds, but I am overly sensitive to light and sound.  Fortunately, this never proved problematic and I usually recovered quickly. 

There is a soundtrack. That's almost all I recall of it, sadly. I really liked the piece that played on the character screen and would often pause the game just to hear it. I do not mean to say the music is bad, just that I cannot recall anything to actually voice an opinion on it. Contrast this with Darksiders 2 where I routinely play the soundtrack while doing chores, studying, artwork, etc. I am disappointed at how forgettable I've found the soundtrack to be with Darksiders 3 after the masterclass soundtrack of Darksiders 2. I never once felt that the music added to or detracted from the general experience, probably because I really never noticed it, but I'd much rather this than a soundtrack that actually detracts from the experience as is the case with some games.

There is some good voice acting but I generally consider it inferior to the voice acting in the first two games. This, however, does not mean that I dislike the voice acting. There are some well-delivered lines and the emotions behind the speech generally fit any scene in question. A few characters really stood out in good quality. 

Gameplay:

I have completed this game and earned all the achievements. 

The combat is what kills it for me. I find it cheap, and difficult for the wrong reasons. I have read comparisons to the Souls games but I have never played any of those so that means nothing to me. Darksiders 1 has been compared to God of War. I have completed God of War 1, 2, 3, Ghost of Sparta, Chains of Olympus, and Ascension on their hardest difficulties. I have also completed Ninja Gaiden Black on Master Ninja a few times, though I am by no means good at NGB on MN. While I am not aware of anyone comparing any Darksiders game to NGB, I bring it up to show that I am not unaccustomed to difficult games.

Fury, as one of the Horsemen, is, canonically, one of the most feared and powerful beings in all of creation, even prior to the Apocalypse, but this game presents her as a weakling. This game takes Segregation of Story and Gameplay to the extreme. It is often necessary to whittle away at enemies while even the weakest enemies can often kill you in 2-3 hits. Dodging often feels useless and there is no way to block attacks. All too often, if you don't time a dodge perfectly, a Perfect Dodge, then you will almost invariably get hit as the enemies' aim is almost infallible, with incredible homing. Further, if an enemy hits you once then it will usually hit you a second time with a follow-up, meaning you're often effectively one-shot. Worse is that the Perfect Dodge is not just a useful gimmick, like it is in Darksiders 2, but effectively necessary for survival. 

You can try to isolate and kill one enemy at a time, and you should, but the game has an annoying habit of throwing multiple enemies at you at once, often in small arena-like areas. While two enemies isn't usually so bad, three or more quite often means you're dead because you can't block and dodging is largely useless if not perfect as well as the fact that you can be hit during the execution of a Perfect Dodge by at least one of the other enemies nearby. This game seems to think you should kill slowly, one at a time, but then throws multiple enemies at you; It appears to be confused as to what it thinks it is, and I think it's fair to say that I am certainly confused as to what the game thinks it is.

Never do I feel powerful as I progress, only less weak. This is in stark contrast to War and Death. Fury is the weakest of the Four, but this does not readily explain why she so easily dies. I think if Fury started with double the health, 1.5x the attack power, and had a slightly more useful dodge then things wouldn't be so bad, and to compensate for these changes I would make it a bit more difficult to gain levels. 

Despite my complaints about the combat, I have actually enjoyed several of the boss fights and boss-like encounters. I don't really know what to say on this point, but I thought I should share it all the same.

You can level Fury's health and physical and arcane power, but it often feels moot until you get weapon enhancements, and even then it depends on which you get, which you equip, and how you upgrade them. These can potentially end up making a significant difference, especially when combined with a certain item and a particular piece of DLC armor. These enhancements can improve both offensive and defensive abilities. If you have the Keeper of the Void DLC then you can equip more enhancements, due to an increased number of weapons, making the game that much easier. Each enhancement has a passive and active effect, with the passive effect always active if added to a weapon and the active effect only active if it is on the currently drawn weapon. You can only use one enhancement per weapon but the combined effects of the passives means that this doesn't particularly matter much if you've taken care to level them and you equip them efficiently.

I played Darksiders 1 and 2 a long time ago and got this in Humble Monthly, thought I would give it a try after hearing mixed feedback and I am a little bit torn between giving it a positive or negative review, for me it sits right in the middle.

First I will say, this game tries to borrow from a lot of different genres.
It tries to be a metroidvania like its predecessors by having different abilities you acquire throughout the game to unlock new areas or side areas with bonuses, however it feels a little bit forced in this iteration. Most of the time, one ability unlocks the next zone, which leads to another ability that unlocks another zone, etc. It feels quite linear in that regard, and most of the backtracking I did only led to some minor currency or power-up. In some instances I went back, unlocked a passage from a previous zone and it led me to another block I could not unlock with my current abilities, which made it feel like a waste of time. Instead, I should continue down the linear path until I get enough abilities that I can go back and clear everything at once, but then all those power-ups are meaningless.

It tries to be a "souls-like" game by using limited healing, checkpoints and a souls currency which is used to level up. It does not go very far in build customization, you basically allocate each level up to either health, regular damage or counter damage. You can also upgrade weapons and slot stones into them which have passive effects, as well as upgrade those stones. Finally, combat is also designed to include a lot of dodging and countering and punish mashing (there seem to be a setting to disable that if you dont like it), which I enjoyed but it quickly becomes repetitive when countering attacks is the only optimal way to go. In that regard it feels more like an Arkham-style fighting than Dark Souls. The souls aspect is also made a bit trivial because you can die as many times as you'd like and still are able to collect your souls back, they don't disappear if you die on the way to get them back. On top of that the NPC that makes you level up accepts as many souls as you have, even if it is not enough to level up (so if you have 1000 souls but need 1500 to level you can still give him those 1000 souls and no longer risk losing them). It made me feel like I was playing Dark Souls on some kind of easy mode and felt a bit condescending.

This game also errs on the side of games like Devil May Cry, with multiple weapon options that each have their own combos and encourages you to mix and match, two different meters that fill up when fighting which enable you to use a powerful ability and an invicibility ability, but like I said most of that is trivialized by the fact that enemies don't stagger too much (the souls-like aspect) and countering their attacks is required to stay alive and is anyway optimal since it deals the most damage.

All in all I commend the developers for incorporating so many different systems and mechanics into the game, but it feels like there is something missing to bring it all together harmoniously.

Now on the topic of story, I heard this game was praised for giving a female character a strong lead, but I have to say I am hugely disappointed. I may upset some fans for saying this but Fury is a typical example of a female character written from a male perspective. She's rash, impulsive, frequently makes a fool of herself and needs to be "steered" in the right direction by the supporting cast of male side characters. The whole game is supposed to showcase her growth and be the story of how she became a better person but it just feels demeaning and very remote from any kind of female empowerment story. At least to me.

I did not really like the fact that this game is a(nother) prequel to the first Darksiders and is just here to fill in some gaps and explain some things that happen in the first game. It basically is a whole story in itself but in the grand scheme of things it is ultimately completely pointless, since we already know how it is supposed to end since we know what happens next.

To conclude, I would say that this game deserves some love, it looks great and plays alright and I am sure some people will have a blast with it. It offers a lot of content if you're into exploring every nook and cranny and building up your character, however it falls short on many aspects and I could not bring myself to spend more time playing it.

Well, this isn’t that great of a game, it doesn’t really succeed as a sequel to Darksiders 1 and 2, and it doesn’t really succeed on its own premise either, it just kind of exists between the two different game's design ideas.

Let’s just get on with it, it’s no secret that when Vigil Games envisioned Darksiders they took a lot of inspiration from The Legend of Zelda, and even though Darksiders 2 introduced RPG elements it retained its Zelda DNA, with the RPG elements having been built up around the Zelda core rather than influencing it a whole lot. Darksiders 3 on the hand, tries to fusion Zelda with Dark Souls on a much more intimate level, where they tried to build a core out of them, which didn’t really work out that well.

There are elements of the game wanting to be Dark Souls so much but failing in how tight and poorly optimised the dodge mechanic is, it wants you to lose currency and progress when you die, but it doesn’t want to give you useful or applicable “campfires”, it wants Zelda like abilities, but it also wants to tie them to combat on a much more fundamental level. There are a lot of things Darksiders 3 wants to achieve, it wants to satisfy returning fans of Darksiders 1 and 2, but it also want to appeal to a newer soulsborne fanbase, and it wants to give a satisfying difference from how War and Death plays, which it actually does pretty well, taking everything into consideration, Fury plays and acts very different from her siblings and displaces a personality wholly her own, which I’ll commend Gunfire Game for achieving. But other than that, it doesn’t really measure that well up to its predecessors.

102582174.review:
TLDR: Darksiders 3 is a mostly solid game that, if you can get it on sale (≤$20), I'd say it is definitely worth trying out. 6.5/10

I had a doozy of a time playing this game. The first four to five hours I spent on this, I was baffled at how this game could have been so poorly received online. The visuals have a fun 90s comic book aesthetic to them, the combat, while somewhat frustrating at times, was still pretty fun, and the sound and story were pretty enjoyable. Then came the later stages of the game.

Darksiders 3 tried experimenting with a mesh of some character action/beat-em up style combat, but with the Darksouls inspired take on "don't bite off more than you can chew" and fight too many enemies at once. In theory, this is pretty fun, especially since Fury is meant to be a very experienced warrior, making many of her fights 1v1 or 1v3,4,5, etc. seems cool. The problem is that, unlike Dark Souls, which features pretty forgivable hitboxes and a bevy of tools to avoid, mitigate, or negate their damage, the enemies in this game are absolute lethal killing machines, and you have exactly one maneuver to prevent them from hitting you. Fury can 'perfect dodge' to avoid 100% of the damage of an enemies attack and then land a pretty strong counter (provided you're close enough); the problem here is that enemies frequently get behind you and outside of a small red arrow and a quick sound queue that will appear to indicate their attack you will have nearly no warning when one of these flanking enemies attacks you which can lead to some cheap-feeling deaths and frustrating combat encounters. It's also worth noting that when you're fighting the larger rooms of 7-10+ enemies, these sound queues and red arrows are so numerous that it's really just not helpful, and in addition, in the traditional mode of the game, you are locked into an attack animation and cannot cancel that animation to dodge; meaning you get locked in on one enemy and hit by another very frequently, especially in larger fights. You are able to use Items, a leveling system featuring stat upgrades, and special weapons from unlockable forms that can help here, but do yourself a favor and toggle on classic mode (A decision I made way too late into the game), which will save you from a majority of these combat-related headaches. 

Aside from combat, you have your traditional Metroidvania-style puzzles to progress through the map. I personally did not really love or hate these puzzles. None of them really stuck out in my mind as particularly fun or terrible. The puzzles that involve slowly waiting for bugs to ingest some power up and then chucking them really quickly to destroy a wall just sort of felt like a needless chore, in my opinion, though. 

Where my main gripe in this game comes from is the last two levels, in which, without giving spoilers away, I will just say feature both the least fun boss in the game "Gluttony," which is just an unfun chore to fight, as well as probably the worst most unfun level in the entire game "Lowlands" which features several instant death moments (genuinely a majority of game deaths I had came from this one level). This is a shame because, as I mentioned, prior to these later areas, I really enjoyed exploring the world of this game, but my desire to go through the side paths to unlock shortcuts and secrets died and in its place a desire to just be done with the game formed because of these two final areas. 

Lastly, the story. I hadn't played any of the Darksiders games previously, so I was confused by the grander context of the universe (fair enough since I skipped the prequels), but even the more graspable story of Fury wasn't really all that great I found. Your mileage here, as with everything else I mentioned, will vary. However, for my money, I sort of started tuning out what was happening in the end. It really feels like something I could have read in an issue of Spawn back in the day, which might sound incredibly appealing to some and very offputting to others. 

Overall, the bones of a genuinely cool game are here, but it just doesn't feel fleshed out enough for $60. If you can get it on sale for $20 or less, then I'd recommend it, but otherwise, unless you're a fan of the series or a Metroidvania fiend, I'd wait.  6.5/10
