100494733.review:
So, to start with: It's a bit scaled-down from Darksiders II, but it still fits. The theme, visual identity, and story are all recognizably Darksiders, and all satisfying enough. Enemies are varied enough, especially considering how few enemies it takes to pose a threat, and nearly all of the bosses are at least memorable in their design, and sometimes in their combat styles. It's hard not to love [spoiler]Sloth, a boss carried around by his minions because he's too lazy to walk -- I've never had a boss be too lazy to fight me before![/spoiler]

The story is... not [i]good[/i], but fun. Think of it a little like Warhammer 40k: A little absurd and a little over-the-top, doesn't completely make sense, but can Rule-of-Cool its way to a good time anyway. (Also, way less grimdark, despite being literally apocalyptic.)

Of the DLC, I skipped The Crucible, but I can recommend Keepers of the Void as at least a reasonable set of Zelda-dungeons that were somewhat missing from the base game. The only problem is, the DLC bosses are all absurdly more challenging than anything in the base game, and the reward for defeating the final one is pretty powerful, which means the rest of the game was [i]much[/i] easier afterwards.

Xbox Controller works fine and is probably recommended -- there's no precise aiming that would make a mouse useful.

It's hard to describe what kind of game it actually is. It's definitely not an ordinary sequel.

[hr][/hr]

Performance is kind of all over the place. On a Titan, struggles to maintain 60 at times, but can usually manage at least 40-50, and there's a config file hack to unlock higher refresh rates. High refresh rates don't seem to cause problems, except maybe some framepacing issues, so I also played with a frame limit of 120. Most cutscenes are locked to 30 for some reason. There honestly doesn't seem to be enough going on here to justify these issues, but it was rare enough and minor enough that it didn't kill the experience for me.

Only one crash-to-desktop for me, and it didn't cost me any progress.

[hr][/hr]

So what about the actual mechanics?

Darksiders (as a series) does plenty to establish its own visual theme and story, but it also tends to borrow mechanics wholesale from [i]many[/i] games. I actually kind of like that, and the first game played out like a mixtape of a bunch of my favorite games... but it's not like the Crossblade is "inspired by" the Zelda Boomerang. It just is that boomerang with different artwork.

So when this one is described as a Souls-like, it's not just that it has hard bosses, a parry system, and a death-run mechanic. It's more like talking about Bloodborne, where you may as well give up talking about "blood echoes" and "bloodstone" and so on, they're just reskinned souls and Titanite, respectively. In this game, Lurchers are souls, Adamantite is Titanite, and Lurcher Clumps (and Clusters and so on) are soul items. Nephilim's Respite is Estus, and I honestly can't be bothered to remember the equivalent of Firekeeper's Souls.

Where it differs is the hollow system (an elemental system, probably closest to DmC), upgradable enchantments, wrath and havoc attacks, and difficulty settings... and otherwise being pared down significantly, even compared to Dark Souls 1. There are, maybe, ten weapons and ten armor sets in the game, each a single item (not a separate helm/torso/gloves/boots/etc), no equippable accessories (just permanent upgrades), and of course no equipment load system. With so few items, there's no real item-text-as-hidden-storytelling. You can't murder friendly NPCs, and it's not like they'd drop anything interesting. There's no mana or refillable-at-bonfire spells -- the closest is wrath and havoc bars, but these can only be used when full. You can't really build a mage, the closest you can do is find equipment that refills those bars faster when you have to go back to melee.

All of which is great for me, and probably great for fans of earlier games who might not have [i]wanted[/i] a Soulslike. I bounced off Dark Souls as both too difficult and too [i]inaccessible[/i], to the point where you kind of need a wiki to understand basic mechanics. This one might lean towards too much handholding, but the game should have enough difficulty settings to provide a reasonable challenge both for actual Souls fans, and for people who [i]don't[/i] want to Git Gud.

But it's worth pointing out that while this game stole most of its mechanics from Dark Souls, there's a lot to Dark Souls that didn't make it into this game.

[hr][/hr]

What about other stuff from the Darksiders games?

It's been a long time since I've played those, so it's hard to tell, but it seems like a [i]lot[/i] is missing. Gone is the horse-riding, and also most areas big enough for a horse to make sense. Gone is the [i]entire[/i] item ecosystem from Darksiders 2, and Fury is the first Horseman who doesn't seem to have a gun. The upgrade [i]tree[/i] is gone entirely, replaced with only three stats you can level up, plus leveling up equipment.

There's still the Zelda boomerang, and it can carry your Hollow element. And there are [i]very[/i] occasional Zelda-like puzzles, most of them extremely simple -- you need the DLC if you want a puzzle challenge. And there's a setting (separate from difficulty settings) to make the combat more forgiving, allow more animation-cancelling and such, to at least make the hacking and slashing feel more familiar.

There's also still wrath and Havoc attacks... but that's really all I can think of. Gameplay-wise, it's almost better not to try to compare this to the rest of the series. You get a much better sense of what it is by comparing it to Dark Souls.

[hr][/hr]

With all that said: It's hard to know who to recommend this game to. I guess: If you liked the first game and you're willing to try a Souls-like, give this a shot? But I had fun and the game's technical issues didn't ruin it, so it gets a thumbs up from me.

A hack n' slash game that has you taking on the role of Fury, one of the horsemen of the apocalypse, to whip the seven deadly sins into submission. More things happen and stuff is said in deep intimidating voices and humans exist but don't really do much. It's a good backdrop to the action that takes place overall really. Some interactions with the main character and the others can be entertaining too.

Fury's on the squishier side so she can die pretty quickly, but dodging your foes' well telegraphed attacks will keep her alive, with proper timing allowing a deadly counterattack. This and her regular attacks are all satisfying to perform on the various enemies you face. Fending off a horde of enemies is feasible but care must be taken, getting stuck between them and their flurry of attacks can spell certain doom. Your adversaries feel varied enough for the game's length and each provide a decent challenge to surmount on their own. The bosses provide more spectacle and challenge than your typical fight but are still pretty manageable, at least on "Normal" difficulty.

The game has a large focus on exploration as well, with the metroidvania elements you'd expect such as paths being gated off by abilities you acquire later, the game being a large interconnected space with shortcuts you can unlock, puzzles to solve and secrets to find for the observant. Exploring the world is enjoyable overall, with the main annoyance being the lack of an overall world map. It can make it a little hard to figure out whether you're going the right way, and you might experience confusion when trying to figure out which fast travel destination is where. And the only thing there really is for you to find are upgrade materials for your weapons, the rare weapon boosting rune and some consumable powerups. The fast travel points are also where you respawn after death, which can be annoying if you die repeatedly in some places.

It looks and sounds really nice too.

A fun romp overall, I'd strongly recommend it to fans of hack and slash as well as exploration focused games.

100069668.review:
Darksiders 3 was very divisive when it first came out. It was divisive because it strayed away from the hack and slash / action adventure roots people were familiar with from the first 2 games in favor of a Dark Souls approach. Haven beaten the game I think this would have been a better game if it dropped the Souls  portion and stuck to its roots. The game is good but could have been better.

I really had to push through the beginning of this game because all the little mobs were killing me quickly. Often times it would be the off screen goons jumping in and sniping hits at me leading to quick deaths. There's a depth of field mod to help with peripheral vision but I skipped it and played the game as it was intended. Once I'd learned to filter enemies into single lines or lure them away from mobs things became slightly better.

The next frustration was the check point system. Early on check points were a minute or two from bosses which meant tracking back through mobs you'd already killed every time you died to a boss -- and remember, it's early on in the game, you're still learning the systems and are underpowered most of the time. I hated this approach in Hollow Knight and I hated it here. Later on in the game, check points were more frequent and outside boss rooms AS THEY SHOULD BE. 

Souls act as currency in this game. You trade souls accumulated for items or to buy attribute points needed to level up your character. Souls are lost when you die forcing you to track back and collect them where you died, a mechanic I'm not fond of as you might as well just respawn me at the last checkpoint with whatever I've accumulated at that point. Fortunately, souls also come in crystal form and are preserved when you die. You quickly learn to dump your raw souls into purchasing attribute points while keeping crystal souls in stock for bigger purchases or stat pumps.

Attribute points are split into health, physical damage and arcane damage. I ended the game with 700 health (20% boost from an item), +50 phys and +200 arcane. Why so much arcane? Because your Wrath, Havoc and all charge moves are arcane based. Havoc form sees Fury transform into giant form that is impervious to damage, heals itself and does arcane based damage. Wrath has various effects governed by which form Fury has equipped but all deal arcane based damage. 

Personally this attribute point system could've been skipped with weapons determining which stat they relied on with weapon slots and other equips giving rise to customization. Speaking of weapons...

Weapons come too late into the game. By the time you've gotten them you've already started upgrading some of them and the resources to upgrade them are either bought with souls, gained from drops or are limited items needed for final upgrades. Souls are better used buying relics and attribute points so you're more or less depending on what you find to upgrade weapons unless you want to grind souls. Weapons are tied to the exploration powers you receive from beating bosses. I would have made all weapons available from the start so that players can pick a playstyle and make builds around the weapons and have exploration powers not be weapon dependent. 

The last complaint I have is the absence of a map. The world is well designed. Everywhere you go is distinct. I do not have a perfect memory though so some system of tracking where doors, obstacles, hidden items or points of interest are would have been appreciated. There are hundreds of little blobs, colour coded obstacles and snaking paths in this game. Backtracking is better saved until you have the last exploration power up or you'll burn yourself out revisiting and combing thru areas after each power unlock. 

Asides from these gripes, I had fun with the game once I understood its systems. I played on normal difficulty and classic playstyle (dodge cancelling enabled). Some difficulty was encountered with getting the game running but once I did it ran fine.

If you've played the previous Darksiders entry then this one is worth a go with the caveat that it takes some getting used to. I've never played a Souls game before so maybe the folks who have will have an easier time with it. 

Onto Genesis for me. :)

Over all very good game, would recommend.

99808081.review:
I Had a really good time with this game. Part 3 trades in the 'beat em ups meets Zelda dungeons' approach of 1 and 2 for a more Dark Souls inspired combat system in an interconnected Metroid style world. If you were a huge fan of the previous 2 games you may find the changes in gameplay really off putting but as someone who enjoys the kinds of games Darksiders 3 is borrowing from, I didn't mind too much.

You play as Fury, the whip wielding 3rd horseman of the apocalypse on a quest to find and kill personifications of the 7 Deadly Sins. Its a fun adventure. Nothing super original but TBH what in this series is? The story is very serviceable and I really enjoyed Fury as a character. She's brash and snarky at 1st but has some character growing to do before everything is said and done. Her design is also very nice with tons of detail and she looks great in action with some truly excellent animations.

Fury controls really well and using her whip to attack enemies and weave in and out of groups with her invincible dodge feels amazing once you get it down. The dodge is your only real defensive option but a perfectly timed one grants a cool slow mo counter attack that always feels great to pull off. As you progress, you'll earn new elemental abilities that come with their own sub weapons that can be wielded simultaneously with the whip to string together some flashy and damaging combos. There's also a special attack meter that fills as you attack and dodge that gives access to the equipped sub weapon's magic attack. Use this often cause you'll get it back in no time and it can be very helpful. Fury also has her invincible Havoc Form which is a kind of super mode that you'll want to be much more conservative with but can turn a fight around in a pinch. Turning this on and watching Fury let loose on a tough enemy or devastate an entire group is so much fun. Healing is handled much like Dark Souls with a limited but rechargeable health item that can be upgraded and dropped by enemies. The game also has consumables you can use for temporary buffs and finite heals. These items have a use animation that can get you tagged if you're not careful but finding the right time to use them mid fight is vital to success. The combat is tough but never feels unfair and difficulty can be lowered at any time if you're struggling. I suggest anyone looking to test themselves to check out Apocalyptic difficulty.

Darksiders 3 also has some light RPG mechanics so you can carve out your own playstyle with different stats to level and focus on as well as equippable items that can do everything from buff your magic attacks to passively heal you. Its not super deep but it does help to flavor the action quite well. The elemental powerups I mentioned previously also add to your exploration options with things like double jumps or gliding through the air. The world is all interconnected and going back to old areas with new powers can be very rewarding with all the secrets hidden around and the fast travel system keeps backtracking from ever being a chore. The game takes place in a post apocalyptic city which can make the world a little boring visually from time to time, but the game is still quite colorful so nothing is ever too drab to look at.

Enemy design is really well done and there's tons of variety in the enemies you fight. The bosses can be pretty unforgiving while you learn their patterns and have that 'Simon says: you HAVE to dodge here, then attack exactly twice' problem the soulslike genre is often pretty guilty of but they can be fun dances once you get them down. Apocalyptic was what I played on my 1st run and it was pretty frustrating at points but the normal mode should be a nice even challenge for most folks. 

The game clocks in around 10-15 hrs depending on how much side content you do and there is some replay value with new game plus as well. The Keepers of the Void DLC adds some (honestly pretty samey but still fun)  dungeons and bosses you can fight for new sub weapons and The Crucible DLC adds a survival arena. They're both pretty fun and I recommend them on a sale. 

I was surprised how much I enjoyed Darksiders 3. There isn't really anything new on display but what is here is very well done. I think anyone looking for a Souls style game with some character action flair or even just a solid action game with some fun exploration could do a whole lot worse.

If you’ve played Darksiders III then you most likely have played the first and second one as well. Like the second one Darksiders III opts to do things a little differently and in my opinion it succeeds, but not on all fronts.

While the first one was a great Zelda clone and the second one even bigger with an entire open world and a loot system, this third one scales things back a little, this time choosing to be a little more like a Dark Souls game instead. 
You can tell that Darksiders didn’t do as well as a franchise and therefore the funding seems to have been decreased this time in comparison to the previous titles, but I commend them for trying something different with the obviously smaller budget they had.
Calling it a Dark Souls clone would do it injustice - and it would be disrespectful - because it is its own game, set in the Darksiders universe, complete with unlockable moves, hidden loot and well known traditional visual style (this time playing as Fury). It all feels like an actual Darksiders game, except with harder, sometimes even frustrating, combat. But gone are the dungeons of old, as is your mount from the second game and some other small stuff.

Traveling through the world feels responsive and all of the areas seem to be well connected, with a boss fight at the end of each area and plenty of items to be found. There’s a bit of (optional) backtracking involved so it still has a little bit of a Metroidvania blueprint in it.
Better equipment can be found and unlocked and you have a whip at your disposal when you first start the game. There’s nothing that helps you block damage, instead you have to rely on dodging and trying to finish the fights as quickly as possible (but it isn’t necessary if you don’t want to). Enemies will drop souls that help you level and power up and if you die there’s one more try to retrieve them; die again and they’re forever lost.
The boss fights can be difficult, but never as hard as Dark Souls’. With controls that can be changed (one of the first patches gave this option, because sometimes the original movement and layout didn’t quite work as good) and plenty of items that can help in combat it might take you a few tries to take one down, but generally speaking it shouldn’t take you over 5 tries or so.
Finishing the game should take you anywhere between 12 and 15 hours I’d say.

The visuals of the game aren’t brilliant, but they fit the style of the Darksiders games for sure. Fury seems be nicely animated.
The voice acting is also solid, with a few enemies here and there speaking in an over-the-top manner, but also making it seem more like a spectacle than it actually is in the process, which is a positive.
I didn’t really have any issues, except for a few issues where the camera didn’t do what it was told. And the controls which were a little weirder in comparison to 1 and 2, but that issue was quickly solved with a patch.

The big question is: would I recommend this third Darksiders game? Yes. The combat may be hard(er), but it’s also quite enjoyable once you get into the flow of the game. It’s a smaller, tighter game in comparison to the previous titles, but that doesn’t make it any worse. In fact, it was kind of refreshing to play something a little more direct, a little more linear, after all of these open world games the past couple of months and years.

[h1] Horseless Horseman [/h1]
Like a phoenix from the ashes, Darksiders franchise has risen from the dead following the acquisition of THQ by Nordic Games. The third instalment of the series depicts a tale of Fury, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse, sent to hunt down powerful demons known as the seven deadly sins. Being an avid fan of the first two games I was more than happy to once again see my favourite depiction of the biblical horsemen. However, for all the pretty notions of “the miracle of life” - the act of birth itself is a rather nasty business. The first steps of Darksiders 3 were much more alike those of a toddler than the mythical fiery bird. After a messy launch it took the developers time, plenty of performance patches and 2 DLCs to raise the newborn Darksiders into a game it is today. In short, the title in question is a decent action game in itself, albeit one that falls flat in comparison to the rest of the Darksiders franchise. 

[b] Vulgrim’s fireplace [/b]
When it comes to the long answer as to why Darksiders 3 is an odd one out, perhaps the best place to begin is the fact that the game can be accurately described as “soulslike”. What will immediately draw the attention of the franchise veterans is a significantly different combat system. Now it relies heavily on dodges which, when timed well, allow the player to perform a powerful counterattack. Furthermore, Fury’s simplistic moveset forces her to single-out enemies, forcing a much more methodical approach to combat. No more hurling the Horseman into the heat of battle and decimating groups of foes with devastating combos. Now a group of 3 sturdier enemies may prove a deadly threat. Moreover, take note that the game’s primary currency of souls is now used foremost to level up your character; and needs to be spent at the trader. The souls are also lost on the player’s death, but may be retrieved from the place where you met your end. Let’s just sprinkle on top the fact that the game is now only saved upon reaching one of Vulgrim’s serpent holes, requiring the player to replay significant parts of the level after dying and note that primary healing item is an upgradable trinket – Nephilim’s respite (not-an-estus™). The above doesn’t make the game bad, however it does paint a picture of severe identity crisis.
[url] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2594393382 [/url]
[b] Redemption Arc [/b]
Storywise, Darksiders 3 feels more at home. Called forth by the Charred Council, Fury is sent to eliminate the latest threat, capable of tipping the balance in the endless war between heavens and hell – the seven deadly sins. Taking place shortly before the main events of the first Darksiders, Fury’s mission takes her to a post-apocalyptic Earth. Basic familiarity with Wrath’s chapter of the story is strongly recommendable for context, as Darksiders 3’s plot is for the most part confusing mess.

An example of how the events tend to unfold in Darksiders 3 should speak volumes for itself. At early stage of the game Fury summons her steed, Rampage, only to find it writhing in agony from multiple angelic lances piercing its hide. As Fury watches in horror, her enemy uses the confusion to deal her a grievous blow, only for the broken horseman to get whisked away into a magical portal. A mysterious Lord of the Hollows reveals himself and straight-up tells Fury that she’s being used as a mere pawn - now serving as an enforcer of the council, not the balance her superiors are supposed to uphold. Fury brushes off the blunt piece of exposition as ridiculous. In response, Lord of the Hollows develops a habit of “randomly” summoning Fury, bestowing the now horseless rider with elemental powers and wooing her back into the action, conveniently equipped with means to progress the game. Oh, and Rampage? Fury brings up the matter in a single conversation and the plot thread is dropped there, unresolved. 

What I mean to highlight with the scene above is how Darksiders 3 repeatedly appears to set up events and characters as far more relevant than they eventually turn out to be. To make matters worse, Fury begins the game as a painfully uncompelling character. True to her name, she’s moody and impetuous, in a manner unbecoming of her station. The reoccurring theme of redemption, involved with horsemen quests, in case of Fury is conquering her bad temper. To the game’s credit, it has a surprisingly decent ending, which really takes by surprise considering to how silly most of the plot is. If only it didn’t include a mysterious trinket that everyone allegedly knows about, short only of Fury and the player. Over and over again, the story is all setup and no pay-off.

[b] Two steps forward, one step back [/b]
Reception of Dark Souls inspirations is a matter of taste and some may forgive story shenanigans in an action game. Truth be told, the core gameplay of this title is positively decent. Tailored around new combat system, the fighting does feel satisfying once you get used to it. Especially numerous and varied encounters with the bosses are the definite highlight of Darksiders 3, providing both a challenge and a jolt of adrenaline. The game heavily encourages exploration, inviting player to revisit areas after acquisition of new powers as to reach new secrets filled with loot. Playing a gatherer proved a surprisingly fun way to fill time between the fights, as environmental puzzles are extremely downplayed in Darksiders 3 to the point they no longer play this part. 

Sadly, the second you begin to consider this title as part of the series, it all becomes a downward spiral. Those familiar with previous games may as well forget that Darksiders 2 ever happened. Any notions of an open world, the grand scale, RPG-like loot system are well out of the window. Comparable only to the first game, Darksiders 3 prefers its environment up-close and personal. The entirety of the game takes place exclusively on the ravaged Earth, considerably downplaying biblical inspirations and aesthetic that should be the staple of the game. To make matters worse, the game consistently uses the models from the previous two titles, perhaps the most obnoxious example of recycling being Darksiders 2’s arena made into a DLC in the third game. It is fun to play, however seeing what used to be part of base game sold separately just nails the coffin. In Darksiders 3 defence, the puzzle-centred Keepers of the Void DLC does prove that you could get inventive with Fury’s powers, and delivers by far the best bossfight of the game. It’s a shame that it takes extra content to experience this variety, sorely missing from the base game. No matter how you look at it, as a part of a franchise, Darksiders 3 is a step back in almost every regard.

[b] Beating the dead horse [/b]
Closing summary of Darksiders 3 proved to be unusually conflicted task, as the game left me with extremely mixed impressions. Despite all the criticism I have for the Fury’s chapter, I did enjoy this title. It is a fun action piece, fully capable of delivering several evenings worth of a good time. This would normally earn the game a “reluctant pass” mark, although I do struggle to find an audience I could genuinely recommend this game to. Being a sequel, it would normally be the fans of the franchise, however Darksiders 3 is foremost guilty by association – decent as it may be, the game fails to meet the high standard established by its predecessors. In fact, the fans of series are the ones most likely to get disappointed. Those among you starved for more Darksiders content and prepared to keep your expectations low, should however find this title a safe bet. I have no regrets about time spent with Fury’s whipping frenzy, which doesn’t change the fact Darksiders 3 is just a bad sequel.

Starting off with some positives, graphically it's gorgeous.

No blocks, no hard combos.
Just a primary weapon, secondary weapon of your choosing, neither of which compliment each other.
And a dodge which feels slugging, unsatisfying and is your main method for surviving against enemies, although it does come with a counterattack if you do successfully dodge.

Gameplay itself - combat and puzzles. The combat, well, it's not exactly what you'd call intricate or complex. You click the mouse buttons. A couple different attacks depending on the order and timing but it never evolves past wait wait wait dodge click click click wait wait wait dodge click click click for the stronger enemies and spam click for the few weak ones. Still, it looks cool. The animations and effects feel satisfying. So I never stopped to consider being bored. Despite all this, combat is pretty challenging. Dodge timings are pretty tight and it doesn't help I have subpar reaction times. It usually takes a few rounds of attempts to download the bosses attack timings before you realize "wow this boss is easy". All the 7 main bosses feel simple once you get the hang of it, it's just a matter of execution.

I stated that you "wait wait wait" before dodge then attack and I meant it. You really just stand fucking still until the boss starts their attack animation and time your dodge and counterattack. Because you can't get away with being offensive at all. Either enemies won't stagger or they'll completely block your attacks. Still, it's something of a challenge in a 1v1 but when there's multiple not-pathetically-weak enemies, combat just gets frustrating. You can dodge one attack but unless you get the perfect timing and counter, you'll get hit with another enemy's attack right after. This leads to some secondary bosses being harder than the main ones because while the main ones are usually a 1v1 fight, smaller bosses could leave you outnumbered. The game offers you a way to deal with multiple enemies in the form of wrath attacks though, you just gotta not be stubbornly greedy with holding onto max charge "until I really need it". I suggest you don't have doritos and mountain dew for dinner as you play through the final act because apparently it'll leave you feeling kind of weird. 

Anyway, closing thoughts and recommendation. Do you like fun? Then I suggest you buy Darksiders 3! Are you already prepared to dislike it considering all the mixed reviews? Darksiders 3 is a surprisingly competent Souls-like. Negative or mixed reviews typically were from launch where it was a very different game. Balance, gameplay adjustments, and map adjustments now leave very little to complain about. It leans heavy on Traversal mechanics from Metroidvanias or Zelda, combined with a hack-y-slash-y form of Souls combat that finds an interesting balance focusing on mob fights and solo fights. The story is decent (it starts out a little rough and gets better as you progress) and how it slots into the Darksiders story and what it does with its characters is more compelling than you'd expect.

Having just completed an Apocalyptic campaign on Default Mode [can't cancel attack animations] as my first playthrough, I felt like the bosses were perfectly tuned -- but enemies were a little overtuned at times, often straight up 2-shotting you. Especially when you're fighting in many mob fights throughout a zone, this can get irritating. I'd likely recommend Apocalyptic on Classic Mode [can cancel attack animations].

As a final note for Souls-veterans, other games like The Surge 1+2 offer a stronger "Souls" experience (e.g., slow progression, feeling lost or trapped, very tactical gameplay, etc) but ultimately are less polished than Darksiders 3. Darksiders 3 on the other hand, is a bit more on the 'Souls-lite' side of things at times, but feels very smooth to play. The DLCs slot neatly into a new campaign and were fun to play throughout.

The game in itself is not a bad game, but the worst in the franchise. While the Darksiders series isn't known for an overly-complex plot, the games have a general theme they follow and the MC's quest makes sense in the greater scheme of things. But in DS3 you fight the Seven Deadly Sins which just exist and don't pose any immediate threat aside from the Council wanting you to kill them. The story seems even cornier than the rest of the franchise and this comes from an actual fan of the series.
In terms of gameplay the Soulsborne-inspired elements are a cool idea and addition to the theme of getting inspiration from other franchises for each game. However, I do believe they're poorly implemented. I'm going to leave the easier difficulties aside and talk about the harder ones. I'm a fan of playing difficult games and most of the times I always play at the highest one available. The general rule is that no matter how difficult a game is, it should be fair. I don't feel it to be the case here. On the higher difficulties, you either spam dodgecounter, which becomes broken and the entire games is reduced to a 1-button gimmick, or you don't and die mostly instantly. This leads to an unbalanced experience.
The biggest problem the game faces, however, is related to its performance. Darksiders II had a ton of bugs and performance issues related to the lack of time and financing caused by THQ's bankruptcy. But Darksiders III was released in 2018 by a new subsidiary that should've fixed said issues. This did not happen and the game runs horribly, with an unacceptable amount of stuttering and loading, framedrops, audio issues, crashes, resolution problems etc. A game priced at 60 Euros has no right to present itself with that kind of problems.
Overall the game is the worst in the franchise but still decent enough at its core. The performance issues, however, drop its value significantly and I could barely recommend it even during discount season.

This is a review from a Dark Souls fan who 100% the game in 2021 in COMBAT MODE: CLASSIC and APOCALYPTIC DIFFICULTY. I clarify this because the game I played is quite different from what it was at launch.

Combat Mode: Classic is the developers' (late) fix to a TERRIBLE, TERRIBLE combat design flaw in this game: NO ANIMATION CANCELLING. 

Why is this bad? - you might ask. Well, no animation cancelling means you 100% commit to your attacks: once you swing your weapon, you can't do anything else until that animation has ended. This works perfectly fine in 1 vs 1 scenarios, like in Monster Hunter: World, but is ABSOLUTELY FRUSTRATING in 1 vs many scenarios, like in Dark Souls or Darksiders 3. If you want to know more about why is it so bad, a perfect example is SkillUp's review for Godfall (you can check that on youtube).

Well, this mess was fixed in Combat Mode: Classic. Now there's animation cancelling and combat is smooth, as it should've been from the start.

Now, with the actual review. I played it on an AMD Radeon R9 290, 16 GB RAM and AMD FX(tm)-8350 Eight-Core Processor @ 1440p. I enjoyed stable 50-60 fps with settings at medium / high. The only flaw I found was a weird flickering white screen issue that I solved by cranking up antialiasing to max. I still see some white flickering textures sometimes, but it's barely noticeable.

The game looks gorgeous. The music is pretty decent. Most importantly, the story is interesting and makes sense. The voiceacting is on point. 
The combat (again, in classic mode!)  is smooth and challenging, and takes many ideas from the Dark Souls games. There's a DLC Boss designed to oneshot you with several moves, but still didn't feel cheap or poorly thought. For me, this is something amazing to achieve.
There's enough variety in enemy design and weapon design to not feel boring, even after my almost 40h campaign.
The puzzles are okay: not too easy, not too frustrating. 
Exploration feels rewarding, and there's a LOT of loot to be had if you decide to stray away of the main path, including optional bosses.

As a side note, I am not a fan of the Darksiders franchise. I really, really tried to give Darksiders 1 a chance, but it was only a painful experience (in 2019 or so). So I haven't completed any other Darksiders game besides this one.

Overall, this is a solid game. If you manage to buy it on sale, you won't regret your purchase.

94431865.review:
I have a love/hate relationship with this game, at several points I've wanted to drop it, but maybe because I'm stubborn or just a fan for the franchise I've been pushing through.
It does so much right and at times it can be fun, but more often than not it's a frustrating slog.

If you love Darksiders buy this game on sale and play it on one of the lower difficulties so you don't have to engage with the messy combat system that borrows all the worst elements from Darksouls without the polish or compensating mechanics (although some people seem to love the combat it...).
If you don't love Darksiders then you're money is probably best spent elsewhere, if you're a fan of dodge-and-win gameplay maybe this is for you.
So this is a very weak recommendation with a lot of caveats...

Now for the details:

The story of Darksiders 3 isn't amazing, and DS3 is set parallel to DS1 the same as DS2 so the story isn't being progressed at all, so not continuing that 'to be continued' ending of DS1. The story is centred around the horseman Strife and her character journey to be less angry (oh and setting up a bunch of plot elements for future games... which may never happen).
The graphics are pretty decent, environments are really nice, the music is pretty good (series has always had a good soundtrack), and the voice acting isn't too bad. Sad that the actual gameplay is a let down.
On higher difficulties (where you're forced to engage with the combat mechanics) you'll find most encounters to be annoying, with poor telegraphed attacks (usually the mobs, bosses tend to be better at telegraphing although there timing can be a bit messy), attacks are often wider than your dodge range (so you better get those perfect dodges in), and enemies that attack you from off-screen (in general fighting more than 1 enemy in this game is a pain even with off-screen attack indicators). Combat does get (a lot) better as you unlock additional items such as a range weapon so you can lure enemies to you (or play a game of find the exploit), and you even get an item to increase iframes and health regen, but these only come half-way through the game. So a big chunk of the first portion of the game is a slog, they've changed how checkpoints work so you respawn at this games version of a bonfire and all the enemies you killed will respawn... so I hope you like the feeling of having your time wasted.
In fact the checkpoint change was probably the biggest issue, since I can overlook occasionally bad combat, and the cheap deaths, but when you suffer a cheap death (say your dodge didn't go through correctly or you're surrounded and dodge one attack only to be hit by another and that kills you, or you've just met a new enemy type which has a couple of one shot kill abilities that you couldn't know about ) the worst part is the game punishing you for dying in those cases.This builds more frustration and satisfaction with each death.

The game has a simple level and attribute system, this works decently well on lower difficulties where you can adapt to your play style, but the developers approach to high difficulty was to increase enemy health-pools and attack damage (so the laziest way possible), so you're more or less forced into a glass cannon build (spending points into health is meaningless if you're still getting killed in 4 hits instead of 3), which just means the issues with dodging become increasingly apparent.
The developers have attempted to patch some of the worst parts of the combat, so now your dodge can interrupt your attack animation but even with this the combat feels off probably due to hit boxes being too large, some enemies requiring a perfect dodge, attacks tracking your dodge and chained attacks still hitting you.
There's difficult and rewarding, where the mantra of 'git gud' is spouted a lot and each death feels like a screw up on your part (something to improve), and there is difficult and frustrating because death was unavoidable because the mechanics weren't polished enough. Sometimes the game is in the former, more often than not the game is in the later.

Oh and the puzzles that the Darksiders series was known for? Well they've pretty much removed all of that so you have more time to... engage with the combat. There are a few, but they're not particularly deep of complicated, and only appear later in the game when you've unlocked more puzzle-y abilities. It's a bit sad really, the first game was basically a puzzle game with some combat, the second one has some drawn out and tediously samey puzzles but had more combat, and this one had most combat but not a lot of puzzles for variety.

If you know anything about the development backstory you'll known Darksiders 3 had a rocky history, and although I should be luck as a fan of the franchise that there even if a 3rd game I'm just sad that it's not an evolution of the Darksiders series (in terms of mechanics and gameplay) but just them copying some mechanics from other games and pasting them over without the needed polish (always a risk when you decide to go in a different direction with an established franchise). If there is a 4th game maybe they can try and polish the combat up, and really make it shine more (and do away with the dark souls bonfire and give us proper checkpoints again).
I don't think we'll see a Darksiders 4, sadly... Darksiders 3 is certainly far from the game that killed the franchise, but it wasn't the game to save it either.

I've beaten this game twice before, but I always fail to do it on Apocalyptic. That's because, even though I really love the story, and I love the challenge presented...I just can't get over the enemies re-spawning when I die.

It looks like they took a page from Dark Souls, well THQNORDIC, put that page back. I Feel this game, as compared to the last two, lacked a great deal of refinement.

If that where the worst part, my review wouldn't be so long. I only recommend this game to those in need of a good story, and just want to hurt things with a sword whip.

You get, a Hammer, a Whip, a Halbred, and nunchakus. I'm not going to complain, but I would have liked to use the hammer with fire, or the nunchakus with lightening. The fact they had to be tied to a specific element just limited their uses for me. I whipped things 90% of the time. 

Darksiders 1: Gauntlets, Scythe, Bigazz sword, shuriken, Hand-gun, a magic horn, the "get over here" chai. Your combos where locked up and you had to train (buy) them. So progression felt better just based off this fact alone.

Let's compare that to Darksiders II real fast, where you get...Dual Scythes, Hammers, Maces, Spears, A gun, a talent tree with like, 6-8 different abilities that can be upgraded...there is a wiki page that is quite long on the list of weapons. I mean, it was awesome. I felt I had even more freedom than Darksiders 1 to play to my style. Your combos again where locked and you had to buy them with a new currency "gilt". That was still fine, it was even more improved because you could typically buy all of them less than a quarter into the game.You also had side quests, and a place to see that information/track it.

Darksiders III...you get 6 weapons, each can have 1 unique ability that can be equipped...you can upgrade both abilities and weapons but it doesn't present anything new...just stat increase. Unique/legendary weapons where removed, maps removed, fast travel removed, horse removed, talent tree removed, quest log removed, side-quests depreciated, leveling system is payment based, all combos are unlocked from the begining (making it real hard to get used to using the right combo at the right time). Blocking has now totally been removed, your character flinches at everything, every enemy has immunity to flinch on a specific move set, instead of only SOME of the enemies having immunity to flinch. 

Bosses where rushed, 1 dimensional, boring as hell and often left me thinking "is there another method? Is there something I am missing?" Well, there is sometimes, but it's so subtle and you are given exactly 0 clues about it, in most cases trying to do it on harder difficulties just results in death.

 As I mentioned. Major step back...they took the map, fast travel is now Darksiders 1 style again...Just what the hell happened? I would recommend this game only for the story, don't play it for the game-play. Just shift to easy and coast through. 

Progression feels like progression only when you gain something from it. If you are constantly just gaining numbers, while the enemies are gaining the same numbers (if not more frequently on the harder difficulties) the game is not "fun". It becomes a task with no surprises. The first playthrough I remembered thinking, "ok, got nunchucks with fire, and a spear with lightening, wonder how many elements i collect in this? will there be an ice bow? or perhaps a water lance?"

No...you get a slow ass gravity hammer that is unusable on harder difficulties without the timing and attention span of the big G himself.

Anyways, great story...but what happened guys? Did you blow the budget on graphics? I feel like buying this game on release was a lot like buying a puppy with parvo.

Should I bother with Darksiders Genesis? When will Darksiders IV come out? Will you correct those mistakes made in III?

Anyways, my two cents, hopefully THQNORDIC finds it useful, I enjoy what you guys do, take care.

93317506.review:
The best way I can summarize this game as a whole is that it has great concepts that are ALL poorly executed. I love the first two darksiders games but this one isn't worth your time no matter if you're a fan of the series or not. I first played this on my ps4 and hated it due to the performance issues, and so I tried it again on steam when it was on a deep sale. 

So where to begin? First, the camera. Since this game is trying to be a souls-like, it makes sense that the camera would be zoomed out enough so that you can react to whats happening around you. Not in this game however. Instead, if you lock onto an enemy not only is it near impossible to see what your other enemies are doing, but it's also difficult to see what the enemy that you are locked is doing as well because the camera likes to stay directly behind Fury, your character, instead of being above your character like in the soulsborne games (or zoom out the camera even more, like it did in Darksiders 2). And this problem gets even worse in areas with tight corridors.

This game's combat is worse than the previous two titles. The first problem with the combat is Fury's defensive capabilities. She has none. All she has is a dodge that has too long of a recovery time to be of any use unless you're either using it for perfect dodging, allowing you to retaliate with a powerful attack afterwards, or for fighting someone one on one.  However, if there are multiple enemies in the mix then dodging while locking on is a bad idea because you could be dodging into another enemies' attack. In that case you might think that it's best to not lock on and instead dodge (or rather dash) away from the enemies for breathing room, except Fury's dash doesn't travel far enough to be of any use and on top that it takes too long for her to recover from each dash, meaning the enemies are going to put in some cheap hits. War in the first game has a dash that is just as terrible as Fury's, but to compensate he was able to block attacks. In the second game Death was able to roll three times in quick succession, with his third dodge having a long recovery time to prevent players from spamming the dodge button. Strife in Genesis has two guns and he can set up traps. The game tries to be an action game like the rest of the series, but the souls-like mechanics don't compliment the combat in any way and instead clashes with it.

This game also has some miscellaneous issues as well. For one, during your second encounter with Wrath, his first phase is not fun in the slightest because the only challenging gimmick to it is that he constantly runs away to heal himself by killing angels and demons that re fighting each other, in other words you have to out dps his healing, which even though I'm lvl 40 and almost have my whip and secondary weapon fully upgraded, I still can't damage him enough in time. There were also instances where some objects (not a lot though) had missing textures and I had enemies get stuck on terrain. 

Lastly, The Scar. FUCK. THE. SCAR. If you want a prime example of poor level design, look no further than the scar. It has enemies that spawn multiple enemies when you fight them, (and I've already rambled on why fighting multiple enemies at once is terrible), bullshit enemy placements such as ranged demons from multiple platforms away attacking while you're busy attacking other enemies who are in your way (and dashing away isn't going to save you), and puzzles that are either unclear ( how was I supposed to know that the tornado is unable to lift a heavy block if it's frozen ) or require you wait a few moments othrrwise the puzzle won't work ( again that freaking tornado ). 

The only praise I can give this game are the seven sins themselves. Their designs (as far as I'm aware) are clever and unique. Sloth is a big, fat bug that lets his drones do all the work for him; Pride looks like an angel and acts like she's better than anyone ( she even refuses to fight you unless you prove you're a worthy opponent by killing the other sins ) even though she wears a mask that hides an imperfect face underneath; And Lust is no longer a depiction of sexual lust but rather all forms of lust ( a lust for glory and a lust for power being great examples ) and wears awesome looking armor. As I said, the design for the seven sins are great. It's just a shame the rest of the game isn't all that great.

In short, even if you are a fan of the series, save your money, time, and sanity by giving this game a pass. This is my first time writing a review this long, so I'm sorry if it's somewhat of a mess, but as a fan of the series I needed to get this off my chest. 93113313.review:
Never played the previous Darksiders, so just coming at this as a person completely new to the series in 2021 I'm really having a lot of fun. It is basically a Devil May Cry / metroidvania game with some Dark Souls mechanics (not difficulty). 

Less of a button masher than DMC and a lot more forgiving than DS, it's a nearly perfectly well balanced action game as far as difficulty goes. You are kind of a glass cannon that can dole out crazy damage and combos but you can get stomped very easily if you are not careful. The exploration is also top notch. Using new powers and techniques to revisit old levels and unlock huge new areas is a treat. The boss battles are great, and the game runs smooth. 

The graphics are serviceable, it definitely feels like an older game even though it's relatively new. The effects are good, the art is crisp, animations are smooth but it does lack detail and some textures are really muddy and the lip syncing is pretty old school. 

I really like the character you play as, but she can be off putting. You are basically playing as Xena with super powers. Voice acting is good, story is serviceable and has some cool things going on keeping you intrigued as to what is going to happen next.

Speaking of which, I have only unlocked two of the multiple forms, and they offer different play styles. I soon found that having multiple tools at your disposal wasn't just helpful for traversal, but you can spec the different weapons with upgrades for different jobs. For instance, I configured my whip to reap more currency from destroying the environment since it has a crazy long reach, you can trash a room quick for a bunch of extra $. Daggers I have poured a bunch of money and upgrades into to make them my burst damage weapon of choice for 1v1, while the other weapon (forget the name) is spec'd to generate fury so I basically kill small mobs with that, go to daggers for big guys and have a steady stream of fury attacks. Each weapon has a special fury attack that needs to be charged up first but can unleash devestation and can really get you out of some sticky situations. 

There are different armors available, but they are few and far between, I wish there was a bit more in that regards. 

The biggest complaint is targeting enemies. The camera angle it puts you in when you target an enemy is horrible especially when facing off with multiple enemies and leads to you getting hit in the back or from off screen a lot, HOWEVER, with a mouse/keyboard I am able to play without targeting at all very easily and the issues with getting hit from behind disappear as you can easily view your surroundings when not in the targeted camera lock. If you have trouble with getting hit from off screen I would strongly suggest giving mouse/keyboard a shot. 

Some complaints about the game are just untrue. I saw a review from IGN stating that if you level up you never turn into a badass and can constantly get creamed and have nothing to show for your work (like skyrim or something where all the creatures level up) this isn't really the case by what I can tell. Enemies in different areas will be higher or lesser level and it IS possible to get to places you aren't really meant to be yet if you are good at exploring (though they do a decent job locking big difficulty spikes behind powers you have to obtain first when you are a bit more powerful). In the metroidvania style, once you have some new tools under your belt you are supposed to go back to previously traversed maps and do some exploring. I can tell you the enemies there have not leveled up with you and you do end up feeling like a shredder. Some enemies that caused me a hard time I came back to and just obliterated them no problem. 

This game doesn't do anything new or innovative in any way, but it is a well balance game with combat that can be best described as 'difficult but fair'. I'm probably half-way through the adventure and having a blast with it though and will certainly be playing it to its conclusion and quite possibly explore whatever DLC it has to offer. Highly recommended if it goes on sale.

92036813.review:
Hell hath no fury, like a woman scorned... or so they say.

Darksiders 3 is the fourth instalment in the Darksiders franchise and explores the story of Fury, one of the four horseman of the apocalypse. Does it live up to the hype? Is it a satisfying pay off to the long wait? Hard to say really.

Taking a turn from the previous games hack and slash/rpg models, DS3 takes a Souls like approach to the series, with a revamped combat system, overhauled world design, and a stronger rpg focus on stat builds over its predecessors.

Pro's:
- Highly satisfying combat mechanics that actually feel like they pack a punch, far more satisfactory than any of the Souls series for that matter. 
- Excellently themed score with a great mix of the divine, dark, and the chaotic elements of the balance of the war of the ages. 
- Large spanning map with loops and bends that all link up quite effectively. 
- Unlocking new core skill sets feels akin to the Ocarina of Time days, opening new opportunities to explore and attack enemies.
- Large variety of weapons and attack animations, from massive hammers to darting claws. 
- Vastly improved art style over the older games, makes for not only a more modern look, but still the timeless design it always was.
- Relatively well written story that connects neatly into the original title, without too many holes, and a greater mystery hinted at to fuel your curiosity. 
- Relatively good puzzle mechanics that won't seriously halt you in your tracks, but some will require a bit more of a think. 

Cons:
- Fury as a character feels poorly portayed. Fury doesn't equal rage. She's much too hot headed and the voice actor doesn't feel the strongest for conveying that emotion.
- Lack of a map means no real ability to gain bearings. This is an odd step away from the traditional game designs. 
- Sometimes, very unclear mechanic explanations with little-to-no hints about them. 
- No currency scaling and hence, no reason to grind the late game areas for loot. You're better off killing the opening area mobs as they net the same reward. 
- Abundance of resources that overall seemed a tad pointless. I cleared the game only ever using a couple strength shards and heals. 
- Left/right directional quick inventory system rather than a scroll wheel or other form, more of a pet peeve really.
- MASSIVE Save game glitch that reverts potentially hours of progress and happens at random, no known fix and no fix in sight from THQ. I myself lost at least one sit session of progress.
- At times, very unfair enemy attack chain capabilities against your lack of ability to stagger. Massive hits on small mobs sometimes barely phase them, but you can be stun locked.
- What feels like a lack of voice actors, same voice for numerous npc's.
- Pet peeve: no consistency in character sizing in regards to humans. War absolutely towered over humans in the first game, now he's the same size. Why?

Story: Certainly not bad, but not as satisfying as the previous games. Most characters are voiced well and the plot is clearly drawn out for you. Only complaint is most of the characters of the Seven Deadly (the main bosses of the game) feel more comically designed rather than kind of biblically. Greed feels very much out of place in the universe, same for Sloth, Gluttony, and perhaps Envy. We get to see an array of familiar faces again, including all of the horseman, Ulthane, and everyones favourite, Vulgrim. Adds some new characters along the way, but they feel a little lacking compared to the mains. As for Fury, she is far too short tempered and this damages her character presentation I think. Her bark is far worse than her bite it feels as she is constantly mocked, ridiculed and jeered at for being the weakest link of the Four. Though she might prove triumphant in the end, I feel like she's only really just scraping by, and not growing as she really should. She may be Fury, but that shouldn't render her uncompromising.

Gameplay: Arguably the most divisive aspect of the game. Trading hack and slash for a Souls-like experience was granted to stir a ruckus. Honestly, I didn't mind this. You can opt to play with a more traditional combat design, but the game was purely designed for the new experience. Fury never really feels underpowered, but she certainly never feels as powerful as she should be. Travel outside of serpent holes is slow and tedious, but at least serpent holes are no longer an area to explore in their own right. Puzzles aren't anything too fancy, but those present in the area The Scar are a little drawn out and the area generally feels overly designed. Much more twisty and turny than the others. 

Graphics: Not much to say. Sharper, more vibrant, and a much nicer lighting system over the previous games. Far more detailed than the previous games, and will age better. 

Sound: Gorgeous sound design. Everything feels adequately representative of what you see on screen, from the low hum and fizzle of waxing lights, to the grind of monolothic stones, to the slosh of swampy and murky waters, to the crack and crunch of soil beneath your feet. The music is a great accompaniment when it plays and the main menu theme feels foreboding yet empowering. 

Overall Verdict:
Though a divisive entry into the series, it's certainly not unwelcome. A slower, more careful approach is required here as you delve into the beginning of humanities doom, and the all time conflict between heaven and hell. As someone who has been a fan of the series since its conception I do recommend this game for continuity, at a price of course, a bargain, a devilishly one at that. Not an amazing, stand out experience, but nothing that you'll shovel under trying to forget about.

7/10.

[h1]Don't let yourself be fooled by the steam store page![/h1] 
This game seems like a generic hack'n'slay at first but in reality it is a metroidvania combined with souls like features and a hack'n'slay combat system.
[b]That being said I think if you like two of the three mentioned genres you will probably enjoy this game.[/b]

[b]all in all this is a very good game[/b]
However there are a few things that could be improved in order to make darksiders 4 one of the best videogames ever.

[h1]Exploration[/h1]
My strongest criticism is that there is NO MAP. I think a map plays a crucial part in any Metroidvania in order to keep track of the rooms you have already cleared and to make the backtrack more enjoyable. And believe me there is a LOT of backtrack. The levels itselfs are very well designed and convoluted. Its cool to unlock a new shortcut or to come back to a previously locked area hours later and remember when you visited it first time. However because of the lack of a map I did not know where to go two or three times after defeating a boss.
There is a little compass on your HUD but to be honest I did not feel like it was much of a use.
[b]remove the compass, give the player a proper map and the game will improve a lot![/b]

[h1]Puzzles and abilities[/h1]
While this game starts as a simple fighting game you will find yourself solving more and more puzzles as the game progresses. They have done a good job balancing the amount of fights and puzzles. You are given 4 different forms each with an unique ability, while they do not really differ in fight they still provide unique feelings and are important to solve different tasks.
[b]Nevertheless I feel the combat would improve a lot if the enemys actually had strength and weaknesses[/b]
Right now you will just skill one weapon and always use it to fight. Imagine having to adapt to every enemy even during combat and always change forms, it would add a whole new level of depths to the game.
Another criticism regarding the different forms is: It is kinda wasted to not give your default form any ability, once you get your first special appearance you will never again use the default style.
[b]I think they should have given the default style an ability too[/b] furthermore it is a questionable decision to give your Hero a purple color scheme and at the same time to make one of your special appearence purple too, it just felt out of place.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
As already mentiond you should not expect too much from the combat system. It still is a hack'n'slay, that means you are given two different buttons to smash plus a dodge. 91732426.review:
My Darksiders 2 review ended with the prediction that there will never be a Darksiders 3-- now, here we are. At the time, THQ declared bankruptcy; all of their IP's and studios were bought up minus Vigil and Darksiders. With no owner, the IP was under threat of becoming abandonware. Then came Nordic Games to purchase the IP. Purchasing the THQ license as well, they would become THQ Nordic and a few years later we get this.

	DS3 flows seamlessly from DS2 in a way that sequels developed by different studios typically don't. Gunfire Games is behind this one, and what percentage of the staff are remnants from DS2 and 1 I do not know. What I do know is that it feels like coming back to familiar territory here. As with every new game in the franchise, there's an attempt at introducing new ideas by parroting game tropes from other genres or franchises of the time. Darksiders 2 added elements of loot-based games and Prince of Persia. Darskdiers 3 mimicks Dark Souls.

	A much, much easier Dark Souls. A lot is made of how 'hard' this game is, but it was either updated when I actually played it or a large swath of people are just bad at video games. Unlike Dark Souls, there are frequent shortcuts you unlock in levels that allow you to more quickly reach your objective. Meaning that when you die, it's not a huge loss since you just opened a gate that allows you to skip all the work you did. And these shortcuts are plentiful: you will never die and feel like you lost a world of progress like you would in Dark Souls. 

	Even the penalty for dying isn't as harsh as in DS. In Dark Souls, you have to make it back to the point of death to recover any currency lost due to dying. In Darksiders, it's much the same, only that failing to recover it and dying again doesn't permanently lose your gains. In essence, there is no penalty for dying other than a respawn. You can even partially put in what you have towards your next level increase, rather than carry around all that currency. 

	The 'Metroidvania' aspects are there, but never to the degree of the Souls series. For the most part, this is a linear game that keeps you on track for the majority of the time. It's never designed in such a way that you are either lost or just exploring for the sake of it. As in the Metroid series, you unlock new abilities that allow you to go to previously inaccesible areas, but there really aren't a lot of optional sections here besides the odd cliff here or the small room there. There are a few shortcuts between areas, and some optional loot (that you can otherwise buy) which require abilities. It's the most straightforward 'Metroidvania' experience, with abilities used to block off areas and bosses so you play the game in the intended manner.

	The combat is what puts some people off. The 'problem' is that enemies do a shitload of damage and aren't staggered off their attack animations. So you can't just mash incessantly and barrage them with so many hits that they either die or are in their 'I'm being hit' animations. You actually have to watch their attacks. Which is fine, since dodging in time gives you a powerful counter-attack. But the camera gets in the way at times since it never zooms out to give you a larger perspective of the battlefield. So you'll get hit from the back or side by one of the 7 enemies attacking you. It's a situation where it can be annoying, especially at first. But as the game progresses it gets easier, since the nature of Fury's attacks are large, sweeping blows all around her with her whip. With increasing attack strength, the minions around you die quicker so you can focus on the 2 or 3 actual threats.  Increasing FOV also massively helps.
	
	The majority of negative reviews take issue with the combat, but it's legitimately the same as before. Each weapon does not carry any fewer moves than in any other game in the franchise. The layout for combos is very much the same. And unlike Dark Souls, you can cancel every move almost instantaneously into the dash. The only legitimate complaints, in my eyes, are that the camera doesn't do you any favors in fights. Otherwise, even the addition of a 'classic' mode for the combat is pointless since it doesn't actually change the combat in any discernable manner.

	Is Darksiders on par with 1 and 2? No, but in my case it's because it lacks the lore and secondary characters that the first two games had. Perhaps the developers wanted as few cutscenes and story sequences as possible in an effort to mimic the quiet and solitary nature of Dark Souls. Whatever the case, I also feel that the game world is small and linear, so it doesn't take advantage of the Metroidvania style of game. But these grievances don't destroy the game for me, and the mega negative reviews are wild. DS3 continues the franchise with a level of quality that keeps on par with previous games. We're just lacking an exclusively Strife centered game to wrap up the horsemen.

89273994.review:
The short version: 8/10 Loved the characters and story, combat requires practice to get used to which may turn off casual players and the lack of map is mildly annoying.

The long version: I really enjoyed the game. Fury is a badass with legitimate character development from the start of the game to the end. The story itself is interesting and well-written, not amazingly deep but appropriate for the series and style of game. Graphics are gorgeous and the art style fits the rest of the series. The different hollows are a fun concept and definitely make gameplay a little more engaging. I do wish the game included a map. I personally didn't have too much trouble following the objective markers but being able to at least look at a full map of the game world would be helpful. The combat is really the only other place I have complaints. The biggest issue is the controls can feel a little sluggish at times, especially when using healing items which leads to extra deaths. The camera can also be an enemy in and of itself, but that's common with pretty much any action game. The combat itself is not overly difficult once you get your dodge timing down, but it leaves a bit to be desired. Basically, combat is 80% dodge-countering, 20% mashing X/Y. If you're coming from Nioh/DMC/Bayonetta/etc. that require more advanced strategies and/or memorizing movesets you may be a little disappointed in the simplified combat here. On the other hand, it's also very different from the combat in the previous Darksiders games so if you're expecting to just button mash your way through every enemy like a god among insects you will definitely be disappointed. I don't believe it's a particularly bad combat system, it's just not what fans of the previous games were expecting and I think that's why it gets so much hate. It sort of feels like the devs played Dark Souls and then said "that's cool, let's do that but make it easier so people don't rage quit (as much)" and this is the end result. Not bad for creating a hybrid between two very different combat styles, but also not really like either of the original styles at this point so it can be frustrating to get used to but it's pretty satisfying once you do. Overall, this was a very good game that was a lot of fun to play (as long as you git gud at dodging) and fit into the ongoing story and setting of the previous entries in the series quite well, definitely worth picking up.

87984910.review:
Having seen the horsemen War and Death’s stories in the first two entries in the series, Fury is given centre stage in Darksiders 3 in a story that takes places before the events of the first game.

Visually Darksiders 3 will look familiar to veterans of the series and does a good job of replicating the slightly cartoonish/drawn style of the original games, whilst bringing it up to a modern standard. The environments are varied and range from overgrown ruined cities to dilapidated underground stations and volcanic caves, each with their own distinct character. There are also a broad variety of enemy types unique to these different areas as well as a number of challenging bosses.

The gameplay is a big departure from the original games however. While the first two were structured similarly to traditional Zelda games, the third is much more of a souls-like. Gone are the open worlds, complex dungeons and puzzles of the first two, which are replaced by a more linear world with shortcuts that enable backtracking. Side quests are also gone and a world map is also absent. The shady demonic merchant Vulgrim returns however as a fast travel/bonfire mechanic and means of cashing in souls to level Fury up. The combat system has been simplified and revolves around dodging and counterattacking and the challenging difficulty will result in frequent returns to the location of your last death to collect your belongings, much like in Dark Souls.

All in all Darksiders 3 is a reasonable souls-like, but the changes to the gameplay, lack of an open world and general dumbing down is likely to leave fans of the originals disappointed.

86758547.review:
Note: I played this on "Classic" gameplay style. I personally recommend classic over default, mostly due to the fact that I prefer the combat style of the previous games and the default style is close but juuuust slow enough that it can feel a little clunky since the difference is like .25 seconds of extra time before you can evade/heal. Also I would not suggest playing this on anything above challenging, At the bottom I mention a list of annoyances that together make anything harder than challenging not sound like a fun experience. Plus this game is way harder than every other DS game so even normal is fine if you want an experience closer to the previous games.

Darksiders as a series loves changed, and this iteration boasts some of the most drastic changes of the series. Gone is the more open and zelda-esque (for the most part) structure as this game embraces a much more narrow dark souls approach. In darksiders 3 you're largely going along a straight forward path to your destination with the ability to diverge and explore every not and then but overall is a VERY funneled experience. 

Levels don't feature that many puzzles and the puzzles that are there aren't super complex. It's only until the final area where puzzles become much more unique, interesting, and common as you have all the puzzle items and they want to really put them to the test. It's actually some of the most unique puzzling in the darksiders series, which is unfortunate given how little of a presence it has. But this might be due to the fact that this game allows you to do a few of the bosses out of order.

But, their shift of focus from sprawling open maps and large scale puzzle dungeons let them craft some very interesting levels. While it's largely a straight line, every part of the level is laid out well enough that you are constantly opening up shortcuts for yourself in a fairly believable manner. In some cases the difference between a level on your first time walking in and when you're finished can be so drastic you pretty much ignore 70% of the level you just played because its all so interconnected and/or you got a power to help bridge a gap that you previously were walking around. Not only that but the levels in general just flow from one to the other really well. This game is essentially just a giant circle where it steers you in the right way forward constantly outside of little side places for items and collectibles.

As I mentioned, this game lets you do some sequence breaking. To my understanding you only really need to kill the first major boss then you can just leave the area and explore the other half of the world. The 2nd power is only to access bonuses along the way. If you complete those sections of the world and get the "third" and "forth" power, you can basically skip straight to 2 bosses that you skipped because the game connects with itself in a really cool way to allow that. But of course you don't get much out of it besides shortening the game for yourself. it's just cool to see a game with a narrow focus like that be so interwoven like that.

Last good  thing i'll talk about is the story. It's surpsingly good for a darksiders story. Generally darksiders stories have cool setpieces, ideas, or implications for this grand plot they are trying to tell. 3 on the other hand has a much more personal story to the character and one that actually shows the protagonist noticeably change in satisfying ways as you go through even if a few elements here and there don't entirely hit home. Now it's not anything amazing or deep, in fact it's symbolism is pretty in your face. But it's a much more interesting and engaging story nonetheless and cemented Fury as my 2nd favorite horseman. Strife in genesis is too good to ignore.

With all that out of the way it did have some annoyances. Nothing that personally stopped my enjoyment that much but stuff that still bothered me a little bit. Occasional clunky controls like the whip swinging detection, some puzzles are actively not fun as they can involve instant death or clunky timing, some areas which should trigger a "fell off the ledge teleport back up" is actually fatal, in one area it will put your lost souls in an unreachable position, some bosses had less than fun mechanics and some of them attack immediately out of a cutscene, the final boss has an attack which creates an entity that can steal your lock-on focus when it should be untargetable, same boss by sheer bad luck can stun lock you, and for no reason at all you are locked out of any optional bosses if you fight the 2nd to last boss despite letting you freely explore the world again before the final boss. It tells you of this before you go, but there's just no good story reason this happens and I didn't realize I was missing an optional boss until after I beat the game. Also pray you have an SSD when you do the final boss because you're required to sit through a loading screen just to enter the fight every. single. time.

Probably the biggest issue of all is occasional unfair nonsense, most notably these insect eggs/cocoons in one are which litter the entire level, but only some of them will break open to attack you instantly. You pretty much have to learn which ones break and then get used to the range where they shatter to attack you. It sucks and even on challenging it's more damage that I want to constantly take.

Overall, very fun game from the standpoint of someone who really likes darksiders. It scratches a lot of my darksiders itches while advancing the story to its hopeful conclusion while also offering another different experience like what 1 was to 2 and what genesis was to the rest of the series.
