I love the Darksiders universe and story concept. Some elements may be a bit predictable and it's by no means a perfect game, but it's still one of the better ones out there IMO. There are difficulty settings for everyone's liking too.

Pros:
- Great storyline and game concept
- Much more character development than you'd see in some other modern games. Protagonist is badass.
- Lots of areas to explore. Personally I really enjoyed the fiery pits (The Hollows), felt a bit like a part of Hell).
- New types of enemies and frequent boss fights throughout the game ensure that it doesn't become boring
- Provides a tough gameplay experience for those who want a challenge, but there is an easy mode for those who don't.

Cons:
- The save system is pretty brutal. When you die, you'll be teleported back to the last Vulgrim location you visited (NPC vendor). The Lurchers (currency) that you've collected will be dropped where you die, or close to that location and you'll have to get them back. Any unlocked puzzles, opened doors etc. will not reset though so that's something at least.
- Even in the medium difficulty modes, the game is quite challenging because you can die quite easily and don't deal that much damage. Not as hard as Dark Souls games but still challenging. Mastering the dodge-counter maneuvers really helps, especially once you put some points into Arcane damage.
- Initially I disliked the lack of a map. It would be complicated because the environment is quite 3D so buildings and dungeons on multiple levels would be a pain to map out and navigate, but anything would be better than nothing. However, once you get to know the map a bit and you learn to use the compass, it's not that much of an issue. A horse would have been welcome though for faster riding through some areas.
- The upgrading system for your weapons is a bit of a pain. You need to collect specific items, but you won't find enough to upgrade everything to the highest level unless you grind them out in pointless killing of respawning trash mobs.
- I wish that there was more motivation to use the different kinds of weapons. I finished most fights with just the main whip and the Fire Hollow active, but almost never used any of the others. If they were not needed to navigate and solve puzzles, I wouldn't have touched them at all.

All in all, still a great game - don't let people tell you it's a terrible game because if you give it an honest chance, I think you may like it. As I said, it's not perfect, and I have a few frustrated moments too, but it's still absolutely worth it IMO.

I played the first two games years ago, and naturally I have forgotten quite a lot. But Darksiders 3 brought back my memories of that apocalyptic world. I want to thank the developers for recreating the same mood. It feels good to be back and to see the recognizable art style.

Story-wise it's a proper addition to the existing universe. Fury has her own mission, but we will meet some familiar characters in the meantime. The story and its twists, the characters and enemies, the voice acting and the soundtrack - everything is done on a very good level.  Fury herself is awesome on her own: her character is evolving throughout the game, but she is awesome in the beginning, and she is still awesome in the end, but in a completely different way.

Gameplay-wise this game is now closer to a souls-like. I think this change is justified by the fact that Fury is the weakest among Horsemen, so it's natural that her fighting style heavily relies on dodges and that she can be defeated in just a few hits. I played my first time on Apocalyptic difficulty, and I died quite a lot, especially on bosses. However, after leveling up enough and upgrading my weapons I became a bit overpowered, so the last 2 or 3 bosses were defeated on first or second try.

Even though I liked the game in general, some moments were not that good. Blocking enemies are annoying. Your whip is long, yet it usually hits only one or sometimes two enemies in a crowd, and you don't have any means of crowd-control. 85008998.review:
For fans of Darksiders and D2, this game alters a few things and while its still a decent game theres some things that may put off fans of the series- myself included. So this review is "Recommended but with caution". 

The good:
+Good story and character development- provided you play the whole way though. 
+The devs adding "classic" mode to make the combat more like Darksiders I and II is a HUGE and welcome addition. They also added "checkpoints" which save any puzzle progress youve made so if you die you wont have to repeat them again. 
+Extra weapons and upgrades are all back again, and the menu interface is mostly the same (even the font) so it's easy to navigate these. 
+No crashes, glitches or bugs. 

The bad:
-No map. Some reasons a dev actually said about this is, “We didn’t think players like them,” and “We want players to get lost.” For a game as big as this is with its connected world, you either better remember where that certain special pile of rubble you couldnt get to before, write it down or forget about it all together. All you get is a compass with a skull showing which direction to go for the closest Seventh Sin (boss). Thats it. Not even a minimap either. Whats kinda baffling is that there IS fast travel at any Vulgrim location, but you cant actually see it on a world map. Dumb.
-In order to sprint you always have to push a button to do so. Wouldve been great if I could just hold the analog stick all the way and run like other games do instead of having to push down the left stick every. single. time.
-Many of the puzzles are really out there and some of the solutions are just dumb. The creativity of D1 and D2 puzzles are nowhere to be found here. 
-Difficulty. This game is hard, even on "Balanced" (Normal) difficulty its quite brutal. I know people have compared the combat difficulty to the likes of Dark Souls and Ive only ever dabbled in Demon's Souls on PS3 so I get the idea...But I think the biggest problem with this is that low level grunts can literally kill you in 3-4 hits. And when you die? You respawn at the nearest Vulgrim spot that you discovered. So you can be in a boss fight, die, then youll get sent back alllll the way to a Vulgrim spot in which youll have to make your way back to the boss. And this just isnt for bosses either. If you die anywhere on the map youll still get sent to the nearest Vulgrim spot and you will most likely have to spend some time making your way back to the place you died- with all enemies respawned too. And those checkpoints i mentioned earlier? Yeah, they only save puzzle progress. 
-FOV is way too close. Thankfully there is a mod in the steam forums that fixes this, but not having an FOV slider built in by default to a third person action game is just stupid. 
-The locations all have this samenyness to them. Lots of cave areas and metal crates everywhere it seems like. 
-Some people didnt have this problem, but for me a lot of the time the FPS would drop to the 40-50fps range constantly. Theres hardly any loading in game so its most likely an issue with streaming assets in but it doesnt do it very efficiently.  

So if youd made it this far in my review you may be asking yourself if its really worth buying this game because they changed so much. Well,  if youre wanting more of a D1/D2 "feel", the best advice I can give you is switch the difficulty to "Story" (easy) and the combat to Classic, which is exactly what I did. Dying really fast fighting small mobs and backtracking got old real quick, so this change definitely helped out a lot. Around hour 5 or so I switched difficulty and completed the game in about 13 hours total, (yes i enjoyed the ending, stick around after the credits too). Anyway, I really want to see how the fourth and supposedly final game in the series plays out as Im a huge fan of the first two games, so for me at least this was necessary.

84567686.review:
Really enjoyed playing this, even though I was not excited about the game from the first trailers, back I it was first announced.

Starting the game you immediately notice that it's pretty different to the first too. Some people hate the changes, but after getting used to the gameplay, I liked it better than the older style. All you need to change is swap to the Classic combat and you are good to go. 

It is called the Dark Souls of Darksiders for several reasons:

- there is no map, so you have to find your own way, but since the locations are fairly small and loop back and connect with one another in multiple paths and shortcuts, the world feels really accessible (not sure why some complain that they don't know where to go, especially when the boss location indicator changes direction at every turn showing you the direct path)

- weapon upgrades use the same system you can find in DS, with lower levels needing smaller upgrade stones and going to bigger and rarer as you get to higher levels with the option to buy the basic supplies later in the game

- combat has to stamina, but you'll need to dodge a lot, which is easy to get used to and you'll be able to execute the perfect timing dodge with counter attacks in no time (especially with Classic combat mode, were you can cancel you actions to dodge)

- your primary healing item is similar to the Estus flask, it just refills while killing enemies instead of while resting, plus you'll find upgrades for more uses (you start with only 2, but I ended the game with 6) and more healing per use, just like in DS

The art style is great, character design pretty good as well (excluding the human models, as they just don't seem to fit the setting), but for some reason the game is still not optimized, so it runs poorly even with decent specs (turning down shadows and foliage quality along with AA are the best ways to improve performance, plus setting it to Fullscreen seemed to eliminate most of the stuttering).

The game is locked at 62fps with some cutcenses locked at 30 (seems random, and in one scene a camera angle might be at 30fps, then the other change back to "unlocked" then go back to 30 again in half a minute). But you can unlock the gamplay fps in the config files, so it's not a major issue.

The story the basic but enjoyable and fits Fury's character. Voice acting is great along with sound design in general.

Played on Normal difficulty, had some minor trouble at first (was more of a training period to get used to the combat, rather than the game being too hard) and ended up OP af by the end of the game, so if you are good at DS and don't want a walk in the park, you should start the game at one of the higher difficulties.

Most of the weapons seem to be useless in combat - ended up using the default Barbs of Scorn with the occasional swing of Chains of Scorn as I was running around with the Flame Hollow from the moment I got it.

Finished the first two games twice (the original releases and then the remasters) and have to say that I enjoyed this one the most (but what do I know, I also prefer Mankind Divided to Human Revolution).

Overall I'd rate it at least 8/10.

Played at 1440p on 3900X with 1070Ti and 32GB memory and struggles to maintain stable 75fps.

84499763.review:
Enjoyable within its limits. 

Darksiders III is the equivalent of comfort food. It was very clearly made on a tight budget while still trying to honor the original Darksiders games and bring them up into the modern spotlight. Hack and slash glory is still to be found, albeit recontextualized within a From-Software framework. You have limited healing items, currency/experience that you drop when you die, scattered checkpoints that you use both for fast travel and leveling up, etc. More often than not, this merging of gameplay styles results in an enjoyable experience, but Darksiders III never really reaches the full potential of either genre. 

Combat is free in flow, with Fury definitely being the most nimble of the Horsemen we've had so far, but launching enemies into air and tackling them with differing styles and weapons never feels right. You're unable to swap weapons mid-combo, instead waiting on a full second delay in order to switch, by which time the enemy has already recovered and is making ready to strike. If the developers had allowed you to swap styles mid-combo, it would have improved the feeling of Darksiders III ten times over, and resulted in an experience that's pretty damn good for the action game genre; unfortunately, they elected to keep things difficult and "grounded" in an effort to appeal to that FromSoft inspiration. 

That decision reaps little fruit, however, as little of FromSoft's magic can be found in this game. The devs give it their honest effort, and I'm always willing to applaud that, but of the game's twelve or so boss fights, I can only think of two that I would call great. Only one is "bad," but the rest are so blase they might as well be forgotten, and I only beat the game yesterday. They rely on the same combo time and again, so once you learn how to dodge in tandem with it, you've pretty much got the fight won already. There are the rare attempts to introduce second phases, yet more often than not, the mechanics those new phases introduce are so incredibly forgiving that the impact they have on the overall encounter is next to null. 

You might wonder at this point why I'm recommending Darksiders III. I always believe it's important to highlight a product's failings up front, so you can know whether or not the game appeals to you. Combat in Darksiders III is fun, and often satisfying, but it fails to live up to the quality of either its predecessors or its inspiration. However, this review isn't "Is Darksiders III a good Darksiders game" or "Is Darksiders III a good Souls game?" Looking strictly at what III has to offer, I honestly enjoyed almost all of it, and don't regret spending a dime.

The game's story was surprisingly pretty good; it's nothing truly exceptional, but Fury is my favorite of the Horsemen by a significant stretch. Her initially unlikable ice-queen attitude peels away gradually, revealing a character defined as much by her faults as by her strengths. She grew on me before I really realized it, and by the game's end, I was honestly hoping to see her again in Darksiders IV, just to see where she ends up. 

The actual world design is something I'd also like to take a moment to praise. While never coming near Lordran in complexity, it does a wonderful job of weaving interconnected levels right next to each other, with those connections opening up in surprising locations once you have the proper tools. It's deeply satisfying to see a door you think you'll have to come back to hours later to open, only to be knocking on the other side and pushing it to reveal a familiar locale. 

I bought Darksiders III during the Winter Sale at $15. At that price, I think it's a steal, but $60 presumes polish this game simply does not have. As much as I enjoyed it, I can't recommend you buy it at that price unless you want to support the developers for their efforts. In this age of Destiny-esque loot grind in so many single player games, Darksiders III's simplicity was an incredibly welcome breath of fresh air. I would encourage you to grab the game at $40 or below if you have a passing interest; it's well worth the money at that point.

[h1]Great idea, flawed execution[/h1]

Let me just start by saying that I love the Darksiders franchise, so it pains me to write something critical of this game. 

First the overall plot of hunting down the Seven Deadly Sins is a great idea, and I think a natural extension to the themes in the DS universe. This game just kind of dropped the ball in a few places, though.

[b]The World[/b]
You play this game mostly on Earth, after the Apocalypse, but before the events of DS1. My main problem with this is the size of this world. In 2009, this was totally acceptable. But for 2018, I expected something much, much larger (Open World in fact). The map size is comparable to that of DS1 and it feels even smaller because [spoiler]because you don't get to ride your horse.[/spoiler]. Maybe that's why they got rid of the minimap in this game, to not draw as much attention to the size.

[b]Combat[/b]
Not bad. The new dodge system is a lot of fun (if you can do it right!) and the enemies are new ones mostly that weren't present in previous games. There are no executions though, which I miss. As far as weapons, you have your whip (very long reach by previous games' standards) and secondary weapons based on the hallow you are using (for closer combat). There is also the cross-blade that we saw in DS1.

[b]Graphics[/b]
The graphics are not very impressive to be honest. They don't look all that much improved from DS2 in 2012. This is especially evident in the human character models. They kind of look like Fortnite characters. Some of the other characters from DS1 look much the same as they did 10 years ago. This game came out 6 years after DS2, but you couldn't tell from the graphics or world size.

[b]Overall[/b]
Overall I enjoyed the story and playing through, enough to play it a little more in Apocalypse+ mode. There was a lot of potential that I think was left on the table, whether because people didn't have time or vision. Too bad. Maybe they will get it right if there ever is a standalone game with Strife.

[b]Aviso spoilers: [/b] Voy a contar alguna cosita relativa a los poderes de Furia o sus armas y armaduras, pero no habrá spoilers de la historia. Si no te importa saber de antemano que Furia puede hacer X o Y cosa adelante, si quieres descubrirlo todo por ti mismo/a, fuera de mi césped. 

No he terminado el juego, así a ojo debo llevar un 60-70% del mismo, pero llegaba con las expectativas muy bajas y me está gustando, así que me ha dado por compartir ya mis impresiones. 

Empecemos por el rendimiento y gráficos. Antes que nada, decir que el juego está capado a 60FPS. Poniendo en google 'unlock fps Darksiders 3' os saldrá un mini tutorial para desbloquearlos, es solo editar un archivo de configuración. 
Bien, gráficos y rendimiento. Tengo un i7-4790 y una RTX 2070 acompañados con 16GB de memoria y juego a 1440p. El juego suele rondar los 60 y pico y 70 fps. Tiene zonas más livianas que puede subir hasta los 100 pero son zonas puntuales. Y tiene mini caídas a 50 fps pero que duran un segundito como mucho y no son nada frecuentes. Eso en mi equipo, por supuesto. Si tuviera que mojarme diría que es un trabajo decente, pues los mapas son grandes, hay mucha vegetación y están llenos de cosas, pero tampoco es un pulido perfecto, pues el juego no es tan puntero gráficamente ni tiene tecnologías tensas que demanden mucha máquina. Por eso esperaba más que 6X-70 fps, pero bueno, no está mal, diría que no es un portento de la optimización y tampoco es un desastre. 
Y ya que hablamos de los gráficos vamos allá. El juego no tiene las mejores texturas, ni los mejores modelos, no tiene raytracing, ni tiene nada raro. Pero se ve bien. El resultado es muy redondito, muy bonito y coqueto. Se ve bien sin más, pero junto con el estilo del juego es eso, bonito. Además, los efectos son bastante chulos. Furia tiene 4 poderes de los cuales aún solo tengo 3, que inundan la pantalla de colorines y movidas que la verdad es que queda muy bien. Gracias a esto los combates tienen un aspecto muy atractivo. 

Y mencionados los combates pasamos a la jugabilidad, que es lo importante. No soy ningún experto en este género, al contrario, pero podría decir que el combate de Darksiders III es menos complejo que el de DMC5, por ejemplo, que creo yo que ahora es el máximo exponente y el rival a batir. Darksiders III no se le acerca a Devil May Cry, ni lo pretende, apostando por un sistema de combate mucho más simple y horizontal. No hay combos eternos en el aire ni puedes hacer combos infinitos, pues los enemigos, más reducidos en número que en otras propuestas similares se defienden y se cubren. El juego incluye una mecánica de contraataque, pues, si esquivas un golpe enemigo en el momento justo el tiempo se ralentiza y puedes propinarle un ataque crítico basado en tu nivel de daño arcano. 
Furia maneja en un principio una única arma, un látigo, bastante espectacular y agradable de usar. Pero no solo de látigos vive el hombre, y Furia va adquiriendo poderes/formas a medida que transcurre la aventura. Se llaman Vacíos, y te los entrega un señor que no diré quien es por eso de no spoilear gratuitamente. Hay cuatro y solo puedes tener uno activo, pero los puedes alternar en cualquier momento. El primero que conseguimos, el Vacío de llama, le otorga a Furia un arma nueva, poder usar fuego para interaccionar con el escenario, super salto para llegar a sitios elevados y, con la barra de ira llena, explota, se prende fuego y daña a los enemigos cercanos en el tiempo. Cada vacío le proporciona a Furia un arma nueva, una nueva forma de usar la ira y un salto distinto. Además, Furia cambia su aspecto físico según el vacío que lleve, cosa que es bastante espectacular. 
El arma principal, los cuatro vacíos, la ira y el esquive hacen que la jugabilidad de Darksiders III sea espectacular a la vista, aunque no tiene la variedad de otros títulos más exigentes. Quizás si vienes de echarle 100 horas a DMC5 para dominarlo se te quede corto este título. Si solo quieres pasar un buen rato zurrando a monstruitos es una muy buena opción.

Estas almas las puedes llevar a Vulgrim, un demonio que te las cambia por puntos. Con los susodichos puntos, puedes aumentar tu salud, tu daño físico o tu daño arcano. Es una progresión muy light que a nadie le importaría si no estuviera, como digo, un sistema de niveles estaría mejor, pero imagino que habrán querido mantener aunque sea mínimamente la progresión que es un clásico de la saga. 

Podría hablar de algunas cosas más, como el mundo y sus conexiones consigo mismo, los objetos consumibles, los enemigos y jefes, pero considero que eso sí es mejor ir descubriéndolo uno mismo a medida que va avanzando.

Aquí sin embargo si no esquivas en el momento bueno para el contraataque, igualmente esquivas. Así que en este sentido el combate es más sencillo que en los souls. Por cierto, vas sin escudo, por lo que es más como Bloodborne que Darksouls, nada de protegerte. Además tienes la opción de convertirte de vez en cuando cuando se llena cierta barra en una bestia invencible (al igual que en Darksiders I), lo que facilita la cosa. Resumiendo, la batalla se parece bastante al tema de los souls, pero aquí por un par de cosas es más sencilla.

-El escenario: en el 1 el escenario es más lineal, aunque luego las mazmorras son unos laberintos muy parecidos a los Zeldas. Quizá este es el punto fuerte del I, las mazmorras laberínticas. Pero su mapa general es mucho más lineal y pobre que el de los Zelda. Pero sin embargo considero que el mapa global del III es mejor, hay muchos caminos para ir de un sitio a otro, puedes enfrentarte a los jefes de distinta forma, en fin, un mapa mucho más rico globalmente.

- Tema de las hogueras, viajes. En los darksiders hay viajes rápidos entre ciertos puntos. En el III el viaje es más rápido, como en los souls.

- Tema de las almas (aquí ánimas, en bloodborne ecos de sangre). Sistema parecido a los soulborne. Vas acumulando al ir matando a enemigos y las puedes usar luego para comprar objetos o subir de nivel. Y además las que no llevas gastadas las pierdes al morir aunque puedes recuperarlas. Parecido sí, pero no igual. Primero porque si tienes 5000 animas y necesitas 10000 para subir nivel, puedes gastar las 5000 que tienes para dejar pendientes las otras 5000 con lo que ya no las vas a perder. En los souls tienes que llevarlas encima hasta llegar a 10000 arriesgándote. Pero es que en los souls si te matan, al renacer puedes recuperarlas si llegas al punto donde te mataron, pero tienes que llegar a la primera, las almas de 2 muertes atrás se pierden definitivamente. Aquí no, aunque te maten a la siguiente las almas siguen estando ahí, por lo que sabes que aunque te maten tarde o temprano las recuperarás. Eso hace que no sea tan chungo morir como en los souls. Y por si fuera poco los objetos que puedes romper para usar almas (tendría que estar diciendo ánimas, pero se me entiende) digamos que son más grandes en este juego que en los souls, por lo que la mayoría de las almas que se van obteniendo están en objetos que no pierdes y que puedes romper justo antes de romper. Así que si te agobiaba el tema de las almas en los souls, aquí en realidad no es para tanto. En el I ni las pierdes al morir, y se usan para adquirir cosas (no para subir de nivel).

- Subidas de nivel. En los souls al subir de nivel cada vez te cuesta más almas. Aquí también. Pero en los souls las mejoras además por subir el nivel van disminuyendo. Si le das a aumentar vida lo mismo al principio te dan 20 o 30 puntos más, y más adelante te sube 3 o 4 puntos incluso si subes mucho parece que no sube. Aquí hasta donde he llegado (dándole la vuelta al juego 2 veces) no parece haber descenso. Además también hay objetos que te permiten subir de nivel automáticamente con usarlos, y no sé, pero lo mismo puedes encontrar 15 por partida. En los souls no existe esto, bueno, quizá algún npc te permita alguna subida instantánea, pero no tantas veces por partida, muchas menos. Además los atributos a subir son tan solo 3, más sencillo. En darksiders I no hay en un principio mejoras de nivel, sino que mejoras con el equipamiento.

- Mejoras de armas y armaduras. Las armaduras solo se pueden mejorar en nueva partida + (osea, dándole una segunda vuelta al juego). Las mejoras de armadura son considerables (en los souls no). Y la mejora de las armas diría que es similar, tanto en la forma de subirlas como cuánto se va mejorando. En darksiders I la mejora del arma es automática con su uso.

- Forma de contar la historia. No es tan caótico como los souls, de hecho se explica lo que pasa de forma bastante clara.

- Decisiones importantes y finales. Nada, muy poca cosa, hay 2 decisiones que puedan variarte el final del juego, y la variación no es gran cosa tampoco. En darksiders I ni eso, más lineal.

- El caballo. Hay gente que se queja de que es un jinete sin caballo, que el caballo no se usa en el juego. Pero vamos, en el I si bien es cierto que se usa el caballo, sale muy tarde y solo se usa en un par de momentos (aparte de para poder recorrer zonas ya exploradas). No lo veo como un elemento tan usado en el I como para que se eche tanto en falta. No sé si en el II sale más.

En fin, el juego está bastante bien, a mi me ha gustado. Comparando con el I, pues sí, le han quitado varios elementos Zelda, la más importante quizá las mazmorras laberínticas (aunque aquí lo que es laberíntico es el mapa general). Luego otras diferencias menores (no hay cofres, no hay "cuartos de corazón" y cosas así). Pero a su vez tiene cosas mejores, desde luego el sistema de combate me gusta más.

Y respecto los soulsborne, sí, hay muchas cosas inspiradas en los souls, pero como he detallado más arriba, hay algunas diferencias que hacen que no sea tan chungo (mecánicas de batalla más fáciles, mejoras menos limitadas, el tema de perder las almas mucho más light, etc), además de poder elegir el modo de dificultad.

Por cierto, en mi primera partida elegí la dificultad máxima y me costó mucho el primer jefe final, que sale enseguida, sin embargo en la segunda dificultad más difícil me lo pasé a la primera. El primer jefe sale muy pronto cuando todavía no te has adaptado a las mecánicas del juego, pero lo cierto es que una vez que las controlas no es para tanto. Lo digo para indicar que no os asustéis si os atascáis tan al principio. Luego no se hace tan complicado. Algunos jefes hay luego que cuestan, pero algunos me parecieron una broma de fáciles que eran. Yo habría cambiado el orden de los jefes para adaptarlos a una curva de aprendizaje más natural.

En fin, recomendado, pero no lo pilles si es que quieres jugar a algo igual a los anteriores.

Darksiders 3 is a standard semi-open world hack and slash 3D platformer with some RPG elements, such as upgradeability and leveling up.

At Hot Runs Reviews, this was the first entry in the series we have played.

Darksiders 3 is set in a post-apocalyptic world and stars a female Ripe-4-Costume-Play-Protagonist (R4CPP). As we learn throughout the game, the R4CPP is a horsewoman of the apocalypse whose goals are to traverse a number of low budget jumping puzzles, defeat seven deadly sin based bloat-bosses and slay gruntingly horny monsters. The ejaculatory phallic tentacles of “Gluttony” were particularly revolting.

The primary pleasure of playing this game comes from the combat which is quick, sometimes button mashy, and can be very satisfying - as you gain new powers, such as fire, lightening, “purple drank” and ice. Like many things in this game, the abilities have obliquely vague names like stasis core among others. What these really translate to are Zelda-like skills that allow you to perform better in combat and open new areas on the map. It would have been very helpful if the game had more tutorials on how to use these.

The story of Darksiders 3 plays like a bad action movie, and is best ignored. Even if you pay attention you will be left wondering why any of this matters, and if your time is really being well spent. Do you really feel like investing in the success of unrelatable Nihilists with vague agendas?  

At Hot Runs Reviews, we found most of the dialog confusing and especially irritating to sit through in the sections where you are forced to “walk” and observe R4CPP listening to the Watcher.  The overall aesthetic lends itself to the fantasies of teenage boys in Sega CD commercials and horny Nu Metal fans.  Thankfully, the soundtrack did not contain any Nu Metal - with the majority of the sounds in the game being generated by the distant jerking-off-in-a -corner far away ghouls you encounter.        

The game does suffer from some performance issues, particularly when entering a new area.  Your computer will hang with no “loading” indication, leaving you wondering if purchasing a GFX card from eBay was wise. Fear not, you probably do not have a sh1tB@g- the game is just loading, and even if you have a Hot Runs Brand SSD, your run will be significantly cooled by these screens.

Our Expert Hot Runner did beat this game and did not regret playing it. However, he was not compelled to “save” all of the humans or proceed with new game plus. In end though, due to the inclusion of a Certified Bloated Boss - we can recommend this game to any fans of 3D platforming and end-of-world fetishists to play from their LAN equipped Bug Out Bunker while listening to "Rollin Rollin Rollin" by Limp Bizkit.

This one is really hard for me. I played a small amount of the first game but I didn't really enjoy the combat so I never finished it. I played through the second one several times, though, because I really enjoyed the combat, the variety of play styles, and the crucible, which honestly made the game worth replaying all on its own. Then we come to 3.

I got this game from humble bundle and was super excited. I was playing the crap out of it and loving basically every second of it. The bosses were fun to fight, the enemies were varied and interesting, fury and the watcher were hilarious, the environments were fun to explore and traverse, it was really a great experience. Then I got about half way through the game and things changes.

I still liked fury and the bosses were mostly ok but some of them sucked, enemies were just becoming an annoyance with super amped up damage and health, gimmicky mechanics and super armor as far as the eye can see, not to mention getting less varied, the watcher was getting annoying and seemingly was written by three different people. Environments became a bit bland and repetitive with less and less exploration, to the point that the final area seemed to have none unless I'm just blind. There were side stories that go nowhere and twists that seemed forced, with a general decrease in the quality of the writing, plus the crucible being a dlc unlike in darksiders 2 and there's basically no build variety because there's no skill tree. I'm going to go into more detail now but if you want to avoid spoilers then I'll say: play it if you love the series, love hack n slash, or it's on sale, and play it on easy if you want to stay sane.

The biggest problem was the bosses so I'll start there. The bosses that bothered me the most were gluttony, pride, and envy 2, I guess you would call her. Gluttony was a weird mix of boring and frustrating. He has a grab that has fairly little warning so if you're in melee range it could happen any time and if you don't have a lot of levels in health or you're already hurt it will likely kill you which leaves you sitting back and waiting to counter with the spear for a ranged attack, he has these flaily attacks where he retreats inside the tentacle and then does two sweeps and 1-2 slams and for some reason these attacks are undodgable as far as I can tell; no matter when or what direction you dodge, even if you trigger the perfect dodge and even if you have the enchantment that increases your dodge i-frames, you will get hit by them, so that further pushes you to the walls of the arena, but if you're far away he'll do an attack where he spits pools of acid where you are that stay there forever which means you can't get close but you can't get away either, and in the second phase you just end up underwater trying to make him do this attack where his kraken portion tries to suck you in then you make it suck in a bomb and it's nothing special.

Pride wasn't that terrible but after the first third/half of the fight she pulls the head off of the statue at the far side of the arena and makes it float around the arena shooting out a beam that never stops, the head can't be destroyed, the beam is undodgable, it does absurd damage, and can get you combo'd to death instantly if she attacks at the same time you get hit by it. It's not particularly hard but it's not that fun either because of the beam and it honestly just feels like a lazy attempt at difficulty that ruined an otherwise serviceable fight for me.

Then there's envy 2, lord help me. I was REALLY enjoying the fight with envy 2 at first. She uses the talisman, after taking it from you, to summon the souls of the other sins to use attacks from their fights. But. She has an attack that hits 360, is undodgable, does a significant amount of damage, and is so fast that if you are doing anything when she starts the animation you cannot get out of range. But that's _not even the worst part._ The wrath attack that she uses is from the second fight with him where he creates three shockwaves back to back. The shockwaves are undodgabel so you have to jump them. Except. If she does an attack while wrath is out then 99.99% of the time you'll get hit by one while avoiding the other. If that happens you will get stunlocked to death by her combo and his shockwaves hitting you. This one thing killed me 6 times and ruined the fight for me because every time I saw wrath I would think "if she does anything I'm dead and I have to start over" and that's not a fun or fair way for the fight to work. There are also a lot of bad hitboxes in this fight specifically that will have you getting hit by attacks that are nowhere near you.

As for the normal enemies, they get very repetitive (to the point that the final areas only have like five different types of enemies throughout,) they are just given a ton more health and damage to make them a continued threat, which feels extremely lazy, anything bigger than your average demon gets significant super armor, sometimes seemingly infinite super armor, and they get very gimmicky. One enemy will summon much weaker clones of itself to attack you. I don't know if there's a limit but I've seen it have at least two clones summoned at once. That same enemy also has extreme super armor so you can't stun it basically ever AND fairly high damage that will decimate you if you get stunlocked by it and one or two clones. Then there's another enemy that summons enemies but it summons full power enemies, not weakened versions, it can buff them, it has a metric ton of health and super armor, hits like a truck, and to top things off it has a shield that is always active so if you end up on it's left side while trying not to get ganked by the adds you're shit out of luck for doing damage.

Sometimes she's intentionally annoying to fury, sometimes she respects fury, sometimes she's just an asshole, and while I think any one of these approaches would have been good they really tear each other down. It's very confusing when in one sentence she's being silly, the next she's complimenting you, and the next she's treating you like garbage.

There's not a lot to add to what I said about the environments. The city, the catacombs, and the subway are all pretty good, they have a wide variety of locations and designs, good enemy variety, etc. but the later levels, the last area and the bonelands in particular, are very one note and have a small number of enemies that are just copy/pasted all over the map and very little to find, most of which isn't even really hidden.

Then there's the side stories that just don't matter. The lord of hollows, henceforth known as gwyn, tells you to kill abraxis, abraxis tells you he's gonna free BBEG supreme and gwyn is going to hollow the entire planet and he's using us to achieve it, then you can kill abraxis or tell him you'll kill gwyn. I killed abraxis and then went to gwyn and he was like "yup, i'm gonna hollow everything. you gonna kill me? because now's your only chance." So I did. And then that was it. You don't get anything for it, the council doesn't say anything about it, it doesn't change anything. Maybe there's more story if you only kill one but I don't know. There's also a sentient tornado that you destroy and it thanks you but the watcher gets mad at you for it and then it never comes up again.

The writing really goes downhill to the point that the cutscene right after killing envy 2 makes little sense, which is bad because it's the second to last. Then at the last second they reveal that one of the humans was strife all along! Boy, sure am glad he did literally nothing to help me throughout the game and fury somehow couldn't tell.

Overall, I'd say you should play it if you love the series, love the genre, or it's on sale, but it's only worth playing on easy.

81589928.review:
This game is embarassing to look at. Every element it borrowed for its own mishmash of mechanics are all poorly executed, even parts of its predecessors! Funnily enough, the blood mark system from Dark Souls is the least offensive in this stew.

The whip feels like a flaccid piece of string, only good to repeatedly flinch enemies that approach you, which rarely works out as their recovery is so fast that a missed swing from this sequence of attacks immediately has them ready to counterattack you between your own swings. Even with the first unlocked dual fire whatever weapon that lets you rush down, it's a constant recurring theme that if you want to play this like an action game - you know, like Darksiders has been in the past - you'll need to dodge constantly.

Good grief this game almost fetishises dodging. If you're up against more than one enemy, you'd best swing once at most and dodge right after. Don't dodge too soon, though, or any swing will just hit! Which is a great thing to see happen when there's five enemies clobbering at you and didn't dodge just right. What happens is usually instant death unless they were all measly mooks.

I'm playing on the difficulty above Story. I think it's called Normal and there are about five more difficulties harder than it, yet I find myself dying in two swings against those red... lanky goblins? I don't know what they are, but they're quick, annoying, and they love waddling off right out of your camera.

Ahhh, the camera, the single worst part of this game. If you don't use lock on, enemies will quickly find themselves out of your field of view, but this isn't a Capcom game! They'll gleefully take free swings at you that you have no way of properly dodging in time. So as soon as you notice one going off-screen (and you don't always notice - what with some of them blending in the bland decor) you're pretty much going to have to back off so you can move your thumb from the attack button to the camera thumbstick.

What about lock-on? I'm glad you asked! Left bumper is an almost vital part to controlling the battle, letting you activate whatever super modes I can't bother to remember the name of or letting you switch elements. Too bad left trigger requires to be held for lock-on to work. There's a toggle, you say? Well the problem with that is that as soon as the enemy dies that its locked on to, lock-on just disables again. Not to mention that the lock-on camera does not solve the above paragraph's issue and enemies will gladly stab you in the back as they're very quick to position themselves to.

This game is a practice in frustration, quite fitting for the horseman's name. None of the enemies feel good to fight against in any situation. Singled out they're a pushover, in a group they're a bother that drag out combat with the necessity of constant dodging. 

...but let's go deeper! Darksiders has never played to the strengths of its protagonists. The final horseman is a shootey guy, but he's now in an ARPG? Even though some of the best parts of previous Darksiders was the shooting in third person? Why not have Fury in there instead? Whips and the focus of more ranged melee fits right in the ARPG genre! More so, why not have Darksiders 2 like that? It had a loot system that, again, fits an ARPG much better than a sleepy third person platformer/hack'n'slasher.

And War. I never finished the first Darksiders, but at least swinging a sword felt satisfying enough. A combination of range and umpth. Fury's whip has ranged, but not enough to make for a real advantage and lacks any kind of satisfaction. I picked up a sword that's part of a puzzle but I'm literally just ignoring the puzzle and going through other parts of the world because its moveset and damage are more satisfying to use than a measly whip. Sadly the animation leaves me a touch more exposed, leading to more frequent deaths.

Darksiders III needed serious reflection on what it borrowed and what it iterated from the predecessors, and has failed on all accounts. I can't recommend this game in good faith, and I already got it from Humble Monthly, so consider the already low bar it failed to meet.

Oh, and here's the kicker. The game freezes on the main menu if Discord is running. GG.

81449435.review:
Darksiders 3 is a hack-and-slash. The latest installment in the Darksiders series where you play as Fury. Supposedly, you are 1 of the 4 Horsemen but it is not the traditional 4 Horsemen (Pestilence, War, Famine,  Death). The objective is to level up and kill the final boss in a linear fashion.

Gameplay-wise, controller is best. If you are using a PS controller, you cannot change the controls. It is pegged to the Microsoft Xbox controller.

Conclusion, Darksiders 3, just play it on Story mode. Balanced mode is very difficult.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Sufficient Fun
Not much depth but above average.

2. Puzzles
Very interesting. The steps are not so obvious. The obvious step is wrong. So, you have to think and guess what the level designer intended. E.g. 3 swords puzzle.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Unnatural Worldbuilding
The apocalypse has come, now all of a sudden New York city has underground demonic paths and caves? It's disjointed design. It doesn't sync well. The environment is very "meh". You don't go, "This is amazing". You go, "Meh".

2. Attacks don't Connect
Despite using the Unreal Engine, DS3 doesn't have the same auto-hit like Batman. You end up swinging your chain at empty air. Unsatisfactory feeling from a hack-and-slash game.

3. Reload Screen
If you die, reload. This is such an archaic and old method. If you die often on the higher difficulties, you spend 10 seconds each time reloading the stage multiplied by the number of times you died.

4. Weird Glitches
Dying in the lift at the Maker's Forge if you don't call it up. Dying in the acid sea and you can't reach your body.

5. No Real Secrets
Just in some alcove somewhere.

6. Shiny Orb
Why does a shiny orb represent everything?

7. Resetting the Fiery Weapons
After getting Salvation (ranged weapon), you turn offed the Fiery Weapons. 

8. Salvation is Unoptimized
Instead of aiming and auto-targeting, you have to Right Thumbstick, hold Left Trigger, move Right Thumbstick to target, Right Trigger to fire. 4 steps to do 1 thing.

9. 4 Hollows Don't Make Sense in Context of the Game
Incoherent. 

10. Changing Forms is Tedious
LB + ABXY? So difficult to carry out in combat.

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Let Your Attacks Connect But the Enemies Can Block
Let the attacks hit but if you make a mistake, the enemies block.

2. Optimize Salvation
Just hold LT, move Right Thumbstick to aim, release LT. 1.5 steps. Don't forget to let it hit the enemy on the boomerang.

3. 7 Sins, 7 Weapons
Pride - Long Spear (Melee and can be thrown in combat)
Greed - Ranged Salvation (Greedy so it grows stronger with the number of Sin Weapons you collect, Ranged only, multi-target, Ignore the puzzle requirements levels up with other weapons)
Sloth - Shield (Slow and doesn't move around, Freeze, Passive, Increases your Counter Window)
Lust - Armour (Sexy body, Lightning, Passive)
Wrath - Axes (Like the game, Flame)
Envy - Dual Edges 
Gluttony - Gavel (Hammer, Void)

4. Upgrading Sin Weapons Increase their Potency
E.g. Gluttony's Gavel would gain AOE smash effect, followed by black hole effect that pulls enemies in before the AOE smash effect

5. More Uses for the Lightning form
Power up engines, teleport to hard to reach places.

6. Instead of Changing Forms, Change Sin Weapons
Just LT/RT to switch between the Sin weapons you have.

7. 7 Sins, 7 Zones, 7 Types of Monsters
Each zone to have monsters that reflect each sin. E.g. Greed would have creatures that drop more items and steal the Souls that drop. Sloth would have big armoured creatures that are slow but hard to kill, Lust would have beautiful, elegant creatures that either lure you towards traps and ambushes or bait and run away, Wrath would have creatures that enrage and go berserk when they see you.

8. No Linearity
Choose the other in which you kill the 7 Sins. No Envy is first and Pride is last.

80960126.review:
I really tried to like this game, but at the end of the day, it had a few glaring faults that made me simply not enjoy the act of playing it.

Put simply:
1) You cannot dodge/heal in the middle of an animation. I understand that this was a deliberate design decision. It was a bad one. Any game that makes dodging THIS important as a mechanic (in so much as I'd say it makes up about 80% of any combat), you should always be able to cancel an attack to dodge.

Caveat: They DID release a classic combat mode in which you CAN in fact, cancel your attack animations to dodge, which made the game at least playable, for me, but you still have to completely stop what you're doing if you want to heal, which is a big problem for 2 reasons: Your dodging/sprinting are not very fast, and all the enemies move faster than you can get away from them, which means you can effectively only heal between combos, if ALL present enemies are either stunned, dead or too far away to hit you, because even if you DO manage to get your heal off, it's not instant (even in classic mode) and takes about a full second or two to actually replenish your health.

2) Enemies to not get stunned from hits consistently, some hits stun them, some do not, some enemies get stunned more than others, and some can straight up block your attacks, which may all sound pretty par the course for an action RPG, except this is a game that seems to favor careful and deliberate combat, wherein you dodge a lot and wait for an opportunity to strike (which in itself seems to against the theme of the main character, who is impatient and hot-headed, yet you the player are expected to play her as if she is careful, methodical and cunning). The issue with this, is that you can dodge, attack, and all but ONE enemy will get stunned, and if that enemy happens to be outside your FOV you'll never notice until he hits you and chunks you for a good 1/3 of your health, despite being a trash mob. 

Put simply, nothing about the combat feels consistent. The difficulty, enemy stuns, the amount of enemies, and even the damage each enemy deals (I fought one mini-boss about 17 times, most of my deaths due to spamming the heal button over and over and it not healing, and sometimes, for absolutely no reason, one of his base attacks would 1-shot me from full health, when every other time it only dealt maybe 1/2 to 1/3 of my health). Your attacks feel unresponsive at time and when they DO go off, they lack weight on even the lowest tiers of enemies. The dodging, while significantly less clunky on classic mode, never feels great, because even when you DO dodge and go in for a counter, if you miss or fail to stun even one enemy, you are still going to get hit and lose a massive chunk of health, which takes away all of the rewarding feeling of pulling off the otherwise rather stylish dodges/counters.

At the end of the day, the reason I stopped playing was because the game simply wasn't fun to play. It felt challenging for all the wrong reasons. I felt like I was struggling more with the controls and combat mechanics than I was with any of the actual enemies, with the except of certain sections where the main struggle was due to the encounter being designed in such a way that the basic mechanics of the game do not properly equip you to deal with, such as hordes of trash mobs dancing outside your extremely limited field of view, blocking all your combos, and forcing you to dodge, but never actually letting you get more than 1 attack in your counter-combo off because if you try to you'll get hit by something else.

If you want to get into the franchise, get Darksiders 2, that game is absolutely amazing. If you are already a fan of the series and want to play another game that's different in a GOOD way, get Darksiders Genesis, it takes the series' hack n' slash style back to its roots and was actually really fun. If you want a souls-like game, just go play one of the MANY souls-likes out there. Literally the only reason to play this game over any of the others is either to suppor the developers in hopes they make a 4th game that will ideally learn from these mistakes, or because it's on a huge sale for $20 or less and you want to find out for yourself what all the polarizing reviews are about.

[h1]The third entry of the Darksiders series takes a step towards the Soulslike universe and it all for the better[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]
-Sound, music and grapchics quality you'd expect from a AAA title
-Satisfying core gameplay loop of stomping minions, tackling groups of mid-tier enemies, hunting minibosses and bosses
-Fight mechanics took a step towards the soulslike formula of learning enemy movesets, figuring out the weak spots in the pattern, then dodging & counter-attacking which I find much more enjoyable than that of previous titles'
-Somewhat present customization via attribute points, gear enhancements and multiple weapon options
-Ever-present indicator points you in the general direction of story progress
-At the same time, the world appears to be more open than in DS 1 and 2, allowing the player to wander off more freely

[b]Cons[/b]
-Options menu is a disappointment for a AAA title
-The menu feels clunky and unresponsive should you attempt to interact with a mouse & keyboard combo
-Asking 60 buckaroos (or even 80 for the deluxe edition) for a 2+ years old game is more than questionable

I've only spent close to 5 hours with DS3 so far, but have enjoyed every minute of it so far and can't wait to get back at it, [u]I'd recommend you keep your eyes open for a reasonable bargain and get your hands on it, I doubt it'll be a let-down for you either![/u]

80340203.review:
[h1] TL:DR [/h1]
Another of The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse is in line, this time to defeat the Seven Deadly Sins. This is also a new game design (Dark Soul-ish) in the Darksiders game series and one that does not please its fans. Nevertheless, the game is good and can be entertaining for any gamer, especially if on sales event. This is one of those games that make you love and hate them at the same time.

[h1] DISCLAIMER [/h1]
Remember, in this game, DODGE, DODGE, DODGE. Don't be turned-off by so many bad reviews, players get easily frustrated when the dash & slash does not do wonders killing everything in their favorite game. If you play it properly, it is a good game. Just do timely dodges, learn the proper combos commands when moving on walls and you will be safe from frustration. Failing to dodge fast when required is often a recipe for a guaranteed wipe. Dodge and upgrade your skills constantly and you will finish the game smiling.

[h1] PROS [/h1]
- Good story and mythological references, along with the usual humor.
- The overall design of the game keeps you involved from the beginning to the end, it gives you reasons to reach the end of story.
- Good enough graphics and art-style, though some areas could be improved.
- Decent voice-overs and soundtrack.
- Decent combat system and skills-tree (again, you must properly use the DODGE skill).
- Interesting puzzles to solve in order to advance, some of them pretty smartly designed (just think out of the box).
- Interesting wall movement mechanics.
- Well designed boss fights (saying for the third and last time, in this game DODGE is your friend for both mobs and bosses).
- One of the games where skipping content and mobs in the way is really not much of an option (yeah, sorry, I dislike speed-runs, games should be played as they were designed).

[h1] CONS [/h1]
- Harder to play than previous games. Maybe too much. On harder difficulties you may find the game frustrating, at least until you reach the higher level of upgrades for your character. At some point, unless you upgraded your character skills enough, you begin to wonder if you play the mighty FURY the horsemen of Apocalypse or just a pale shadow of her.
- Occasionally, you may find it difficult to seek your direction towards main objectives, in water and underground.
- Dodging in combat requires fast reactions, sometimes too fast.
- The save-system consists of automatic checkpoints, so if you don't reach Vulgrim NPC (or interact with him for manually save if you made a level re-loop) and get killed you must start over from the last checkpoint.
- FPS count may vary a lot even on best gaming computers.
- The lack of map / minimap may confuse some players used to get straight directions by consulting them.
